Notes on Lodging Allowance Rates


	

(a)	Rate A	Applies to personnel who, if required to live in Service single accommodation, would be exempt both food and accommodation charges.


(b)	Rate B	Applies to personnel who, if required to live in Service single accommodation, would pay either single or MU rate of food charge, but be exempt accommodation charges.


(c)	Rate C	Applies to personnel who, if required to live in Service single accommodation, would pay either single or MU rate of food charge, and accommodation charges.


(d)	Rate D	Applies to single personnel who on posting to a new duty station where Service single accommodation is not available, occupy their own accommodation, provided that all other conditions of entitlement to LA are met.


(e)	Rate E	Applies to married unaccompanied personnel who on posting to a new duty station where Service single accommodation is not available occupy accommodation owned wholly or in part by the claimant, or his/her spouse, or dependant child, or by a non-public company in which any of the former maintain a financial interest - provided that the accommodation is not the claimant's main or family residence.


(f)	Claimants under 18 years of age and who receive New Entrant Rate of Pay are not required to pay council tax, therefore, when required to pay accommodation charges they will not pay the MOD's CILOCT. As appropriate LA rates include an element for MOD's CILOCT, 7p should be added to those rates marked with a (f). Claimants under 18 years of age who pay reduced accommodation charges, therefore, when required to pay accommodation charges, should have 40p (33p accommodation charges +7p CILOCT) added to those rates marked with a (f).


(g)	For single Northern Ireland Claimants add £3.46.


(h)	For married Northern Ireland Claimants add £2.53.

title: Consultation document on the UK Government's new strategy on HIV/AIDS in the developing world
text:
Consultation document on the UK Government's new strategy on HIV/AIDS in the developing worldCONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
on the 
UK GOVERNMENT’S NEW 
STRATEGY ON HIV/AIDS IN THE 
DEVELOPING WORLD  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
1 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
 
This Consultation Document has been prepared as part of the process 
of producing a new UK Government Strategy on HIV/AIDS. It is not a 
statement of government policy but rather a paper to encourage 
feedback and ideas on what should become UK policy. The document 
describes actions that the UK Government is proposing need to be 
taken as part of the global response to the epidemic.  
 
This Consultation Document continues the discussion initiated by the 
UK Government’s Call for Action on HIV/AIDS and will serve as the basis 
for a far-reaching consultation with civil society, NGOs, international, 
multilateral and donor bodies, the private sector and developing country 
Governments. The new Strategy will be published later this year.  
 
The primary question being posed during this period of consultation is: 
what role should the UK Government play in the global response to 
HIV/AIDS? In particular: 
 
• How best can the UK Government work with its partners? 
• What is the best balance between UK led action and our support of 
international action? 
• What is the best balance between multilateral, bilateral and research 
activity? 
• What should be the balance of work with Government, civil society 
and the private sector?  
• What should be the balance between prevention, treatment and care, 
and impact mitigation? 
• How should the UK focus its attention between emerging epidemics 
and highly affected countries?  
• How much attention should be given to Middle Income Countries 
(especially those risking greater impoverishment because of 
HIV/AIDS)? 
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
2 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
INTRODUCTION 
 
1. HIV/AIDS is a major threat to development and the elimination of world 
poverty. No region of the World is unaffected. Whilst the most serious 
epidemics are in Southern Africa, emerging epidemics elsewhere, 
especially in Asia and Eastern Europe, are growing rapidly and pose a 
significant threat. By 2010 there will be more Asians living with HIV than 
Africans. 
 
2. Over recent years – and especially since 2001 – there have been 
significant shifts in the international communities response to HIV/AIDS. 
This has included: greater international advocacy; increased political 
leadership; substantial increases in global funding; significant international 
interest in lowering drug prices; and considerable research efforts focused 
on the development of new technologies and solutions. However, the 
global response to date remains inadequate. We are not on track to 
contain the epidemic, and in turn, this threatens our ability to achieve all of 
the Millennium Development Goals. . 
 
3. HIV/AIDS is an exceptional challenge requiring an exceptional response. 
Recognising this, on World AIDS last year, the UK Government published 
its Call for Action on HIV/AIDS. It described the Prime Minister’s strong 
commitment to the global fight against HIV/AIDS and represented the first 
step in an intensification of effort the UK to tackle the epidemic. The UK’s 
new strategy on HIV/AIDS to be published later this year will describe how 
the whole of the UK Government – led by DFID – is geared to support the 
global effort to tackle the epidemic.  
 
Box 1: Roles and comparative advantages of different UK Government 
Departments  
 
The Department for International Development leads the UK’s efforts to tackle the 
epidemic in the developing world. DFID will build on its strong network of country offices, 
the technical skill of its staff and leadership role within the international community. DFID 
has a traditional strength of supporting responses which are pro-poor, equity based, 
gender sensitive, targeted, evidence based and help strengthen nationally owned 
systems.   
 
The Foreign and Commonwealth Office provides high-level political leadership in 
tackling HIV/AIDS both bilaterally, through the work of British Ambassadors and their 
staff through the world and multilaterally through our engagements in the UN, G8, EU 
and New Partnership for Africa’s Development. 
 
The Department of Health’s action to combat HIV/AIDS is centred on the epidemic in 
England and focuses on policies relating to sexual health and HIV. DH leads on the 
UK’s relationship with the World Health Organisation.   
 
HM Treasury ensures adequate levels of finance for HIV/AIDS responses, including new 
models (e.g. International Finance Facility) and leads on the UK’s engagement with the 
International Monetary Fund and World Bank. 
 
The UK Government’s workforce, especially all those posted overseas, are supported by 
an effective HIV/AIDS workplace policy covering prevention and care. 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
3 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
 
4. The UK Government cannot and does not attempt to work in isolation. 
There is a clear international framework in place for action on HIV/AIDS. 
The UK will continue to work towards the key international targets set in 
the UNGASS Declaration of Commitment on HIV/AIDS including: 25% 
fewer infections by 2005; three million people on treatment by 2005; 
achieving the “three ones”; and slowing progress of HIV/AIDS by 2015. To 
achieve these goals, each actor involved in HIV/AIDS – civil society, 
NGOs, international, multilateral and donor bodies, the private sector and 
developing country Governments – must work to their comparative 
advantages to play a complementary and effective role. Tough choices will 
need to be made at the global, regional and country level about where the 
UK - and others - should prioritise effort and resources.  
 
Box 2: The role of the UK Government within an international context 
 
The UK Government’s response to HIV/AIDS will be set firmly within the international 
context. In all of the areas for action proposed in this consultation document, we will 
work closely with other development partners, focusing our own efforts where we can 
add most value.  
 
The UK Government will continue to work through a mixture of channels: including our 
bilateral country and regional programmes; through multilateral bodies such as the EC, 
the World Bank, the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria (GFATM) and UN 
agencies, who all have an important part to play. We will also work with research bodies.  
 
The choice of where best to focus the UK’s efforts between these will depend on which 
elements are is best placed to take action and public-private partnerships. For example, 
whilst investing in the UK’s bilateral programmes can provide finance and support 
catalytic approaches, working with the UN harnesses their unique convening function. 
Individual UN agencies also bring their own specialist skills. These include co-ordination 
(UNAIDS), advocacy (UNAIDS, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNIFEM), technical advice (WHO) 
and delivery (UNICEF). The UK encourages its international partners to play to their 
strengths, working as part of a coherent overall effort.  
 
5. This consultation document is structured around five key areas which the 
UK Government considers essential to the global response:   
 
I. Focusing on the poor 
 
II. Scaling up evidence-based interventions  
 
III. Building effective national responses 
 
IV. Improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the international response 
 
V. Investing in long-term solutions 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
4 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
I. FOCUSING ON THE POOR  
 
6. The UK’s ambition to eliminate global poverty underpins our commitment 
to addressing HIV/AIDS and to supporting national responses that reach 
and benefit the poor, not the most affluent. Our global approach to 
HIV/AIDS therefore stresses that national strategies need to be pro-poor, 
gender and equity focused and designed in such a way as to reduce 
stigma and discrimination. Towards these ends, the global response 
should: 
  
Support HIV/AIDS programmes that help reduce poverty  
 
7. HIV/AIDS both causes and is driven by poverty. Unlike other diseases, the 
HIV/AIDS epidemic is particularly devastating as it disproportionately 
impacts upon both the most productive - who provide economic growth - 
and the poorest in societies.  HIV/AIDS impacts upon the capacity, and 
productivity of households as well as public and private sectors. 
Preventing, treating and mitigating the effects of HIV/AIDS will reduce 
these impacts and contribute to poverty elimination. Poverty also 
increases vulnerability to HIV/AIDS. Women and girls living in extreme 
poverty, for example, are more likely to exchange sex for money and 
goods to survive.  In order to prevent households from falling into chronic 
poverty, responses should support national efforts to develop or extend 
social protection programmes in the most affected countries. These 
programmes will need to consider the effectiveness and feasibility of cash 
transfers as a sustainable means of supporting the most vulnerable. 
 
Scale up efforts to address gender inequalities caused by the epidemic  
 
8. Women and girls are biologically, socially and economically more 
susceptible to HIV/AIDS than men.  Responses should support work with 
government and civil society partners to reduce the factors that exacerbate 
women’s and girl’s vulnerability, including promoting women’s rights to 
political voice, reproductive health and the inheritance and ownership of 
land. Responses should support efforts to ensure education for girls, 
prioritise efforts to reduce gender-based violence including sexual abuse, 
and scale up efforts to work with men and boys to tackle gender 
inequalities. Responses should also involve working with governments and 
other donors to ensure that national polices and programmes address the 
impact of HIV/AIDS on women and girls. 
 
Support strategies that promote an equitable response to HIV/AIDS   
 
9. Marginalised groups, defined by poverty, gender, ethnicity, age, sexuality, 
disability or other social factors are particularly vulnerable to HIV/AIDS and 
its impacts. Our primary goal should be to ensure that vulnerable and poor 
people are able to access the information, resources and services they 
need to prevent, treat and mitigate the impact of HIV/AIDS. Responses 
should ensure equitable access to treatment, including Anti-Retrovirals 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
5 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
(ARVs), and care. Responses should support strategies that address the 
rights and needs of marginalised populations. This will require a pro-active 
stance on equity, ensuring the inclusion of disempowered groups, 
legislative and policy reform, and supporting civil society activities.  
 
Work to reduce stigma and discrimination related to HIV/AIDS  
 
10. Freedom from discrimination is a fundamental human right. The United 
Nations Commission on Human Rights has confirmed that discrimination 
on the basis of HIV/AIDS is prohibited. Stigma and discrimination against 
people with HIV/AIDS and marginalized populations constitute one of the 
greatest barriers to preventing, treating and addressing impact of 
HIV/AIDS. Responses should work with civil society, and the private and 
public sectors to empower people living with HIV/AIDS and marginalised 
populations; address institutional discrimination in public and private 
organisations; educate people about HIV/AIDS, and support work on 
legislative reform. Responses should continue to advocate with 
governments to ensure that they meet their international obligations on 
human rights, including reducing stigma and discrimination.  
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
6 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
II. SCALING UP EVIDENCE-BASED INTERVENTIONS 
 
11. There is no single solution for tackling HIV/AIDS. The stage and nature of 
the epidemic varies across the world. In the worst affected countries 
HIV/AIDS is reversing the development gains of recent years and is the 
major obstacle to poverty reduction. Elsewhere there is a time-limited 
opportunity to prevent emerging and concentrated epidemics from 
spreading widely.   
 
12. Across the spectrum of the epidemic’s stages urgent action is needed 
now.   Leadership will be vital. Political leaders can dramatically influence 
the course of the epidemic – for good or ill. Yet while high-level political 
leadership is essential to create an encouraging environment, leadership 
is also pivotal at other levels of society. Faith based leaders have a unique 
contribution to make, as do leaders in the private sector, traditional 
leaders, community leaders, people with HIV/AIDS and women leaders.  
 
13. Responses need to be proportional to the need and must therefore be 
adapted to reflect country and regional differences. Choices need to be 
made about the combination and scale of interventions necessary to 
control the epidemic in each situation.  The basic ingredients of an 
effective response are known: prevention, treatment & care, and 
alleviating the impact on societies. When effectively combined these 
elements have the ability to change the course of the epidemic - but only if 
implemented in timely fashion and appropriately taken to scale. The global 
response should: 
 
Strengthen the effectiveness and coverage of prevention efforts 
 
14. Prevention is the mainstay of any effective response. Urgent action is 
needed to avert the devastating consequences of widespread HIV 
infection in countries with emerging epidemics, and to limit spread in 
countries with established epidemics. We must learn from experience and 
apply the evidence of successful intervention. The preventive interventions 
we know work must be taken to scale.  Prevention programmes require 
leadership and change at the political, community, household and 
individual levels. Global responses should be informed by evidence and 
involve: 
 
• A broad range of biomedical and behavioural responses including: 
ongoing epidemiological and behavioural surveillance to better 
understand the epidemic; condom promotion and marketing; HIV/AIDS 
education for young people including life skills and peer education; 
mass and participatory communication; preventing and treating 
Sexually Transmitted Infections; blood safety; post-exposure 
prophylaxis; access to male circumcision; and, prevention of mother to 
child transmission.  
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
7 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
• Improved access to comprehensive reproductive health rights and 
services. At the local level, sexual and reproductive health services are 
the cornerstone of efforts to enable people, especially young people, to 
make informed, safe and healthy choices. Only about one in five 
people at risk have access to prevention information and services. 
More needs to be done to better integrate services for HIV/AIDS and 
reproductive health so that they are complementary and not 
competitive.  
 
• Policy development and targeted interventions to contain the epidemic 
by focusing on vulnerable population groups including: injecting drug 
users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, mobile populations, 
prisoners and others at high risk. Responses should support harm 
reduction measures for injecting drug users particularly in emerging 
and rapidly accelerating epidemics in Asia and Eastern Europe.  
 
• Programmes that address the underlying causes of vulnerability and 
aim to change the environments in which people have little choice but 
to take risks that may expose them to HIV infection.  Effective 
measures include increasing girl’s access to education, supporting 
community mobilisation, securing land rights for women, confronting 
stigma and discrimination and action around livelihoods strategies. 
Responses should support civil society initiatives to increase the 
engagement and voice of people affected by HIV/AIDS, and 
marginalised populations.  
 
• Increased access to confidential voluntary counselling and testing, 
which serves as a fulcrum between strengthening preventive efforts 
and delivering treatment and care.  Voluntary counselling and testing 
needs to be taken to scale and rolled out equitably. Testing must 
remain voluntary and confidential, and not involve coercion 
 
Support efforts to provide increased, and eventually universal, access to 
treatment and care  
 
15. Responses should support efforts to provide increased, and eventually 
universal, access to treatment and care for people with HIV/AIDS, as part 
of the WHO / UNAIDS ‘3 by 5’ goal to provide anti-retroviral therapy to 3 
million people in developing countries by the end of 2005.. The rationale 
for this is based on equity considerations, improved effectiveness of 
treatment programmes in resource poor settings, significant changes to 
the costs of treatment, and a greater understanding of the fundamental 
importance of care in effective responses to HIV/AIDS, to restore hope, to 
reinforce prevention efforts, to prolong life and reduce the numbers of 
children growing up without carers. 
 
16. Internationally there is now recognition that treatment and care are 
essential components of a comprehensive response. Whereas previously 
the emphasis in programme design and implementation was firmly on 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
8 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
prevention efforts, there is now increasing recognition that treatment is a 
key component of the response and that care has become a vital and 
necessary one. Treatment with ARVs is a major prevention and mitigation 
intervention. It can reduce the level of transmission in a population and 
gives people a reason to seek testing. ARV treatment is a pro poor 
intervention as it enables a sick population to maintain economic 
productivity, reduces ‘short termism’ and asset stripping, prevents or 
delays widowhood/orphanhood thus preventing the creation of further 
vulnerability to infection. However, this should not mean abandoning 
prevention in order to focus on treatment and care. All elements have to 
be considered in any response to HIV/AIDS as part of a broad continuum. 
This will include comprehensive prevention efforts, voluntary counselling 
and testing, anti-retroviral therapy, treatment and prevention of 
opportunistic infections (including TB), home based care, palliative care, 
and impact mitigation.  
 
17. The global response at the country and regional level should be to 
promote a treatment and care response, within a continuum and working 
in partnership with others, that is pro-poor, equity and gender focused, 
helps strengthen the systems that deliver health, and supports prevention 
and impact mitigation efforts. Working with civil society and the private 
sector at country level on treatment and care issues is fundamental to an 
effective response.  
 
Develop strategies to address the socio-economic impacts of HIV/AIDS  
 
18. In the worst affected countries, HIV/AIDS is wiping out 50 years of 
development gains. The immediate impacts of HIV/AIDS illness and death 
are felt at individual and household level through the loss of emotional 
support, labour and income. Increased morbidity, mortality and 
absenteeism for caring and attending funerals will affect civil society, 
public services and businesses. Projections suggest that, in highly-
affected countries, there will be long-term impact on saving rates, 
investment, markets, services, education and, ultimately on political and 
social stability. Global responses should:  
 
Identify ways of improving the life chances of young people affected by AIDS  
 
19. It is not yet possible to predict what long-term effect the epidemic will have 
on the generation of children in the worst affected countries who are now 
growing up surrounded by death and illness. There are concerns that, in 
some countries, the effects of HIV/AIDS are generating widespread loss of 
hope and confidence in the future. If left unaddressed, fatalism and 
pessimism among young people may increase the risks of social 
discontent and, particularly, in countries that are already prone to conflict, 
could exacerbate existing social and political tensions.  
 
Work with the public and private sectors to develop and implement strategies 
to mitigate impacts on the labour force  
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
9 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
 
20. In some of the most affected countries, HIV/AIDS is having a significant 
impact on the size and composition of the labour force. This, in turn, is 
affecting the capacity of public and private sectors to function effectively.  
At company level, impacts include reduced productivity, loss of skills and 
increased costs – both undermining performance and profitability. 
Similarly, HIV/AIDS is weakening the capacity of public services but is also 
placing new demands on them. Education, health and security sectors are 
all particularly affected.  
 
Support orphans and children made vulnerable by AIDS  
 
21. The epidemic is dramatically reducing life expectancy in the worst affected 
countries.  It is altering the shape of societies, with a disproportionate 
impact on young women and on 15-39 year olds. 14 million children have 
already lost at least one parent to the virus, and the numbers are set to 
rise to 20 million by 2010. Evidence also suggests that orphaning in highly-
affected countries may be causing early entry into the labour force and 
exacerbating problems of child labour. Like all children, orphans and those 
made vulnerable by AIDS need to be able to benefit from essential 
services such as education and health. The impact of orphaning will be 
reduced where treatments are able to prolong the lives of parents and 
carers. Emphasis will be given to supporting the development of policies to 
protect and assist orphans and vulnerable children including means of 
expanding community-based responses to broaden the safety net for such 
children. This will involve financial transfers to affected families.  
 
Work to address the broader impact of HIV/AIDS on social stability, conflict 
and security.  
 
22. High levels of HIV prevalence can have serious economic, political and 
social impact.  HIV rates are suspected to be high in conflict and post-
conflict countries. Lack of access to information and the breakdown of 
services create an environment in which HIV/AIDS is easily spread. 
Women and children may resort to sexual bartering. Conflict conditions 
can serve to normalise violence, including sexual violence, against 
women, children and men. UNAIDS estimates that the prevalence rate 
among some African military personnel is generally three to five times 
higher than that in the civilian sector and this figure rises during periods of 
demobilisation. Some military leaders see HIV/AIDS as a huge threat to 
maintaining the integrity of the armed forces. This has direct implication for 
future national security arrangements. HIV/AIDS may also contribute to 
conflict. The impact on individuals, communities and services could lead to 
an increase in social discontent and a decrease in government’s capacity 
to respond. However, there is also evidence in some countries, such as 
Uganda, suggesting that HIV/AIDS has not had this effect, serving instead 
as a catalyst for social mobilisation, political engagement and the 
enhanced legitimacy of government and leaders.  
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
10 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
Work to address the significant impact of HIV/AIDS on food security  
  
23. Illness and mortality caused by HIV/AIDS compounds existing problems of 
household and national food security, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa. 
Responses should support agricultural development in country and to help 
create an equitable international framework for agricultural trade. They 
should involve close working with FAO, WFP and other relevant 
organisations to improve the planning and management of humanitarian 
responses to food crises and to ensure that these responses support long-
term development efforts, including the additional impacts created by 
HIV/AIDS which require better planning, a faster response, and may need 
to be extended for a longer term. Responses should support efforts to 
increase the effectiveness of targeting households on the basis of 
vulnerability, rather than HIV status. Given the lack of evidence for the 
effectiveness of targeting on the basis of HIV status, international efforts 
should aim to improve understanding of the interactions between nutrition 
and HIV/AIDS. The unreliability of data on food security and vulnerability is 
one factor that impedes policy planning processes in the agricultural 
sector. Responses should support better data collection and the greater 
responsiveness of institutions to the changing patterns of vulnerability and 
food security as the result of HIV/AIDS 
 
Work to address the broader impact of HIV/AIDS on environment and natural 
resource management.  
 
24. High levels of HIV prevalence can have serious impact on food production 
and agricultural systems, due to the selling of household assets (land, 
animals etc.) to meet increased medical costs, and reductions in labour to 
manage the land.  Likewise, common-property resource systems relying 
on formal and informal management networks may break down as key 
individuals succumb 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
11 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
III. BUILDING EFFECTIVE NATIONAL RESPONSES 
 
25. HIV/AIDS is an exceptional challenge demanding an exceptional, but 
sustainable, response built in to long-term planning. Whether addressing 
emerging or advanced epidemics, there is an urgent need to raise 
HIV/AIDS up the political agenda and take programmes to scale at the 
same time focusing on broader development priorities. The ‘pre-HIV’ 
planning, management and service structures within many countries are 
not matched for this challenge and therefore need to evolve. This will 
require a pluralistic approach to the way in which aid is delivered. It will 
require strengthening health services but also addressing broader service 
and human resource constraints. HIV/AIDS programmes therefore need to 
be mainstreamed into all sectors, now and in the future, to determine how 
each should respond based on their comparative advantage. Government 
action alone will not suffice. A multi-sectoral approach is required bringing 
together government, civil society and private sector responses. Strategies 
need to be matched to the capacity of each of these actors and integrated 
into broader development priorities in a particular country’s relevant 
planning framework, budget or PRSP.  It will also be necessary to adapt 
responses when working in difficult environments. The global response 
should: 
 
Adopt a range of approaches to delivering HIV/AIDS aid  
 
26. A pluralistic approach to aid instruments for HIV/AIDS is required. The 
particular mix will evolve over time depending on the country context – the 
stage and nature of the epidemic, the national HIV/AIDS response, 
capacity of different actors and the broader, long-term development 
agenda. While the national HIV/AIDS strategy needs to be part of the 
government’s budget planning process or Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Papers (PRSPs), a rapid response might necessitate support to be 
earmarked to HIV/AIDS or to be channelled outside of government 
financial systems, even in countries where general budget support is 
accepted to be the most effective way of providing aid in general. 
However, by ensuring the short-term exceptional response is balanced 
with longer-term mainstreaming and integration in national processes, 
sustainability of the response should be safeguarded. 
 
Work with country governments to strengthen and improve access to 
health services  
 
27. HIV/AIDS can have a severe impact on already weak health systems. It 
places increasing demands on all levels of health care delivery and 
support infrastructure, including diagnosis, treatment and care of diseases 
and health needs other than HIV/AIDS. In highly affected countries, health 
workers are faced with a triple burden: dealing with HIV/AIDS in their 
working lives, potentially being infected themselves, and caring for those 
around them outside work. It is vital that responses to HIV/AIDS do not 
undermine work to provide health services more generally, including in 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
12 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
relation to major diseases like malaria and TB, and on health care 
interventions such as those promoting maternal and child health. New 
responses need to build on and strengthen sustainable systems rather 
than distort resources and policy priorities.  .   
 
28. In high-prevalence countries in the short-term, HIV/AIDS is likely to require 
an enlargement of the health sector relative to other sectors. While we 
must not ignore the constraints on the speed at which the sector can 
expand, well-targeted investments in health services have the potential to 
achieve wider gains in the MDGs for health. There will be a sensible limit 
in the rate at which programmes can expand because of absorptive 
constraints in health services.  Using many providers and adopting 
strategies to address bottlenecks, for example in human resources, will be 
important in allowing HIV/AIDS programmes to reach adequate scale. 
Non-state actors including community groups, faith based groups and the 
private sector will be important in responding to the challenge of HIV/AIDS. 
However, it is important to develop health delivery services in such a way 
as to minimise transaction costs of attending clinics and other services. 
Multiple entry points can act as a disincentive to access if poor and 
vulnerable groups have to travel to different locations to receive treatment 
and care for different health care needs. 
 
29. Treatment of HIV/AIDS and opportunistic infections presents particular 
challenges to national drug procurement, management and supply 
systems, including in relation to affordability of vital medicines, 
sustainability of financing and rational selection and use of drugs. 
Responses should support efforts to build country capacity around access 
to medicines. These approaches will be consistent with the broader UK 
Government Access to Medicines strategy, which is currently being 
produced. This strategy will outline broad policy and plans for increasing 
access to medicines for poor communities in poor countries. This will 
involve improving the affordability of medicines, increasing research and 
development into diseases that disproportionately affect poor countries, 
and understanding how developing countries can best work with the 
international community to improve access to medicines. 
 
30. A key area related to affordability will be the effective use of the TRIPS 
th
and Public Health agreement of August 30 2003. National governments 
can play an important role in partnership with patent based companies in 
accessing differentially priced products, as well as creating the right 
intellectual property regime to allow voluntary licensing and compulsory 
licensing agreements as appropriate. Effective use of the TRIPS and 
th
Public Health agreement of August 30 2003 will be key. High-quality, 
effective and affordable generic competition has an important role to play 
in further reducing the prices of essential medicines for the treatment and 
care of people with HIV/AIDS, as well as for other diseases particularly 
affecting poor countries. Quality and efficacy issues are of prime 
importance in relation to all drugs, including generics. Responses should 
support efforts to strengthen capacity in medicine procurement, 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
13 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
registration, regulation and monitoring of medicines, and the management 
of intellectual property. 
 
Work with country governments to strengthen access and delivery of 
services  
  
31. Protecting and promoting the livelihoods of people with HIV/AIDS requires 
more than just effective supply of health services. It requires effective 
delivery and improved access to a range of services including education, 
agriculture, water, energy and security.  Making these services work 
involves not only changing service delivery arrangements but also 
reforming public institutions. It requires making governments accountable 
to their citizens. This implies a focus on changing institutions and systems 
across government and building demand for services in a sustainable 
manner. But it also implies putting poor people at the centre of service 
provision: by improved approaches by which they can monitor and 
discipline service providers, amplify their voice in policy making, and by 
strengthening the incentives for providers of HIV/AIDS services to serve 
the poor. Responses should support efforts to these ends – to use 
available resources more effectively by strengthening the public sector and 
reinforcing accountability.  
 
Address attrition in human resources for service delivery 
 
32. There is a human resources crisis in many Southern African countries. In 
the short-term, where HIV risks tipping systems into crisis, responses 
should support more radical strategies - including better problem diagnosis 
(for example, understanding better the link between HIV, underlying 
systems failure and migration), special schemes to recruit staff, focused 
technical assistance and the training of intermediate cadres. But short-
term responses are inevitably insufficient and therefore need to be 
balanced with a long-term view of human resources and capacity 
development, addressing problems such as low-pay, migration, 
deployment and retention as part of wider service delivery systems.  
 
Work with civil society and private sector to support their role within 
multi-sectoral strategies 
 
33. Responses should support the scaling up and greater coordination of civil 
society initiatives to address HIV/AIDS prevention, treatment, care and 
impact mitigation. Responses should also support the engagement of 
faith-based organisations that are effectively addressing stigma and 
discrimination. Civil society also has an important role in promoting 
political voice and participation. Responses should support the 
engagement of civil society, including organisations representing people 
living with HIV/AIDS, marginalized populations and women’s groups, in 
policy, planning and implementation processes. The media also has an 
important role in tackling stigma and discrimination.  
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
14 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
34. Responses should support efforts to further increase awareness among 
businesses of the impacts of HIV/AIDS as well as dissemination of 
emerging best practice in workplace policies and broader company 
response strategies. In particular, responses should support work to 
facilitate lesson learning between large companies and their suppliers as 
well as efforts to strengthen the capacity of the informal sector – in which 
many of the poor are employed – to respond to the epidemic. Furthermore, 
action by the private sector to provide leadership and advocacy for 
Government action on HIV/AIDS should be supported, as should public-
private partnerships with Government and civil society to deliver effective 
services.   
 
35. Response should continue to work with pharmaceutical companies to help 
make vital medicines available in developing countries. Research and 
development into new medicines and preventive technologies and 
strategies to ensure equitable access to new technologies and medicines 
by the poor should be encouraged. 
 
Adapting to the challenge of working in difficult environments 
 
36. The range of potential partners varies widely country to country.  In 
countries identified as 'good' policy environments there is often a large 
range of financing and technical support on offer.  Defining the UK 
comparative advantage in 'donor crowded' settings is essential, and 
reinforcing the message of the Three Ones, becomes the UK's most 
important contribution, ensuring harmonisation of funding, policy and 
planning, led by government.   
 
37. In weak and failing states, which contribute significantly to fuelling the 
epidemic, there has to be much better international understanding of what 
works in poor policy environments.  In some of these settings the UN may 
be the credible partner, in others civil society may be preferred.   The UK 
response at global level in providing support to these key agencies to 
enable them to tackle HIV is difficult environments is essential (e.g. 
UNHCR, WHO through its Health Action in Crises, UNICEF, UNDP and 
others) 
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
15 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
IV. IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF 
THE INTERNATIONAL RESPONSE 
 
38. An efficient and effective national response depends on both ensuring 
sufficient resources to tackle the crisis and ensuring that these resources 
are used to maximum benefit. UNAIDS estimates that there is a large and 
growing resource gap between global finances available for HIV/AIDS 
programmes and estimates of what could usefully be absorbed in low and 
middle income countries – US$10.5bn in 2005 rising to US$15bn in 2007. 
However, resource flows have increased and since 2001 there has been a 
substantial increase in the international response to HIV/AIDS, with many 
new actors emerging, as well as existing institutions (e.g. the World Bank) 
enhancing their response. In an increasingly crowded arena, a scaled up 
‘exceptional’ response runs the risk of weakening service delivery and 
undermining sustainable interventions. Several countries appear to be 
facing difficulties in absorbing new finances and will have to manage any 
potential macro-economic impact of HIV/AIDS aid. Support for HIV-
affected countries must be harmonised at both international and national 
levels - to ensure resources are used as efficiently and effectively as 
possible.  The global response should: 
 
Take a lead in promoting better harmonisation 
 
39. Better harmonisation is required between donors and recipient countries. 
Working with UNAIDS, responses should mobilise support for 
implementing the “Three Ones” principles: one agreed HIV/AIDS Action 
Framework that drives alignment of all partners; one national AIDS 
authority, with a broad-based multi-sectoral mandate; and one agreed 
country-level monitoring and evaluation system.  
 
Ensure that macroeconomic policies support effective responses  
 
40. Funding flows must be managed to avoid instability but medium term 
expenditure ceilings should not be unjustifiably tight.  Countries sometimes 
feel pressure to be too tight in the face of new aid.  New flows of aid 
should be made in a transparent, predictable and smoothly disbursing 
manner as possible. Erratic and unpredictable flows would cause damage 
to macroeconomic stability and also to the HIV/AIDS programmes they are 
supposed to support.  Responses should encourage medium and long-
term sustainability in the level of flows from all major donors and support 
the work of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to handle 
raising and targeting aid for HIV/AIDS in macroeconomic policy dialogue. 
 
Increase the capacity of countries to absorb new funding  
 
41. Responses should support efforts to better understand the constraints on 
country’s absorptive capacity. They should also  increase the capacity of 
countries to absorb new HIV/AIDS funding and for this to be used 
effectively. This will involve integrating the national HIV/AIDS strategy and 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
16 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
ensuring transparency with the central budget and PRSP planning 
process. It will also include addressing the potential of civil society and the 
private sector to work alongside national governments. 
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
17 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
V. INVESTING IN LONG-TERM SOLUTIONS 
 
42. It is crucial that immediate action to take evidence-based strategies to 
scale is balanced with a longer-term view of how to tackle the epidemic.  .  
In the first instance, substantial effort, commitment and resources is 
required to sustain the prevention, treatment and care, and impact 
mitigation programmes being taken to scale now. The stock of 
international best practices should also be updated and disseminated as 
knowledge increases. More research is required aimed at developing 
better HIV treatments and diagnostics for poor people, children and 
women. Moreover, key elements of an effective response remain 
unknown, and the overall goal of controlling HIV globally will require the 
development of new technologies for prevention and treatment – including 
vaccines and microbicides.  These approaches will be consistent with 
broader access to medicines strategies currently being developed. The 
global response should: 
 
Ensure stability and sustainability of commitment and resources  
 
43. International experience shows that prevention efforts need to be 
continuous. Risk behaviour can rapidly increase if efforts are not 
maintained and adapted to changing circumstances – even where there 
are high background levels of knowledge about preventive behaviour.  
Similarly, anti-retroviral treatment – including monitoring and adaptation of 
treatment regimes – once started, needs to be sustained for life.  Even as 
new strategies and technologies become available the international 
community must work to ensure that these activities are maintained in 
tandem. 
 
Increase our understanding of effective best practices 
 
44. Further research is needed aimed at increasing our understanding of 
effective best practices. This must be placed in the context of different 
environments and effectively targeted to the poor, women and 
marginalised communities.  This will require ongoing research into the 
cultural, economic and policy determinants of vulnerabilities and risk for 
HIV infection and its consequences, and successful responses. 
 
Develop better HIV treatments and diagnostics for poor people, children 
and women  
 
45. Current Antiretroviral regimens are not a cure. Some communities will be 
unable to access expanding treatment efforts - or will become unable to 
continue to benefit due to drug resistance or side effects.  Responses 
should support efforts to develop new treatment strategies that meet the 
needs of the poor, as well as treatments for children with HIV/AIDS, whose 
treatment needs have not been adequately addressed. 
 
Accelerate progress towards developing new technologies   
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT 
18 CONSULTATION DOCUMENT 
NOT UK GOVERNMENT POLICY 
 
 
 
46. Responses should support efforts to identify new technologies to prevent 
HIV. This will also develop understanding of the partnerships and 
incentives required for greater private sector involvement and greater 
coordination of researchers to accelerate and broaden the research 
pipeline for different technologies.  A better understanding is needed of 
how new technologies can be made accessible to people in poor countries 
by strengthening mechanisms and processes for regulatory approval, 
distribution networks, manufacturing capacity and development of the 
capacity of communities and public services to utilise new methods.   
 
 
 
APRIL 2004 
DEPARTMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

Army Home Page / Home Page / Regimental History / Watchman 


















			
	WATCHMAN
	




 



	
The mascot tradition in the Regiments of Staffordshire stretches back to the 19th Century. In 1882 The South Staffordshire Regiment was ordered to march with Lord Wolseley to the relief of General Gordon who was besieged in Khartoum. They entrained at Cairo with their Staffordshire Bull Terrier "Boxer". Unfortunately Boxer leapt from the moving train and was seen lying unconscious or dead at the side of the track.

A few days later when the Regiment encamped at Assiut awaiting orders for the final phase of their march, a very thin and bedraggled dog staggered into their camp and collapsed. Boxer had walked for over 200 miles along the scorching desert railway track to rejoin his regiment, a true soldier.

From then on the tradition of having a Bull Terrier as a mascot continued with the battalions until after the Second World War. In 1949 the 6th Battalion the North Staffordshire Regiment were presented with a Bull Terrier for being the highest recruited infantry battalion in the Territorial Army.

On the 25th May 1949 the 6th North Staffords sent a Company size group (some 120 men) along with its Corps of Drums and Fifes to the Royal Tournament, which was held that year in Olympia. The mascot Watchman I was pure white in colour and showed little interest in the occasion until the Band and Drums struck up. At which point he raised his head and marched proudly to the thunderous applause of an appreciative audience who had immediately taken him to their hearts. Over the next decade Watchman I attended every parade in which the battalion took part and was presented to Her Majesty The Queen on her visit to Burton-on-Trent on 28th March 1957. He passed away in 1959 and was laid to rest in the lawns opposite the Town Hall in King Edward Square Burton-on-Trent.

Such was the tradition, interest and good feeling of the people of Burton towards this most popular mascot that in September 1960 Watchman II was presented to the Regiment by the town at a civic parade. Like his predecessor he was to march at the head of the Battalion throughout the next six years of his life and was presented to Her Majesty The Queen on the occasion of the Presentation of New Colours to the 6th North Staffords and 5th South Staffords, and a Guidon to the Staffordshire Yeomanry at Molineaux in the early 1960’s. His last parade was the Honorary Colonels Parade held at St Martins Camp in 1966. The following year the County TA Regiments were reformed and Watchman II went into retirement until his death in 1974 at the age of fourteen.

He was laid to rest alongside his predecessor at Burton where both are remembered on a commemorative plaque.

The 3rd Battalion The Staffordshire Regiment was raised in 1988 and it was felt that the time honoured tradition of having a mascot should continue. Consequently a search was made to find a dog with the suitable pedigree and bearing to do justice to the Regiment and County. As an indication of the depth of feeling within the County for the mascot, the people of Burton presented the Regiment with Watchman III in 1988. He served until his death in 1998 and was interred alongside his two predecessors.

Watchman IV was presented to the Regiment as a puppy in August 1998 by the Friends of the Regiment and continues to parade with both the 1st Battalion and the newly formed West Midlands Regiment.

	Supply Department 



The Supply Department in a modern warship sits at the heart of the Ship's activity. Whatever the ship may be up to, there will be members of the Supply Department at critical points in the action. This will be so whether firing a missile or landing a disaster relief party, or more routinely, entertaining dignitaries or despatching the Ship's mail. 



When a ship deploys abroad on an operational task, she sets out to execute a particular mission. It is the task of the Supply Department to ensure that she can remain "on task" for as long as is required to see this mission through to conclusion. If we have a product, it is best described as "sustainability" - ultimately that which ensures that when the Captain says "fire" he hears a "bang" and not a "phut"! 



To achieve the range of support we are tasked to deliver, a team of multi-skilled personnel is called for to keep the business of the Ship running as smoothly as possible. It is worthy of note that this team is smaller than those in other classes of similar sized ships in the RN, whilst the overall capabilities of the Type 23 Frigate are much greater. 



Our "heavy logisticians" form the Naval Stores Sub Department. Known traditionally as "Jack Dusties", they look after the Ship's spare parts to support critical equipment. If a spare is to be held, they look after it, ready to lay their hands on it when required; if one is not, they will know how to obtain one, no matter where the Ship may be, within an acceptable timescale. At the last count, the team held some 41 589 items in their care, to the approximate value of £15M. In peacetime the Stores Accountants serve their customers from the "tranquillity" of the Stores Office. In war, (and much against their better judgement!) they fling the doors to the storerooms open to allow immediate access, so crucial to the sustainability of the operational effort. 



The work of the Galley Staff may seem obvious. However the skill and planning required to cater for 170 hungry and discerning palates, for £1.90 per person per day, possibly for several months and without recourse to Sainsbury's, would focus the mind of any civilian chef! Again, their output varies directly with the Ship's tasking. They may one day be required to cater for an overseas lunch party for visiting dignitaries, hosted by the Captain, and quash the stereotypes of British Catering at a stroke! The next, they may be required to present a sustaining "potmess" to the Ship's Company, produced from scratch in less than forty minutes, to be consumed within the same timescale whilst the Ship remains at Action Stations. 



The staff of the Ship's Office are responsible for most of the other things closest to a sailor's heart beyond food, such as pay, leave, travel and tobacco coupons! Add to this custody of large quantities of cash, in a variety of currencies, and the management of the Ship's correspondence, internal and external, and you have a self filling in tray, a permanent queue of customers, and a lack of time off! 



The remit of the Wardroom Management Staff far exceeds their traditional role. In addition to day to day management of the Wardroom, they are at the front end of any function in support of Defence Diplomacy, where their style and skill support our nation's enduring reputation abroad. They have also recently assumed accounting responsibility for the Ship's four internal funds that support the Ship's Mess communities. 



Our smallest, but nonetheless crucial Sub Department, is the NAAFI. The key function of its singleton manager has a unique impact on the Ship's sustainability in as much as it directly effects the morale of the Ship's Company. The importance of a Mars Bar as you secure from Action Stations is hard to put into words! 



It is clear then that the unique requirements of Type 23 Supply Department reflect the range of roles of the Ship itself and span, in each discipline of our business, from routine delivery of quality services in peacetime, to fast reacting provision of life-sustaining functions in war.

title: Meat, dairy foods and risk of breast cancer
text:
Meat, dairy foods and risk of breast cancer
    
      Skip navigation
    



	 
	 
	


    

 
	 
  		

    


    
    



    
      


      Meat, dairy foods and risk of breast cancer


      ?


      Many studies have investigated the association between meat and dairy food
      consumption and breast cancer risk, drawing different conclusions. This paper
      examines these associations by pooling results from eight large prospective
      studies.


      Bottom line


      This paper finds that meat and dairy product consumption, in mid or later life,
      is not associated with breast cancer risk (although it did not examine the effect
      of the level to which meat is cooked or cooking method).


      Reference


      SA Missmer et al. Meat and dairy food consumption and breast cancer: a pooled
      analysis of cohort studies. International Journal of Epidemiology 2002 31:
      78-85.


      Study selection


      Studies were from the Pooling Project of Prospective Studies of Diet and Cancer.
      To be included, studies had to have at least 200 cases of breast cancer; assessed
      diet using a comprehensive food frequency questionnaire; and validated the
      questionnaire. Eight studies were identified with a total of 351,041 women, 7,379
      of whom were diagnosed with breast cancer over five to ten years of follow-up. Ages
      ranged from 31 to 90 years.


      The following were examined:


      Meat


      	main groups of red meat, white meat, and total meat products;
	within red meat, sub-groups of organ products, processed meats, bacon
        products, sausage products and two specific foods, ground beef and hot dogs;
	within white meat, sub-groups of poultry, seafood, fish, shellfish and
        eggs.



      Dairy


      	main groups of total dairy fluids and total dairy solids;
	within total dairy fluids, sub-groups of milk products, low fat dairy fluids,
        low fat non-fermented dairy fluids, high fat dairy fluids, high fat non-fermented
        dairy fluids, fermented dairy fluids, yoghurt products and four specific foods,
        skim and low fat milk, whole milk, whole cream and ice cream;
	within total dairy solids, sub-groups of high fat dairy solids, fermented
        dairy solids, cheese products and two specific foods, butter and cottage
        cheese.



      Individual foods were only examined when intake had been assessed in at least
      five studies. The groups were analysed according to increments of 100g a day (or in
      a few cases 10g a day when more appropriate) and as quartiles (for main and
      sub-groups).


      Results


      Median total meat intake ranged from 25 g/day to 215 g/day between studies (half
      chicken breast = 86 g); median egg intake from 5 to 22 g/day (1 egg = 50 g); dairy
      fluids from 203 to 262 g/day (8 oz milk = 244 g); and dairy solids from 23 to 34
      g/day (1 oz cheese = 28 g).


      The results were adjusted for several variables (a total of 14) including age at
      menarche, menopausal status at follow-up, age at first birth, family history of
      breast cancer, smoking status, body mass index and alcohol intake.


      No associations were found between total meat, red meat, white meat, total dairy
      fluids, total dairy solids and risk of breast cancer.


      For 100 g/day intake increments, the relative risks and 95% confidence intervals
      were as follows: total meat 1.02 (0.97 to 1.08); red meat 0.98 (0.93 to 1.04);
      white meat 1.02 (0.94 to 1.11); total dairy fluids 0.99 (0.97 to 1.00); total dairy
      solids 1.03 (0.95 to 1.11).


      Compared with the lowest quartiles of intake, the relative risks and 95%
      confidence intervals for the highest quartiles were as follows: total meat 1.08
      (0.98 to 1.19); red meat 0.94 (0.87 to 1.02); white meat 1.02 (0.91 to 1.13); total
      dairy fluids 0.93 (0.84 to 1.03); total dairy solids 1.01 (0.93 to 1.09).


      No associations were found between the meat or dairy sub-groups or specific meat
      or dairy foods and risk of breast cancer, with the exception of egg consumption
      (for 100 g/day increment, relative risk 1.22, 95% confidence interval 1.03 to
      1.45).


      Comment


      Although an association was observed between egg consumption and breast cancer
      risk, this association became inconsistent in further analyses, and it is possible,
      even probable, that the association observed is due to chance. The probability of
      finding significant results due to chance increases with the number of statistical
      tests performed; and this analysis examined a large number of food groups and
      specific foods.


      Although no association was observed between meat consumption and breast cancer
      risk, this paper was unable to assess the effect of cooking method or the level to
      which meat is cooked (as the majority of studies did not collect this information).
      For instance, meat cooked at high temperatures (e.g. frying and barbecuing) and
      welldone meat (especially to the point of charring) contain heterocyclic amines,
      known to be carcinogenic. However, the overall lack of association observed in this
      paper suggests that generally, there are no adverse effects of meat in relation to
      risk of breast cancer.

MAY / JUNE 2004 DESPATCHES

The move to Catterick from Northern Ireland went well with the Battalion taking a well earned 3 week leave period and returning in early May. The focus was still on the 'Marching Season' with Drumcree in particular, in Northern Ireland, with the Battalion on standby ready to deploy in a Public Order role if required. However many Battalion and sporting events and activities have taken place in this  period...........




On Saturday the 30th June members of the 1st Battalions C (Charlie) Company paraded through the streets of Sherbourne, Dorset with bayonets fixed and with the Battalions Colours flying. They were joined by contingents of the Territorial Army Rifle Volunteers and the Army Cadet Force in exercising their freedom of the town.





	



 


	



 


The parade culminated with a Church service at Sherbourne Abbey followed by the Annual Regimental Reunuion.


		



 

The Anti Tank (Milan) Platoon pictured below have been awarded the coveted title of the Duke of Kent’s Platoon having emerged as victors in the Inter Platoon competitions. The Platoon now proudly wears the Duke of Kent’s Platoon badge and wears a distinctive lanyard when in No 2's service dress.








	




	





Picture above shows a member of the Anti Tank Platoon practicing weapon drills prior to the forthcoming shooting camp.


		



All members of the 1st Battalion have been completing their annual military tests, ranging from the Law of Armed Conflict, 1st Aid training, through to zeroing their new SA80 A2 Individual weapons in preparation for the Annual Personnel Weapons Test

 


	



Pictured above is Lcpl Si Jenkins who is carrying out individual Chemical Decontamination drill.


 

Exercise Elsinore Finn

Prior to departing Niorthern Ireland, 8 Members of the 1st Battalion took part in Exercise Elsinore Finn , a 2 week Sky Diving Expedition to Lake Elsinore in California USA. The weather conditions where perfect with clear blue skies every day, perfect for Sky Diving. UK based expeditions are prone to poor weather conditions, thus preventing jumps taking place. All members of the 8 squad team completed at least 15 freefall jumps, including the novices who up till the exercise had never jumped from a plane before.


		




	



The Sky Diving 8 team members.

 

Exercise Northern Midi

9 members of the 1st Battalion have just spent 3 weeks in Southern France canoeing 240km of the Canal du Midi. The expedition included 12 consecutive days of paddling, with 20kms covered each day in approximately 6 hours.  The team spent each night in camp sites en route. After a hard 240km the team had earned their 2 days of rest and relaxation in Troulouse prior to the long journey (by minibus!) back to Catterick.


		






Exercise True Grit


	



Private Craig Hayes represented the 1st Battalion at the Army Endurance Motocross competition, Exercise True Grit. This is an annual event open to both miltary and civvilian riders. He finished 48th out of 300 entrants, being the 7th Army rider in his class across the finish line. 


The next edition of the Despatches will contain coverage of the Battalions commemoration of the Salamanca via a day of disruption. The edition will also contain images from the Battlefield tour of Normandy as part of the 60th Anniversary of D Day. All of the D ( Delta) Company platoons will have also taken part in their own live fire exercises, continuing the preperation and build for future operations in any part of the world.

Whilst every effort has been taken to ensure the accuracy of this information, personnel must confirm details through the chain of command or with their Administrative Office before taking any action or making any commitment.

The Royal Air Force - History Section

	
		 
	


	
	 
       

      Royal Air Force History

      
        

      
            
      


      History of No. 607 Squadron.

       

       Motto:No Motto

          Badge:A winged lion salient, the hind legs also winged.
          The badge was an official authorisation of an unofficial badge in use
          by the squadron. 

      

      No 607 Squadron was formed on 17 March 1930 at Usworth as a day bomber
        unit of the Auxiliary Air Force. The former landing ground at Hylton
        used during World War One was in course of preparation as the squadron's
        base, but it was not until September 1932 that any personnel could move
        to the site. Next month a Gipsy Moth arrived to allow flying training
        to commence, and in December the first Wapitis were received. These were
        replaced by Demons. No 607 being redesignated a fighter squadron on 23
        September 1936. In December 1938 conversion to Gladiators began and these
        were taken to France in November 1939 to join the Air Component of the
        BEF. In March 1940 Hurricanes began to arrive and within a few days of
        the German invasion in May had completely replaced Gladiators. With its
        airfields overrun, the squadron moved back to the UK to re-equip and
        in September moved south to defend southern England during the Battle
        of Britain. In October No.607 moved to Scotland returning south in August
        1941 for fighter-bomber sweeps, the first taking place on 18 September.
        In March 1942, the squadron left India and joined No.166 Wing at Alipore
        on 25 May. At first engaged in escort and defensive duties, the squadron
        converted to Spitfires in September 1943 and added ground attack missions
        to its role. It flew Spitfires until the end of the Burma campaign, disbanding
        on 19 August 1945. 

      On 10 May 1946, No.607 reformed at Ouston as a day fighter squadron
        of the Auxiliary Air Force. After flying Spitfires for five years, it
        converted to Vampires in October 1950 and was disbanded on 10 March 1957. 

      

      A Rolls Royce kestrel V powered Hawker Demon of 607
          Squadron. The units striking identification colours were mauve and
          stone!

      

      A Hawker Hurricane Mk 1 in 607 Squadron markings

EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRIES TRANSPARENCY INITIATIVE (EITI) 
Statement from ConocoPhillips
Henry I. McGee III, President, Europe and Africa, ConocoPhillips
June 17, 2003
Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative Meeting
Lancaster House, London
Madam Chairwoman, distinguished government officials, special guests, ladies and 
gentlemen, my name is Henry McGee, President of Europe and Africa for ConocoPhillips. I 
am pleased to be here today with this most august assembly to discuss this important issue.
ConocoPhillips is an international, integrated energy company, founded in 2002, following the 
merger of Conoco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum Company. Combined, the new company has 
more than 200 years of experience in the energy industry. The foundation of the new 
company is our legacy system of shared values, on which we are committed to setting the 
highest standard of excellence in everything we do. In particular, our commitment to integrity 
and responsibility seem especially applicable to today’s meeting agenda. Simply put, we are 
committed to be ethical and trustworthy in our relationships with all stakeholders, we are 
accountable for our actions, and we make every effort to be a good neighbor and citizen in 
every community in which we operate.
ConocoPhillips supports the principles of transparency overall, and in the particular, the efforts 
to increase transparency in payment and expenditure reporting from oil and gas production. 
We believe that improved transparency in government revenues should be matched by full 
transparency in government expenditures. We are willing to play a part in a responsible, 
voluntary initiative, in cooperation with host governments as well as all private and state oil 
companies, and with the support of the international financial institutions. The Statement of 
Principles and Agreed Actions may provide a useful starting point for improving transparency 
over payments and revenues in the oil and gas industries.
We appreciate the work that has gone into this effort over the past year toward a balanced 
and workable framework to promote transparency of payments and revenues. We encourage 
close study of other efforts by the OECD, the UN, IMF and others that has already been 
accomplished in this area, and incorporate lessons learned into the EITI process. We noted 
with particular interest the G-8 Declaration on Fighting Corruption and Improving 
Transparency.
We hope that at the conclusion of this meeting a path forward to further clarification of the 
process will be defined and that all stakeholders – all extractive industry companies, 
governments, international organizations and non-government organizations – will commit to 
work together for the benefit of the citizens in all our countries.

Foreign & Commonwealth Office What is CHOGM?















Back to Full Graphics


























































What is a Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM)?

















Commonwealth consultation is a continuous process, taking place at many levels.


There are regular Commonwealth finance, health, law, education, environment, women's affairs and youth Ministerial meetings.  CHOGMs are the pinnacle events in any Commonwealth calendar and take place every two years in a different country. CHOGMs bring together almost one third of the world's leaders, mostly Prime Ministers and Presidents. A CHOGM is arguably the only international forum where such a diverse group of countries come together to adopt common positions through consensus.


CHOGM 2003

The theme of the present CHOGM, taking place from 5 to 8 December 2003 in Abuja, Nigeria, is 'Development and Democracy: Partnerships for Peace and Prosperity'.  For more information see the CHOGM 2003 website and the Commonwealth Secretariat website:






























	









	








CHOGM 2003






































	









	








Commonwealth Secretariat














The Meeting of the Committee of the Whole (senior officials) usually takes place six weeks preceding CHOGM in London. Meetings in the margins of a CHOGM include the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG) and the Ministerial Group on Small States. Parallel events involving non-government organisations, business and youth also take place.
