190: Equity shares in social housing: literature review 
 
Introduction  
An international literature review was conducted to further understand the processes associated 
with asset accumulation and the potential impacts of applying such an approach through the 
distribution of equity shares to social housing tenants in the UK.  
Key findings  
• Assets are essential for those on low incomes to escape poverty. Asset ownership allows 
people the opportunity to participate as citizens and to contribute economically and socially 
in their communities and to society in general.  
• Equity shares in social housing could go some way to help address asset and wealth 
inequality but there is a lack of understanding and certainty of the direct impact that asset 
accumulation has on the motivations and behaviour of individuals.  
• Literature from the US finds that home ownership may generate positive impacts such as 
neighbourhood stability and community involvement. However, the evidence is far from 
conclusive and the US experience may not be directly transferable to the UK. The literature 
also suggests that length of residence is more important than tenure per se in the 
development of social capital.  
• The extension of home ownership to low income groups is not in itself sufficient to 
counteract neighbourhood decline and deprivation. The extension of home ownership must 
be pursued in tandem with wider regeneration initiatives.  
• Literature on employee share ownership schemes finds that they are a marginal factor in 
influencing employees attitude and behaviour. However, the literature does indicate the key 
elements needed for the successful delivery of an equity share scheme, such as partnership 
and transparency.  
• Individual Development Accounts matched savings accounts developed in the US to help 
lowincome families save and accumulate assets could be used as a model to deliver an 
equity share scheme in the UK.  
Background to the research  
Asset building allows individuals the opportunity to make life-enhancing investments, including 
owning a home, undertaking home improvements, starting a business, moving into self 
employment, or simply providing support for them or their children to access education and 
training. Equity shares in social housing can combine individual well-being with broader issues 
including wealth and asset inequality, promote equality and choice in housing and social justice, 
tackle financial exclusion and support community-based regeneration. Equity shares therefore:  
• give social housing tenants an increased stake in their home and society;  
• improve the wealth position of social tenants;  
  
• encourage social housing tenants to take greater interest in their homes and communities;  
• help social housing tenants to move into home ownership.  
Tenure and Home Ownership in the UK 
Home ownership is an important form of asset accumulation, which provides future returns in 
wealth and income, not only for current owners but as an asset, which can be transferred between 
generations through inheritance. Home ownership does not guarantee a positive return on 
investment and does entail an element of risk-taking. However, as the dominant housing tenure in 
the UK, owner-occupation provides financial and wealth-creating benefits that are not available to 
those who pay rent, either in the social or private rented sectors. Put simply, those in the social 
housing sector, who pay rent and undertake home improvements, do not necessarily benefit from 
this outlay, by securing any future financial return or equity release, as tends to be the norm in the 
owner-occupier sector.  
Owner-occupation has grown in the UK while social renting (particularly renting from local 
authorities) has decreased. The UK has a higher than average level of owner-occupation in 
international terms being the sixth highest in the European Union. The social rented sector in the 
UK is different in composition and function from that in other comparable countries: it serves more 
as a social safety net for low income and vulnerable groups. These groups tend not to benefit from 
wealth creation and asset building opportunities afforded to other middle and higher income 
groups.  
The composition of UK social housing has been influenced by government policy and the impact of 
Right-to-Buy (RTB) especially during the 1980s when some 1.5 million homes were sold through 
RTB. The effect has been an increasing polarisation of housing tenures with local authority rented 
accommodation being residualised and the profile of social renting tenants hollowed out and 
considered as the tenure of last resort.  
Equity shares in social housing might have the desired effect of changing peoples perceptions, 
making social renting a more attractive option. This might be problematic as data suggests that 
social housing tenants are more likely to be economically inactive and to be on low-incomes than 
those in other tenures. The poorest wards in England also contain a significantly higher proportion 
of social renters than other tenures. The social rented sector contains higher than average 
proportions of single parents, younger households and relatively few in the 45-64 year old age 
cohort. Black- Caribbean and Bangladeshi households are more likely to be social renters than 
other ethnic groups.  
Assets and Financial Exclusion 
Evidence suggests that a significant degree of asset inequality exists in UK society and this 
overlaps with issues surrounding financial exclusion, poverty and deprivation more generally. 
Research has shown that approximately 1.5 million households in Britain (7% of all households) do 
not hold a current account, nor do they have any savings, credit or insurance. A further 4.4 million 
(20%) are considered to be on the margins of financial services. Those who are seen to be 
unbanked tend to be concentrated in areas of high deprivation. Lack of savings and assets and a 
tendency to experience financial exclusion are associated with a number of social, economic and 
demographic characteristics that are common among social renting tenants. 
Despite the lack of engagement with mainstream financial services, many low-income households 
do manage to save, often saving small amounts, through a variety of informal means. However, the 
  
lack of formal pathways to asset accumulation and the problems associated with financial 
exclusion, does expose vulnerable and low-income households to additional risks and expense. 
Research methods  
To address these issues a comprehensive review of a range of different data and information 
sources, including academic publications, research reports and government publications, was 
undertaken. A number of intellectual disciplines were covered in the review: economics, 
management and business studies, regeneration and housing, psychology and behavioural studies. 
Early on it became obvious that there was an overall lack of research and information on asset-
building in general and more specifically, on the use of equity shares as a policy option. To address 
this problem, the research team accessed and reviewed literature and data from the USA, where the 
majority of research on asset accumulation has been undertaken and work has been done to assess 
the economic and social impacts of home ownership.  
Research findings 
Theoretical Perspectives on Asset Accumulation  
Assets are a stock of resources accumulated and held in different forms, such as bank accounts 
(savings accounts), homes, stocks and shares and pensions. Wealth can be seen as the net worth of 
the assets held by an individual or household.  
Advocates of asset-based welfare policy base the grounds for intervention on two principal 
observations. First, economically, asset accumulation is essential to address poverty. For the vast 
majority of low-income households, the pathway out of poverty is not through consumption but 
through savings and asset accumulation. Second, attitudinal effects: accumulation of assets lead to 
important psychological and social effects that are not achieved to the same degree by receiving 
and spending an equivalent amount of regular income.  
The research literature identifies the following psychological and social effects of asset holding:  
• household economic stability;  
• decreased economic strain on households;  
• educational attainment;  
• decreased marital dissolution;  
• decreased risk of intergenerational poverty transmissions;  
• increased health satisfaction among adults;  
• increased property values;  
• decreased residential mobility;  
• increased levels of civic participation;  
• existing theories of savings and asset accumulation may be classified into three broad 
categories: economic theories, psychological and sociological, and behavioural theories.  
  
For the most part, mainstream economic theory has ignored the savings behaviour of low-income 
households. As savings is determined as a residual left over after consumption has been satisfied, 
the motivations for savings behaviour are assumed to be the same for both low-income households 
as it is for middle and high income households.  
In contrast to economic theories, psychological and sociological theories emphasise the notion of 
preferences and motivations and how savings behaviour is conditioned by attitudes and cultural 
norms. Importantly, these approaches consider savings as a deliberate proactive decision, rather 
than a residual form of consumption.  
Behavioural theories combine some elements of both economic and psychological approaches to 
show how individuals create their own incentives and constraints rather than just responding to 
external pressures.  
The institutional approach to savings, highlights the role of institutions formal and informal 
relationships and rules in the process of asset accumulation. Institutional theories focus on the 
extent to which individuals savings behaviour is conditioned by the institutions through which they 
save and that savings behaviour does respond to certain incentives. Four institutional variables are 
assumed to influence savings patterns and asset accumulation: access, information, incentives and 
facilitation. Very simply, for those who have access to formal and structured savings opportunities, 
appropriate financial education, attractive savings incentives, and mechanisms of facilitation will 
save a greater percentage of their income. In effect, those on low incomes will respond to 
institutional opportunities, incentives and disincentives, and given the right choices and structures, 
they will save.  
One conclusion to be drawn from the review of the theoretical literature is the lack of knowledge 
and understanding of the precise impacts and effects that assets have on the behaviour and 
motivations of individuals. More research is required to understand the incentives of asset 
accumulation, especially for lowincome households and the long term effects of asset accumulation 
and whether people would prefer to spend now any form of savings/assets/equity shares, over 
consumption later because their present circumstances and needs are so pressing?  
Asset Accounts - Incentive Schemes in Employment 
Employee share ownership schemes (ESO) provide insights into the effects of incentives on 
individual and collective perceptions, attitudes and behaviour.  
The literature review identified significant limitations with the evidence examining ESOs and 
complexities are raised when considering the many different types of ESO schemes and the various 
functions, which they can fulfil. Overall, share ownership appears to be a marginal factor 
influencing employees attitudes when compared to other issues (e.g. job security). However, 
individual employees do not feel that they are in a position to affect share prices due to factors 
beyond their control. ESO schemes have the greatest positive impact on employees attitudes when 
they see direct financial benefits, and when they feel genuinely involved in company decision 
making.  
Key lessons drawn from the research on ESO for equity shares include the following:  
• the need for a partnership between tenants and landlords in operating such a scheme;  
• the need to design behavioural conditions carefully;  
• the need for clear eligibility rules and transparent administration;  
  
• the need for careful marketing and effective communication to heighten tenants 
understanding;  
• the need to address the potential inequalities involved in conferring equity shares in high 
demand compared to low demand areas.  
Individual Development Accounts 
The majority of research on asset accounts, including Individual Development Accounts (IDAs) 
has been undertaken in the USA. IDAs are matched savings accounts, designed to help low-income 
families save and accumulate assets. The key goals for the use of IDAs include home ownership, 
microenterprise and education and training.  
There is growing international interest in IDAs. Distinct asset based initiatives are being discussed 
and implemented in the UK and the Republic of Ireland. In Canada, the Government is sponsoring 
a major IDA demonstration project, Learn$ave, to assist low-income Canadians to build their 
personal savings and access educational opportunities. Taipei, Taiwan, and the Bureau of Social 
Services has launched a privately funded, three year IDA initiative. Pilot IDA projects are 
beginning to emerge in Sweden, Mexico, Singapore and Puerto Rico.  
At the time of the research there were over 250 communities across the USA with IDA 
programmes, with another 100 in development. The American Dream Demonstration (ADD) is the 
first large-scale test of IDAs and will run for a five-year period. Key lessons identified through 
interim evaluations of IDAs programmes and the ADD include the following:  
• improves access to financial services for low-income families and marginalised groups 
ethnic minorities, women;  
• helps to raise awareness of the importance of money management, financial literacy and 
education;  
• supports high return quality of life investments, such as education and training, self-
employment and home ownership;  
• alters the behaviour and perceptions of individuals and family members towards a culture of 
saving and investing in their own futures; and  
• stimulates enterprise creation through support for micro-enterprises.  
While the final evaluation of the national IDAs demonstration project is still to be completed, there 
is limited evidence on the impacts that IDAs have on peoples perceptions and behavioural patterns. 
Evidence from one evaluation of an IDA programme indicates positive benefits from the use of 
IDAs. Further analysis is required but there is scope to investigate ways in which an IDA 
programme could be used as a model to support equity shares in social housing in the UK context.  
Assessing the Impacts of Asset Accumulation and Home Ownership 
The majority of claims regarding the effects of home ownership and the empirical evaluations of 
these, tend to come from the USA. While there are positive benefits from home ownership, there 
are important political, policy and cultural differences between America and the UK regarding 
tenure. Although a high proportion of British householders aspire to owner occupation, this tenure 
does not have the same intensity of attraction which it has acquired in the United States.  
  
In purely economic terms, home ownership generally appears to be a good investment for 
households which provides a solid return, particularly for middle and upper income groups. 
Researchers have found that home ownership significantly reduced the selfperceived economic 
stresses of blue-collar employees. Nevertheless, an important qualification to this is added by one 
of the few British studies in this area, which warns of the potential for lower returns on investment 
and even negative equity for low-income home owners.  
The social benefits attributed to home ownership include higher levels of property maintenance and 
house price values, increased neighbourhood stability, improved neighbourhood relations, less anti-
social behaviour and accretions of social capital. However, it has to be noted that the experience in 
the USA may not be directly applicable to the British experience due to important cultural and 
historical differences in housing provision.  
Evidence from a number of American studies indicates that, in the right circumstances, home 
ownership does have positive effects for individuals and communities. However, much of this is 
attributable to the greater length of tenancy associated with home ownership in America, and the 
nature of the American rented sector may not be directly comparable to social housing in the UK. 
Even where the evidence from America does suggest that home ownership has a positive impact on 
household well-being, community involvement, neighbourhood stability and social capital, the 
qualification must be added that neighbourhood conditions may reduce these impacts.  
The policy implications for an equity shares programme in the UK are not clear-cut from the 
research into the effects of owner occupation. One interesting finding is that the length of residence 
rather than tenure per se may be a decisive factor in the development of social capital.  
Commentators have argued that, even if the individual and social benefits of home ownership can 
be shown, this might not be a suitable tenure for all households, particularly where this relates to 
lower income households in depreciating housing markets or areas of economic and social decline. 
Extending home ownership will not in itself be sufficient to counteract the conditions of 
neighbourhood decline and deprivation. However, the asset accumulation dimension of equity 
shares could form a basis for the asset accumulation of the human and cultural capital required to 
assist households in such areas. To succeed, any policy to promote the extension of home 
ownership to low-income families should bear in mind that home ownership strategies need to be 
integrated with other regeneration and community regeneration initiatives.  
Conclusions  
There is growing policy interest in asset-based welfare policy, not only as a response to growing 
wealth and asset divisions within society but more generally.  
Assets are essential to those on low incomes if they are to escape poverty asset ownership allows 
people the opportunity to participate as citizens and to contribute, economically and socially in 
their communities and to society in general.  
Based on an assessment of the current literature, it can be said that asset-building policy helps to 
promote individual financial stability and well being, home ownership, lifelong learning, economic 
development and small business creation, social justice, financial inclusion and sustainable 
neighbourhood regeneration.  
Equity shares in social housing is an option for tenants to secure a financial stake in their own home 
and to acquire the same opportunities for asset accumulation, that are afforded to those in owner 
occupation.  
  
There are gaps in our knowledge and understanding concerning asset building policies and how 
equity shares in social housing could promote asset accumulation through home ownership. While 
the research evidence comes mainly from the USA, more detailed investigation of these issues from 
a UK and European perspective would be beneficial for policy development.  
Further research is required to understand the role of incentives for asset accumulation, especially 
for lowincome households.  
Longitudinal and cross-sectional data gathering and analysis is required to ascertain the direct 
impacts of IDA policy on the motivations, behaviour and attitudes towards savings and asset 
accumulation.  
Not withstanding these problems there is scope to further research the linkages between an IDA 
programmes approach supporting or delivering equity shares in social housing.  
Further information is contained in the full report Equity Shares in Social Housing: Literature 
Review, ISBN 1 85112 644 9, £12.

	15 Jul 04







In preparation for the Ship Staff Move Onboard the refit pace is now ramping up with great gusto.  With over 450 out of 726 of the Ship?s Company having joined us and three-quarters of compartments handed over from the contractors Babcock, there is definite light at the end of the tunnel.  All NBCD and fire fighting equipment has now been moved onboard and trials and training are well underway.  Everyone is looking forward to moving onboard on 23 July.   





In June, Commander McQuaker attended the Trooping the Colour Parade in London with our affiliated regiment the Grenadier Guards.  In May 27 Ship?s Company also attended the Scottish National War Memorial D-Day Anniversary Service in Edinburgh Castle. We were also very proud to be able to send a marching platoon of 34 personnel to take part in the Royal British Legion Scotland Freedom of the City Ceremony and D-Day Anniversary Service in Perth.



Despite the continued hard work, the Ship?s Company is still finding time to enjoy themselves.  BBQs, inter-departmental sports competitions and various whole ship get togethers have been abundant on the Illustrious social calendar.  A sport that won?t be see at the Athens Olympics is ?Human Table Football?.  One of our recent sports days had this as an event, which was as hilarious to play as it was to watch!    











There have also been several opportunities for adventurous training, which have included an expedition in the Scottish Highlands and a week of sailing around the Clyde Estuary which involved a practice rescue operation with a Sea King helicopter from 771 Squadron Search and Rescue based at RNAS Prestwick.

	Ministry of Defence road safety week
Devonport Naval Base is making a significant contribution to the National Road Safety Awareness Week by hosting the local Ministry of Defence support event from Monday 8 to Friday 12 November. 



Captain Larmour, Captain of the Base, said: “It is vitally important that we take every opportunity to educate and remind personnel of the actions they can take to maximise safety on the road. I am delighted that the Naval Base is providing facilities to support the campaign.”



Throughout the week advisory roadside vehicle health checks will take place across the Naval Base. For two days there will also be a drop-in eyesight check available.

 

Over the Tuesday and Wednesday everyone from across the dockyard will be encouraged to visit the pavilion of exhibits with static and interactive displays from a wide range of organisations. Among these are a driving skills test with the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA); Devon and Cornwall Constabulary offering advice on motorcycle safety, and a cycle retailer, Natural Cycles, offering advice on cycle maintenance and safe lighting.

National Heritage Memorial Fund
The Prime Minister has been pleased to re-appoint Liz Forgan OBE as Chair of the National Heritage Memorial Fund from 1 April 2004 for a further period of three years.
 
7 April 2004 
Biographical Notes
Liz Forgan is a journalist and broadcaster and currently Chair of the Scott Trust. She was formerly Director of Programmes at Channel 4 TV and later Managing Director of BBC Network Radio. She has been Chair of the Churches Conservation Trust, a Board Member of the British Film Institute, and was awarded an OBE in 1999.
Notes for Editors
The National Heritage Memorial Fund (NHMF) is a fund of last resort which provides grants for buying items which are of outstanding interest, important to the national heritage, and which are at risk of being damaged or destroyed. The NHMF is also responsible for the distribution of the heritage share of the proceeds from the National Lottery which it does via the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF). The HLF gives financial help to projects which safeguard improved access to land, buildings, objects and collections of importance to the national heritage of the UK. It can also provide support for projects which produce wider public benefits in terms of education, access and urban regeneration.

Captain A. G. Hore Ruthven 3rd HLI

Royal Navy


	
Tue  9 Nov 2004

13 JUL 04






	
	

	13 Jul 04




After what was an operationally very useful and productive time at AUTEC we called in to Nassau in the Bahamas. We were joined on passage by Commodore Fanshawe, Commodore Devonport Flotilla, who spent 4 days with us and spoke at length to most personnel on board.  A relatively small island, Nassau is a favourite with cruise liners and those who enjoy a bit of a flutter.  A number of the Ship’s Company took this opportunity to relax after our longest period at sea and some even managed to sail with more money that they had when they arrived!



Back at sea we were fortunate enough to embark Lt Jude Terry from HMS Collingwood who spent two days giving presentations to the Ship’s Company on everything from pensions to the Divisional System.  Having landed her in Jamaica we then continued with our counter-drugs operations, finding time for a few quiz nights and NBC training along the way.  En route to Grand Cayman we were joined by Captain Brown RN, Captain Surface Ships of the Devonport Flotilla.



Grand Cayman was our next port of call and we anchored just off George Town on 21 May.  Using a boat for transfers we were able to get people ashore and also to bring on probably our largest number of guests for the cocktail party that night.  Things didn’t proceed quite as smoothly as we would have hoped and as the wind changed direction just after midnight we were forced to sail at short notice.  The remainder of the visit was spent steaming up and down approximately a mile off the coast.  However, the boat routines enabled most people to get ashore and enjoy a very beautiful island.

A popular method of transferring personnel, when the ship is far offshore and unable to close land is by helicopter. BANGOR is not equipped with a flight deck and therefore helicopters are unable to land on. She can however, make provision for a helicopter to hover above the aft deck and under the control of the HSO (Helicopter Safety Officer) Lt Alan ‘DOLLY’ Parton winch down persons or stores.



 The winch wire must be earthed as a helicopter if flight generates massive amounts of static electricity. This job falls to the Buffer LOM (MW) Al Gibb here seen holding the earthing pole. Anything winched down is under the direction of OM (MW) Smiler Morton who will remove from the flying area and it escort away. The ultimate safety rests with the HSO but the three-man team work closely together to ensure a safe and trouble free transfer. Introduction

	
The Regiments of the Household Cavalry and Royal Armoured Corps today are descendants of the famous Cavalry Regiments of the Line who rode into battle on horseback and of the Royal Tank Regiment who manned the first tanks during the Great War.

Today, there are 12 regiments that make up the Household Cavalry and Royal Armoured Corps. They are equipped with the most formidable fighting vehicles in the world, from the battle-proven Challenger tank to the fast Scimitar reconnaissance vehicle.

Of these 12 regiments, six are equipped with Challenger 2 and four with the Scimitar. The Joint Nuclear Biological and Chemical Regiment with the 1st Royal Tank Regiment, provide the British Armed Forces with the ability to detect hazardous materials in any environment. 
	

	
The Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is famous for the many ceremonial duties that it carries out in London including the state opening of Parliament. All Household Cavalrymen are dual trained; on horseback and in the formation reconnaissance role.

Every Regiment in the Corps takes pride in its own history and traditions. The winning combination of the skills of a Royal Armoured Corps soldier and his advanced, battle-proven equipment result in an exciting and varied challenge that shows modern soldiering at its best.

To find out more about each of the twelve regiments go to the links at the top of the page and click on the capbadges.

title: PMOS afternoon briefing - 24 June
text:
PMOS afternoon briefing - 24 June
	
		



	
	
	

	PRESS BRIEFING: 3.45PM TUESDAY 24 JUNE 2003

IRAQ

The Prime Minister's Official Spokesman (PMOS) informed journalists of two incidents earlier today near Al Amarah in Iraq, which had resulted in British casualties. He said we very much regreted to confirm that in one incident, six British personnel had been killed. Arrangements were in hand to inform their next of kin. In the second incident, troops from 1 Para patrolling south of Al Amarah had come under fire. The patrol had taken one casualty and two vehicles had been destroyed. In responding to the incident, an RAF Chinook helicopter, carrying a Quick Reaction Force, had come under fire as it landed. Seven personnel on board the helicopter had been wounded, three of them seriously. All had been extracted by helicopter and were receiving treatment. The MoD was investigating the incidents, including whether or not they were related. The Government would provide more information when we could, but we asked the media to respect the fact that our priority was to ensure that next of kin were informed as quickly as possible. The Defence Secretary would update the House of Commons as soon as possible. The PMOS added that the Prime Minister had been due to meet the Defence Secretary, Foreign Secretary and Secretary of State for International Development later today in any event to discuss post-Saddam Iraq issues. That meeting would still go ahead and would take in the latest incidents. Asked whether they would discuss issues relating to security, the PMOS pointed out that security had always formed a central part of discussions about Iraq post-Saddam. Post-conflict reconstruction issues were as much about security as they were about water, education, oil and the like.

Questioned as to whether Al Amarah was known to be a dangerous area, the PMOS said that as he understood it, it was an area which was some distance north of Basra. There had always been a residual threat from hostile Iraqis since the end of offensive operations in Iraq. Security had been improving since the Iraqi police force had begun to be re-established and patrols had been carried out alongside UK forces. However, there had been sporadic attacks in the past which, as today showed, could not be entirely predicted or prevented.

Asked if the first incident had been the result of hostile Iraqi action, the PMOS said that investigations were continuing. Asked if he was implying there was a possibility it could have been a friendly-fire incident, the PMOS repeated that investigations were continuing into what had happened. However, he wouldn't encourage journalists down that route.

In answer to further questions, the PMOS said that the Prime Minister had been informed of the two incidents during this morning and then over lunchtime. He had heard the news with great sadness. It went without saying that he believed those who had died had died with honour, doing a very worthwhile job and serving their country with great distinction.

	

	
	
	PMOS afternoon briefing - 24 June

title: Menna Elfyn – Y Bardd
text:
Menna Elfyn – Y Bardd
				

					
					Bardd Plant, Rebel a Gwersyll Ffoaduriaid yn Israel

					

					Un o feirdd mwyaf llwyddiannus Cymru, a Chymraes sy'n adnabyddus ledled y byd erbyn hyn, diolch i'w theithiau tramor niferus, yw Menna Elfyn.  Mae'r bardd o Landysul, sy'n adnabyddus oherwydd iddi gyhoeddi llawer o'i cherddi'n ddwyieithog, yr un mor boblogiadd gyda darllenwyr di-Gymraeg â chyda'r Cymry Cymraeg.  Ond eleni, plant Cymru yw ei chynulleidfa fwyaf, gan iddi gael ei phenodi'n fardd Plant Cymru 2002-3, y ferch gyntaf i dderbyn yr anhrydedd ers sefydlu'r swydd dair blynedd yn ôl.  Yn ogystal â barddoni, mae hi'n ysgrifennu nofelau i blant ac ar Ddydd Mawrth 3 Rhagfyr bydd Menna yn lansio ei nofel Rana Rebel yng nghwmni plant Ysgol Gyfun Abergwaun, Sir Benfro.

					

					Wedi teithio i bedwar ban byd a mentro tu hwnt i lwybrau twristaidd gwledydd pur ansefydlog, mae Menna yn ymgyrchwraig frwd dros hawliau merched a'r lleiafrifoedd ledled y byd, yn enwedig plant.  Ble bynnag y bydd hi'n teithio, mae'n ceisio cael argraff real o wlad, sut mae tlodion, pobol anffodus a lleiafrifoedd yn byw, a pha broblemau sy'n dod i'w rhan.  Dyma a'i hysgogodd i ysgrifennu ei nofel newydd i blant yn eu harddegau, Rana Rebel.

					

					 'Mater o raid oedd ysgrifennu Rana Rebel.'  meddai Menna, heb betruso  Mae pob cymdeithas wedi anwybyddu hawliau sylfaenol plant i gael eu clywed, eu credu, eu parchu... nid eiddo mohonynt. Mae Rana Rebel yn son am bwnc nad yw'n neis iawn. Am ryw reswm mae anhawster y pwnc yn atyniad  Ond rhaid pwysleisio mai ysgrifennu stori own i a bod ystyriaethau gwleidyddol a chymdeithasol yn toddi i gefndir y meddwl pan fo rhywun yn dechrau byw y cymeriadau... '

					

					Mae terfysgaeth wedi tyfu'n ofid mawr i bawb erbyn hyn, ac mae Rana Rebel yn stori amserol iawn gan ei bod yn treiddio i fyd terfysgwyr ac yn gofyn cwestiynau dyrys ynghylch eu cymhellion.  Beth ar y ddaear sy'n gwneud i rywun aberthu ei fywyd ac i ladd eraill er mwyn gwneud safiad dros achos? Rebel yw Rana, y prif gymeriad, rebel i'r carn. Mae hi'n bymtheg oed erbyn hyn, ond bu'n byw bywyd milwr er pan oedd hi'n ferch fach, yn lladd y gelyn ac yn osgoi cael ei lladd.  Mae popeth yn troi'n gymhleth iddi pan ddaw ar draws dau fachgen anobeithiol o ddiniwed.  Beth ddylai hi ei wneud â nhw, gofalu amdanynt ynteu eu gadael ar drugaredd y gelyn?

					

					Mae'n peri syndod i bobl y Gorllewin yn aml fod plant a phobol ifanc mor barod i fynd yn filwyr, ond mae Menna Elfyn wedi profi hyn yn Sri Lanka, gyda Theigrod Tamil, ac yn y Dwyrain Canol,  Mae'n ddiddorol nodi bod elw Rana Rebel yn mynd i gynnal gweithgareddau llenyddol mewn gwersyll i ffoaduriaid ar dir y Palestiniaid ar y Lan Orllewinol, yn Israel. 'Camp Aida'.

					

					Yn eironig iawn, fe fydd y nofel hon yn anrheg gwych i bobl ifanc Cymru wrth ddathlu'r Nadolig yn eu moethusrwydd a'u hwyl.

					

					Am fanylion pellach neu lun o'r clawr/lansiad cysylltwch â Meinir Garnon James 01559 362371 meinir@gomer.co.uk

					

					

					

					

					Un o'r goreuon yn Ewrop

					

					Mae'r bardd Menna Elfyn yn teithio â'i gwaith i bedwar ban byd. Mae'r gyfrinach yn y ffordd y mae'n cyfieithu ei cherddi, yn ôl Deryn Rees-Jones…

					

					Mae Menna Elfyn yn dechrau Cusan Dyn Dall, ei thrydedd gyfrol ddwyieithog a'r ail gyda gwasg Bloodaxe Books, gyda gair o ddiolch i'w chyfieithwyr: y bardd Americanaidd Joseph Clancy, Gillian Clarke, Tony Conran, Nigel Jenkins ac Elin ap Hywel.

					

					Meddai, "Mae eu gallu nhw i ail-greu y cerddi hyn mewn iaith arall, yn rhoi cyfle i mi allu gwthio ffiniau yr hyn sy'n bosib ei gyfieithu, ac yn fy ngalluogi i i greu helfa drysor gyda chwilotwyr awyddus sydd weithiau'n gweld mwy nag y byddai'r bardd yn fodlon ei gyfadde'."

					

					Mae'n mynd yn ei blaen: "Mae unrhyw driciau tanllyd gen i yn cael eu boddi yn nhân eu gallu hwy."

					

					Eto'i gyd mae Menna Elfyn yn ymwybodol iawn o anawsterau cyfieithu, a'r hyn sy'n rhaid ei wneud wrth gyfieithu.

					

					Mae'r casgliad o gerddi'n gorffen gyda'r gerdd 'Cusan Hances' sy'n cynnwys sylw gan RS Thomas: "Mae cerdd mewn cyfieithiad fel cusan drwy hances."

					

					Ond mae Menna Elfyn yn mynd ati i'w ateb yn hapus: "A mynnaf hyn / A fo cerdd bid hances / ac ar fy ngwefus // sws dan len."

					

					Mae Menna Elfyn yn fardd o ymrwymiad gwleidyddol clir, ac mae ei hymrwymiad i Gymru yn amlwg. Mae nifer o'r cerddi yn ymateb i ddigwyddiadau neu'n straeon o bapurau newydd, neu'n deillio o'i theithiau eang fel sgrifennwr.

					

					Mae ei safwe yn rhestru ei theithiau nesa' rhwng Cymru, Brwsel, Galicia, Romania, Prâg a Phortiwgal y gwanwyn hwn. Mae'r casgliad hwn o'i barddoniaeth yn ei gweld yn symud yn rhwydd rhwng Cymru, yr Unol Daleithiau, Fietnam, yn ogystal â'r llefydd bychain hynny yn y dychymyg.

					

					Yn y gyfrol Cusan Dyn Dall, mae yna deimlad powld, hapus, weithiau'n epigramatig, ac mae'r cyfan wedi'i wreiddio'n ddwfn mewn teimlad o hunaniaeth, yn bersonol ac yn genedlaethol.

					

					Mae'r gerdd 'Dim ond Carnedd' yn engraifft o Menna Elfyn ar ei gorau, ac o linell ola'r gerdd honno y daw teitl y gyfrol.

					

					Mae yna is-bennawd i'r gerdd hon – "wrth ddarllen am y diwydiant dillad isaf". Mae'n awgrymu fod cerdd ysgafn a doniol i ddilyn.

					

					Ond yn hytrach, mae'r gerdd yn fyfyrdod estynedig ar ddillad, ar y fenyw ac ar y corff, rhyddhau dychymyd, y cysylltiad rhwng cyfalafiaeth cenedl, hanes, rhywioldeb, yn bersonol ac yn gyhoeddus.

					

					Mae hi mor anodd dyfynnu o'r gerdd hon gan ei bod hi'n gweithio mor brydferth yn ei chyfanrwydd, ond dyma'r tri pennill cynta':

					

					Mor ardderchog yw gwisg ordderch

					ein dychymyg. Tryloywa'n llaes, sideru

					gwrthbanau trwm ar bostyn y gwely.

					

					ac ar ôl dior yr atgof digri

					am staes mam-gu yn gwrido nôl

					arnaf, asennau crog fel lladd-dy dynol,

					

					daw genethod sidanaidd i'r meddwl:

					sleifio ar gynfas, dyfrliwio'r co'

					heb na ffrâm na bach a llygad i'w pwyo

					

					Mae pwysigrwydd cael cerddi Cymraeg a Saesneg ochr yn ochr yn hanfodol – yn wleidyddol yn ogystal ag yn ymarferol (aesthetically).

					

					Mae cyfieithiad Elin ap Hywel yn rhoi i mi gerdd Saesneg sy'n sefyll ar ei thraed ei hun, ond dyw hi ddim yn rhoi i mi drefn odli dynn Menna Elfyn. Nid beirniadaeth yw hyn, dim ond sylw.

					

					Fe glywais yn ddiweddar fod y bardd a'r ymgyrchydd a'r enillydd gwobr Nobel o Fecsico, Octavio Paz, yn credu mai dyletswydd sgrifennwr oedd gosod pethau mewn carreg. Dyletswydd y cyfieithydd, meddai, yw eu rhyddhau nhw.

					

					Mae'r gwaith yna o ryddhau yn bwysig iawn. Fel y dywedodd y bardd o Gaerdydd, Gwyneth Lewis, "Nid yr hyn sy'n cael ei golli trwy gyfieithu ydi barddoniaeth, ond yr hyn sy'n cael ei ennill."

					

					Mae'r broliant ar gefn y gyfrol, Cusan Dyn Dall yn gosod Menna Elfyn yn rhwydd ymysg beirdd amlyca' Ewrop. Er ei bod hi'n gallu ymddangos yn ddigywilydd i ddweud pethau o'r fath am feirdd sy'n dal i fod yn fyw, mae yna reswm tros wneud gyda Menna Elfyn .

					

					Mae ei gwaith yn llawn egni, deallusrwydd, didwylledd ac ehangder y gallai nifer o sgrifennwyr ddysgu llawer o'i darllen.

					

					

					| GOLWG - Mai 2001 |

title: Microsoft Word - princes royal trust for carers.doc
text:
Microsoft Word - princes royal trust for carers.docYoung carers (young people under the age of 18 who take on
responsibilities for looking after someone in their family) are
particularly likely to be affected by alcohol misuse. Many young
carers are in a caring role for a parent who misuses alcohol. Young
Carers Projects are the specialist service for this group, providing
breaks, clubs, mentoring and family support, but they are able to
work most effectively where they have a good relationship with their
local substance misuse support agencies. Unfortunately, many agencies
which support adults with drinking problems are better at focusing
on their clients as individuals than on their clients as parents and
family members. Alcohol support workers will often be unaware of the
caring role being taken on by their client's children, which can
begin at ages as young as 5 and can involve emotional support,
clearing up after binges, looking after younger siblings and all the
household chores. The effects on young carers can include isolation,
social exclusion, failure at school, bullying and ill health. As a
result, young carers can grow up to be socially excluded adults at
risk of substance misuse themselves.
Most Young Carers Projects take a whole-family approach to supporting
young carers; it is essential that other agencies adopt this approach
as well.
My organisation is a network of 61 Young Carers Projects UK-wide. If
you would like examples of where joint-working has been effective and
where it has not, I would be happy to help.
Yours,
Alex Fox, Young Carers Development Co-ordinator
The Princess Royal Trust for Carers

RAMMELL WELCOMES NEW POSTCODE FOR THE FALKLAND ISLANDS


(19/05/03)









From today, residents of the Falkland Islands will be able to enjoy a postcode, similar in format to those used in the UK. Bill Rammell, Foreign Office Minister, welcomed the innovation, saying:



'The new postcode being introduced today will help reduce delays in the direction of mail to the Islands. Falkland Islands inhabitants often find that their letters have transited the postal systems of places such as the Faroe Islands, Iceland or the most popular destination for lost Falklands mail, Falkirk in Scotland. The postcode should also make on-line shopping easier for Falklands residents, given that most Internet-purchasing services require a post or zip code before transactions can be completed. The Islanders can now take full advantage of today's communications options, with all the benefits that that brings.'



The problem particularly affects letters posted from outside the UK to the Falklands.



Postcodes are simultaneously being introduced today for South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands, and British Antarctic Territory.



Other UK Overseas Territories in the South Atlantic, namely St Helena and Ascension Island, have had postcodes since March 2002.



NOTES FOR EDITORS	

The project was created with the help of the International Division of Royal Mail and the Universal Postal Union in Berne, Switzerland.



	

The designated postcodes are:


Falkland Islands FIQQ 1ZZ

South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands  SIQQ 1ZZ

British Antarctic Territory  BIQQ 1ZZ



St Helena STHL 1ZZ

Ascension Island ASCN 1ZZ

Homelessness statistics 2002 
The homelessness statistics represent the number of households who approached local authorities and were found to be homeless through no fault of their own and to have a priority need for help.

Between July and September 2002, 33,640 households were accepted for re-housing by local authorities. This figure has gone up by 10% since the last quarter and is 9% higher than this time last year. 64% of all households were families with children or households containing a pregnant woman. 

At the end of September 2002, there were 84,800 households living in temporary accommodation - an increase of 4% on the previous quarter and an increase of 9% compared to this time last year. Although the number of families with children in B&B hotels has remained at around 6,500 for the second quarter running, the overall number of households in B&B hotels has increased by 7%.

Nationally, parents, family or friends no longer being able or willing to provide accommodation remained the biggest reason given for loss of a settled home, accounting for 34% of homelessness acceptances.  A further 23% of acceptances were a result of relationship breakdown, of which seven out of 10 cases were homeless because of domestic violence. 

Black and minority ethnic communities continue to be over-represented among those accepted as homeless. Between July and September 2002, of the 33,640 households accepted as homeless, over 8,000 were from a black or minority ethnic background. 
Homelessness varies widely across the country. London accounts for 24% of the total number of homelessness acceptances nationally. This quarter the number of homelessness acceptances in Yorkshire and the Humber region rose by 35%. The North West has the third highest level of homelessness acceptances.  

Priority need groups

Priority need groups are families with dependent children, households including a pregnant woman and people who are vulnerable in other ways, such as mental or physical health problems or for other special reasons. Of the 10% increase in acceptances this quarter, the majority are families with children and pregnant women, accounting for 44% of the increase, and people with physical and mental health problems and old age, accounting for 16%. 

From 31 July 2002, the Government strengthened this safety net to include homeless 16 or 17 year olds and 18 to 20 year old care leavers; people who are vulnerable as a result of time spent time in institutions; and people vulnerable as a result of having to flee their home because of violence. However, most of the increases over the last quarter were within existing priority need categories.  

The number of people accepted as vulnerable because they are young (a category that now encompasses the new priority need groups of 16/17 year olds and 18/20 year old care leavers) accounts for 9% of the total increase this quarter.  

2,770 households were in priority need for other reasons, (a mix of existing and new categories). Out of these, 2,160 households were recorded as being accepted under the existing priority need category 'other special reason'; 460 households were accepted in the new priority need category of vulnerability due to fleeing violence (other than domestic violence); and 160 were accepted in the new priority need group of people who are vulnerable as a result of time spent in institutions.

 The Homelessness Directorate allocated an additional £10 million to local authorities in 2002-03 to enable them to respond to their new responsibilities under the Priority Need Order 2002. Local authorities are generally using the money imaginatively on a range of projects to prevent homelessness as well as meeting immediate need.
109 local authorities will increase the amount of suitable accommodation available to vulnerable groups. 

72 will improve the provision of advice and information on homelessness in their areas. 

84 will increase the resources available to their homelessness teams to provide a better, quicker service.

86 will provide further support specifically aimed at young people.

68 will establish a rent deposit type scheme or build on an existing scheme to help people access the private rented sector. 

54 will provide a higher level of tenancy sustainment and floating support.

31 will establish or build on existing mediation schemes, particularly aimed at young people and families.

 Single homelessness
The Homelessness Directorate recently asked some local authorities around the country to conduct a pilot survey of single homeless people using hostels, day/advice centres and other services during one week in November 2002.

Although it should be emphasised that the survey findings are not representative of single homeless people across the country, they provide us with some indication about their profile and backgrounds. 

In a sample of over 1,400 people:

77% were male.

29% were aged between 18 to 25 years old and 38% were aged between 25 to 39 years old. 

84% were of White-British ethnic origin. 6% were Black.

When asked where they has stayed the night before 41% said in hostels, 21% with families and friends, 14% sleeping rough, 9% were living in their own accommodation and 3% were squatting.  

29% had been in prison, 15% in local authority care and 5% in the Army.

Local authority statistics published in September shows that around 600 people are sleeping rough on any one night. This is around two-thirds lower than the nearly 2,000 recorded in 1998 and indicates that the target on reducing the number of people sleeping rough by two thirds has been maintained.

 Introduction

Homelessness is a complex issue which affects children as well as adults. It is as much about a woman and her children being pursued by a violent man from one address to another as it is about the public image of a person sleeping in a cardboard box.

Domestic violence is perhaps one of the most complex of homelessness issues. It is a significant feature of the experience of homelessness for many women and their children. Over the last seven years, more than 130,000 homeless households have been re-housed by local authorities because of domestic violence. It accounts for around 16% of homelessness acceptances every year. It is an enduring feature of homelessness. 

It is also emerging as a major factor for people who experience repeat homelessness. Indeed it is likely that a proportion of the 130,000 homeless households re-housed over the past seven years are actually the same households who have lost their homes more than once. 

This briefing brings together the most recent research and information about homelessness and domestic violence, and what is know about current accommodation and support services. It explains how domestic violence and its effects can cause a cycle of homelessness, what happens to people who are escaping violence and why an understanding of this is critical for the way that homelessness services are delivered.

Carol

Carol is 21 year old with a daughter aged five. As a child, Carol and her mother spent many months living with friends. Her father was violent and, although he was not physically abusive to Carol, she did witness the abuse her mother suffered and was scared all the time.

Carol had been living with her partner for six years but his violence towards her got worse and worse as the years went by. Her daughter witnessed her being beaten although was not abused herself.

Carol left twice during this period but on both occasions her partner pursued her. She went back to him on both occasions believing he would change, but also because she felt that she could not cope alone. Although she found it hard to talk about what was happening to her, she did talk to her GP with whom she has stayed in contact with.

Carol found the frequent moving around very difficult and desperately hopes that she will not have to move again too soon as in the last six months, her daughter has already missed a month of school.

She currently lives in a supported hostel in the Midlands. She now feels that with the right support she can stand-alone and make a life for herself and her daughter.
 The impact of domestic violence

Domestic violence accounts for around a quarter of all recorded crime and two incidents of domestic violence are reported to the police every minute. It claims the lives of two women a week. Nearly half of all female murder victims are killed by a partner or ex partner. 35 per cent of murders in the last five years have been a consequence of domestic violence. It has the highest rate of repeat victimisation of any crime - that is to say that violence is rarely a one off event. Statistics show women are physically abused an average between 30 and 35 times before they take action.

Domestic violence affects all kinds of women; it is not confined to any social class, ethnic origin, or particular age. Although men too experience domestic violence, women are more likely to experience domestic violence at some point in their lives, more likely to experience repeat victimisation, more likely to be injured and to seek medical help, more likely to experience frightening threats and more likely to be frightened and upset. 

Domestic violence has profound physical, social, and psychological effects on those who experience it. However, these effects vary according to the types of violence and abuse a woman is exposed to and on the quality and consistency of the support she has.

Domestic violence is a significant cause of permanent injury, disability and even death as well as chronic pain and internal injury. Risks of domestic violence increase with pregnancy and, with many women suffering miscarriages, stillbirths and foetal abnormalities.

Psychological effects include guilt and low self-esteem. Incidents of mental health problems, anxiety and depression, as well as post traumatic stress are known to be greater among women who have experienced domestic violence.

Children are also deeply affected by domestic violence. One study has suggested that children are present in around two thirds of households that experience violence . Many children are abused themselves, either emotionally or physically.

The links between homelessness and domestic violence

For some, escaping domestic violence will involve leaving the family home - often as the last resort. In these circumstances a woman and her children are double victims. Leaving home can be an immediate response to a crisis situation or a more planned response to a long period of abuse or violence.

For women living in poverty or who are financially dependent on an abuser, a decision to leave home is likely to be more difficult because of the fear of not being able to find an alternative for themselves and their children. Women in these circumstances are more likely to rely on local authorities or other agencies for help.  

When women decide to leave, they will need access to safe secure accommodation, either temporarily while they consider their options or permanently. Women's refuges have for many years provided places of safety and security for women and their children in crisis. But women fleeing their home also seek help from local authorities for help under the provisions of the homelessness legislation. 

The official figures record the number of households who having approached local authorities are accepted as being homeless and having a priority need (usually children in the family, pregnancy or some form of vulnerability). And these official figures are likely to be an under-estimate of those who lose their homes because of domestic violence. Many other women turn to family or friends as an immediate respite from violence and may only later make an application as homeless. In these cases, the recorded reason for the loss of home would be that they could no longer stay with family or friends.

Studies of homeless families over the years have shown how significant a problem domestic violence is: 

38% of families using Shelter's Homeless to Home projects had lost their home through domestic violence, based on both local authority figures and the family's interpretation of their situation . 

A study of families at a homeless centre in Birmingham found that nine out of ten families were homeless because of violence and that in 69% of cases the perpetrator was a partner or former partner .

The Bleinheim Project in Bradford provides supported housing services for homeless women with and without children. In 2001/2 39% of their clients were homeless because of domestic violence. In the first five months of this year, 47% of women accommodated were fleeing domestic violence.

Although it may be the case that the nature of the projects means they are more likely to be used by women who have been through traumatic experiences, it does reveal how much domestic violence is part of the homelessness experiences of many people.

As well as being a direct and underlying cause of homelessness, domestic violence also appears to be a strong factor for those who experience 'repeat' homelessness. The main study of repeat homelessness among people who approach their local authority for help was carried out in Scotland. Based on a survey of 4,000 applications in 25 local authority areas, it found that around 27% of homelessness applications were 'repeat' presenters . 

Pat

Twenty-nine year old Pat was taken into care as a teenager after suffering physical and sexual abuse from her mother. She met her first partner when she was 15 and he was18 years old. The violence started soon after they began to live together.

Shortly after her son's birth her partner went into prison for two years and she began a relationship with another man who was also violent. Pat moved to Wales to escape, staying in a succession of refuges. She attempted suicide several times and was afraid of telling people about what had happened to her in case they thought she was a bad mother.

She was re-housed but her first partner found out where she was living. Fear of living alone and the difficulties of coping without family and friends made her take him back.

After the birth of their daughter, the violence started again. After her son was also physically abused, she decided to leave and moved to a refuge before finally moving to Yorkshire. The family had four addresses in two years. Pat and her children were placed in a local authority hostel. After three months they moved into a council property in the centre of town. Although she is no longer taking the anti-depressants, which she took for a number of years, Pat has a difficult relationship with her children because she finds it difficult to show them affection. She

also fears that she will in turn become an abuser to her own children. Neither children are reading at the level expected by the schools and have missed at least three months of school in the last year. Both children have spent short periods in foster care over the last three years to give Pat a break.
Why should domestic violence lead to repeat homelessness? 

In some ways this has an obvious answer. It frequently takes many attempts to leave an abusive relationship; women can become trapped in a cycle of domestic violence, being pursued by violent partners and returning to the family home. And crucially, the longer-term emotional and psychological effects of domestic violence and mobility can prevent women and their children from resettling after re-housing.

Domestic violence has the highest rate of repeat victimisation of any crime. A perpetrator may pursue the woman and her family, forcing them to move again. Over 40% of women who reported having been a victim of domestic abuse were not living with their abuser at the time of the assault . Linda, one of the women interviewed for this report and her children had moved 23 times in seven years.

One woman described the life of her family who had had been re-housed: "My husband has followed us, so it's all started again. I'm sick of running from houses all the time, we've been in refuges and hostels. It's no life for the kids. It takes them half an hour to pack their stuff and we'd be out the door. That's how much they are used to it." 

Recognising, accepting and leaving abuse is a lengthy and difficult process. Any intimate relationship means that people's lives become entwined and women may leave their abusive partner and return many times over. Leaving a husband or partner can also isolate a woman from her family and community, so removing her only source of support. It has been estimated that it takes around 6 attempts for abused women to leave their partner. Of those women who left refuges in 1997/8, at least one in five returned to their abusers. 

The experience of being placed in temporary accommodation - bed and breakfast, or a hostel, a long way from the family home, requiring the children to change schools and move away from their friends, important stabilising influences for the children, may seem too traumatic. Children may become unsettled in a new environment and women may feel vulnerable and exposed. In such cases, it may seem a better option to return home.

In some cases, homeless women who have led unsettled lives, perhaps experiencing abuse or neglect in their own childhood, and experiencing violent and unstable relationships in adult life, are unable to settle down. Typically they have few social networks and find it difficult to form and sustain relationships. Isolation, the practical problems of moving into a new home with few possessions and little money, children's behaviour, the appearance of a previous partner or disputes with a neighbour can leave them unable to cope and many will leave again, repeating the cycle of homelessness. 

Linda

Linda is 35 years old and has three daughters, aged 12, nine and eight. She is currently living in a privately rented house in the North West and is waiting to move into a property she is buying.

Linda's childhood was spent in and out of care having suffered sexual abuse. As an adult, Linda has been in a violent marriage for 13 years. She became homeless for the first time seven years ago and moved to a refuge. Since then, she and the children have had 23 addresses having been pursued relentlessly by her husband.

Finally, two years ago, after getting back together with him for the seventh time she decided she would not go back even when he found her. Since that decision she has found it difficult to settle down and has still moved a few times - she would "just put the keys through the letter box and move on". She reached what she describes as "rock bottom", and felt suicidal. Through a health visitor, she was referred to a community psychiatric nurse who has helped her to put roots down somewhere for the first time.
What does this mean for services?
Domestic violence is first and foremost a crime and stopping domestic violence and bringing perpetrators to justice is the over-riding priority. Health and social services, community safety and crime reduction programmes all have a critical role in tackling domestic violence. At a local level, a range of initiatives and partnerships are well established through crime and disorder strategies, and domestic violence forums. 

However, domestic violence is a significant feature in homelessness. Understanding more about domestic violence gives greater intelligence about homelessness itself, so that better interventions can be developed to prevent homelessness and to avoid its recurrence. 

The availability of safe secure accommodation for women, either as a respite or as a stepping stone to re-housing is critical and potentially life saving. Refuges across the country have an important role to play in the provision of safe accommodation at a time of crisis for women and their children. In 1998, there were 2,715 spaces for households in refuges in England . Recent data from Supporting People analysis indicates there are now approximately 3,772 household spaces in England . While there are some differences in the way data was collected, the overall trend is upward.

However, refuge provision is neither the only, nor the main source of accommodation for homeless women and their families. In March 1999, there were over 7,000 households living in temporary accommodation who were homeless because of domestic violence . While there was considerable variation at a regional level, only 15% were in refuges. The rest were living in other forms of temporary accommodation - 25% were staying with friends and relatives; 30% were in temporary council or housing association properties; 13% were in hostels and 6% were in Bed and Breakfast hotels.

With around 40% of domestic assaults carried out by perpetrators living outside the home, many women will want to remain their homes if their security can be assured.  A number of crime reduction initiatives have focused on measures to improve home and personal security to achieve this. Women who elect to stay in their home have generally felt they made the right decision  although, in addition to security issues, a number of practical problems also need to be addressed in order to enable women to remain in their homes - such as dealing with ex-partner rent arrears and revising tenancy agreements. Advice and assistance in these areas are crucial and women receiving such help found the support they received from agencies invaluable. 

The Sanctuary Project

The London Borough of Harrow has set up a new scheme to provide additional security measures for domestic violence victims to prevent homelessness. The scheme works operates in conjunction with the local domestic violence forum and the Police.

Police attending incidents offer the service to women where appropriate and also offer an outreach worker from Women's Aid to talk through their options. Crime prevention officers make recommendations for appropriate safety measures. Crucial to the service is that the works are carried out quickly to retain the client's confidence. The scheme is voluntary and available to women living in any tenure.

In addition to the provision of new and extra locks and lighting, a 'secure sanctuary' is created in the home converting a bedroom into a safe room through reinforcing doors and placement of bolts. Personal alarms and the provision of police mobile phones are also included as well as a help line for women to find out about the scheme.
Women and children will need a range of support, as they will use different services at different times according to their needs. Most refuges provide a core set of support services to their residents and certain services to ex residents. However, since the majority of homeless households who are escaping domestic violence are not staying in refuge accommodation, it is particularly important that they have access to services, which provide them with support during this time. 

The collection of data for Supporting People has provided, for the first time, information about the availability of support services specifically for households experiencing domestic violence who are not living in refuges. The information concerns services for those who are in other forms of temporary accommodation, or who have remained in their homes, and people who have been re-housed. 

This data shows that at the end September 2002, there were outreach services, floating support and resettlement provision for over 3,600 households in England specifically for people experiencing domestic violence. 

There were, in addition, community or social alarm services for over 100 households. Other households who are experiencing domestic violence may be receiving support from a generic, rather than a specialist support service, such as family resettlement projects.

The Supporting People Handy Guide  sets out in greater detail the range of support needs which may be needed for women experiencing domestic violence and which services are likely to be eligible for funding under the Supporting People arrangements. 

Support services for children may also form part of provision for survivors of domestic violence. In 1999, almost 80% of refuges employed specialist children's staff. The range of services includes organised play and outings, work with mothers, supporting children in education and counselling and therapy sessions.

Jyoti

Jyoti, an Asian Women's Refuge in Birmingham, employs two children's development workers, one of whom is funded by Health and Social Services. Supportive work with mothers as well as practical assistance in accessing education and health services for their children is a vital part of the workers role. This involves:

Developing play programmes for children to increase their self-esteem and confidence. This involves outdoor excursions and indoor activities.

Building a relationship with mothers and supporting them in caring for their children.

Supporting children's educational development through organising re-admittance to school and aiding the mother during the process such as helping with completing forms and visiting the school.

Supporting children and parents where child protection proceedings are taking place.

Making referrals to appropriate agencies that may aid the children's development can be made and accessed to support the family.

Children under five also receive the support of the local health visitor. Mothers have the opportunity to discuss their concerns surrounding the social and educational welfare of their child to the health visitor who would arrange additional support.

A new approach to homelessness 

In March this year, the new Homelessness Directorate published 'More than a roof' which marked a key change in the Government's approach to tackling homelessness. It signalled a recognition that, to tackle homelessness more effectively, the personal and social problems that cause and perpetuate homelessness need to be addressed as much as the need to address housing. 

Local authorities across the country are responding to this new approach. They are using the opportunities provided by Supporting People and the new homelessness strategies to review their policies and service provision. A range of new initiatives and services specifically to try to deal more effectively with the homelessness implications of domestic violence are being established. Specialist resettlement workers for women from particular minority ethnic communities; outreach services supporting women before they reach crisis point and through the re-housing process; and specialist advisers assisting women on their legal and property rights. Some examples of new and existing projects across the country include:

Outreach service in Eastbourne, Lewes and Wealden Councils
This is a joint venture with three councils in East Sussex working in partnership with Refuge.  A new outreach service is being developed to help support women who are considering leaving or have left their family home because of domestic violence. Violent relationship breakdown is one of the most significant causes of homelessness in these areas.

Repeat homelessness in Manchester
The council has set up an outreach project for homeless households experiencing domestic violence, with particular focus on those who experience repeat homelessness. The aim is to engage with a client group who have complex problems including substance misuse and mental health needs in addition to their experiences of domestic violence. Outreach workers contacted those who have applied as homeless more than once over the last two years and have offered support and resettlement services for those in temporary accommodation or who have recently been rehoused. The service is also offered to all those who apply as homeless because of domestic violence.

Safe house in Gateshead

Domestic violence is one of the biggest causes of homelessness in Gateshead.  To better meet the range of needs of households experiencing domestic violence, the Council has developed two safe houses providing self-contained accommodation.  This will complement existing refuge provision in the area. The safe houses aim to provide accommodation for women for whom shared accommodation within the refuge is not appropriate for cultural reasons, or because of the make up of the household. Clients will be supported by tenancy support workers who will also co-ordinate specialist services. It is hoped this new accommodation will provide safety and security for around 40 households a year.
Surviving Homelessness Project

This project in Nottingham provides a support service for homeless women and their children, particularly those who have been repeatedly homeless, as well as those at risk of homelessness. Through weekly drop in, therapeutic groupwork and intensive support to individuals, the project aims to break the cycle of homelessness, promote sustained resettlement and improve the health and well-being of women and children. Many of the families share a history of repeat homelessness, domestic violence, abuse as children and parenting difficulties. It provides a safe environment for mothers to explore their role as parents and promote the development of their children. It is a user led service, enabling users to have a real impact on service provision.

Cross Government activity on domestic violence

The Government is committed to tackling domestic violence, a serious and abhorrent crime. Stopping domestic violence and bringing perpetrators to justice is a priority. It aims to ensure that:

We increase safe choices for women and children, whether inside or outside the home.

We hold accountable all those responsible for perpetrating this crime.

We develop effective interventions to prevent repeat attacks.

We challenge the 'just a domestic' culture and ensure that this crime is no longer excused, tolerated or ignored.

To achieve this, the Government is concentrating on:
Increasing safe accommodation choices for women and children

Developing early and effective healthcare intervention

Improving the interface between the criminal and civil law

Ensuring a consistent and appropriate response from the police and CPS

Promoting education and awareness raising 

A Ministerial Group, chaired by John Denham, Minister of State in the Home Office, is working across Government to provide co-ordinated and concerted action on this issue at the highest level. Reducing and ultimately ending this crime requires active joined up working across all Government departments.   To this end, a virtual unit, led by the Home Office has been set up to deliver joined up action and policy on this issue through Whitehall.

Action so far: 

The Home Office has announced that a wide ranging consultation paper setting out proposals to prevent domestic violence will be published by spring 2003. It will build on the proposals included in the recent Criminal Justice White Paper, Justice for All. 

The Women & Equality Unit in the DTI has commissioned a major review of the economic and social costs of domestic violence, the results will be published in summer 2003.

The Lord Chancellor's Department has announced an amendment to the Adoption and Children Bill which will make clear that harm includes any harm a child may suffer or is at risk of suffering as a result of witnessing the ill treatment of another person.

The Law Officers' Department has announced the publication of revised Crown Prosecution Service Guidelines.  This explains the relevant legislation and procedures to follow and sets out a useful checklist guide to assist users through the process.  A policy statement has also been developed which explains how the CPS deal with cases of domestic violence. Summary

introduction of genetically modified herbicide tolerant (GMHT) sugar beet would result in a major
saving in weed control costs in the crop for growers, including control of problem weeds such as
perennial weeds and weed beet.  However, there would be other economic consequences of growing
GMHT beet, some of which would manifest themselves in other parts of the rotation, such as the
previous crop, the cereal stubbles that proceed most beet crops, soil tillage and spray application.  The
average national saving for UK sugar beet growers if they could use the technology would be in excess

Arts and culture
The UK has a rich and diverse artistic heritage. British poets, playwrights, musicians, painters and filmmakers have left works that continue to be enjoyed and admired all over the world.
Today, the massive scope of artistic expression in the UK reflects the personal freedom, prosperity and cultural diversity of the British people.
The UK government recognises and encourages the substantial contribution to the economy made by the 'creative industries'. 
These industries include advertising, architecture, designer fashion, film and video, video games, music, the performing arts, television and radio.

title: A review of local government procurement in England: consultation letter
text:
A review of local government procurement in England: consultation letterA review of local government procurement in England: 
consultation letter 
Dear Colleague, 
Delivering better services to citizens 
I am pleased to enclose a copy of Delivering Better Services for Citizens the report by the jointly 
sponsored DTLR and Local Government Association (LGA) taskforce chaired by Sir Ian Byatt to 
review local government procurement. I also enclose the associated survey of local authority 
procurement practice, Local Authority Procurement: A Research Report. 
The key objective of the taskforce was to review the state of procurement skills and practice in 
local government in England in the light of the requirements of best value in particular. The report 
includes 39 recommendations addressed to local government, central government, suppliers and 
other organisations with an interest in local government procurement. 
The DTLR and LGA have agreed to hold a joint consultation process on the report before 
responding themselves. A detailed response will follow in the Autumn with an action plan for 
implementation. 
The report is being sent out to all principal local authorities in England and to all the organisations 
which submitted evidence to the Taskforce (listed at Annex B of the report). We welcome views on 
any of the issues raised in the report. Responses from interested organisations or individuals other 
than the above are of course also welcome. 
The report is available on the this web site 
Local Government Procurement Task Force 
Local Authority Procurement: Research Summary 
Further copies of the Report (ISBN 1 851124 85 3) and the Research Report (ISBN 1 85112 483 7) 
can be bought from the DTLR Publication Sales Centre on 01709 891 318, priced £10 and £15 
respectively. 
Free summaries of the two documents Delivering Better Services for Citizens: Executive Summary 
and Recommendations 01LG0420 and Local Authority Procurement: Research Summary 
01LG0487 can be ordered from the DTLR Free Literature Centre on 0870 1226 236. 
As we expect to receive a large number of responses we would prefer submissions to be via e-mail 
to the following address: 
byatt.consultation@odpm.gsi.gov.uk 
If you do not have access to the Internet please send your response to: Mark Upton 
Local Government Competition and Quality Division 
Department for Transport, Local Government and the Regions 
5/B6 
Eland House 
Bressenden Place 
London 
SW1E 5DU 
Tel: 020 7944 4149 
Fax: 020 7944 4099 
The deadline for responses is Friday, 24 August 2001. It would assist our analysis of the responses 
if you could set out your comments under the relevant chapter headings used in the paper and 
clearly mark to which paragraphs or recommendations your comments refer. Furthermore, 
respondents should explain who they are and, where relevant, whom they represent. 
The Department or the LGA may wish to publish the responses in due course or deposit them in 
their own libraries or that of the Houses of Parliament. Should you wish your comments to be 
treated in confidence please clearly indicate this in your response. Nevertheless, all responses will 
be included in statistical summaries of comments received and views expressed. 
If you have any questions or views on this consultation exercise you can contact Mark Upton at the 
above address or by e-mail at: byatt.consultation@odpm.gsi.gov.uk 
Yours sincerely, 
 
RICHARD FOOTITT MATTHEW WARBURTON 
DTLR LGA
