	History of the Royal Naval Air Station Yeovilton



The Royal Naval Air Station Yeovilton was commissioned HMS HERON on 18 June 1940 as a base for Naval fighter aircraft. Since then it has grown to become a multi-role station and has become the base of the Sea Harrier Squadrons, Sea King Mk IV, and Lynx and Gazelle Commando Squadrons and since the closure of the Air Station at Portland in 1999 is the base for the two Lynx Helicopter Squadrons. It is also the home of Heron Flight, a communications unit of Jetstream aircraft, together with the Royal Navy Historic Flight which fly the Swordfish, Seahawk, Firefly and Sea Fury at air shows around the country during the summer.



The Station is one of the busiest military airfields in the United Kingdom and is amongst the largest in Europe, normally housing nine squadrons and up to one hundred and fifty aircraft of varying types. Yeovilton is the only airfield to operate helicopters, conventional fixed wing and vertical take off and landing aircraft simultaneously. It is also the biggest aviation establishment in the Royal Navy, employing over 3000 service personnel and civilians to operate and support squadrons, and to provide the many facilities required to run an Air Station.



As the parent station to a major part of the Fleet Air Arm’s front line strength, Yeovilton was heavily committed to the Falkland's Campaign in 1982 when 120 aircraft and 1400 of Yeovilton’s men served in the Task Force. During the Gulf crisis in 1991, the Air Station contributed over 500 men and women and 20 Sea Kings to the coalition forces. During this particular campaign, the Sea King helicopters supported the British 1st Armoured Division in the desert and the naval forces at sea. Shortly after returning from the Gulf, the Station’s helicopters were once again called upon, this time, to provide assistance for the Kurdish Relief Operation and the rescue work in the aftermath of the Bangladesh cyclone. For those humanitarian tasks some 400 men, together with 13 Royal Navy Sea Kings and 14 Royal Marine Gazelles and Lynx helicopters were deployed.



Most recently, Sea Kings from Yeovilton have been a vital part of UN and NATO operations in the Former Republic of Yugoslavia and by the time they left in 2000 they were the longest serving Unit in the region. They were also involved in the operations in Sierra Leone. In addition, Sea Harriers embarked in aircraft carriers have been actively involved in NATO operations in Bosnia/Kosovo, as well as allied operations over Iraq, and flew many missions over Sierra Leone. RNAS Yeovilton personnel and their Squadrons have received many awards in these worldwide operations.



The Air Station is co-located with some staff of the Commodore Naval Aviation and the Equipment Support (Air), a Tri-Service Organisation which looks after all helicopter engineering and support matters. With such eminent neighbours, we welcome many distinguished visitors. This was typified in June 1991, when her Majesty the Queen presented new colours to the Naval Air Command during a ceremony at Yeovilton, and in 2001 the Prince of Wales officially opened the new Wardroom. In addition, the Fleet Air Arm Museum is situated on the doorstep and the history of Naval Aviation is carefully portrayed in many exhibits. The Museum also houses an extensive archive library and research department.



Since Yeovilton was commissioned in 1940,a strong link with the town of Yeovil has been maintained. This was strengthened in June 1962 when the Ship’s Company was granted the Honorary Freedom of the Borough of Yeovil. There was a further association with the local community when, in June 1990, as a part of Yeovilton’s Golden Jubilee celebrations, Air Station personnel were invited by Ilchester Parish Council to become honorary parishioners and to march through the town with ‘flags flying, drums beating and bayonets fixed. HMS HERON has undergone a major re-building programme of Squadron buildings, Station facilities and accommodation.

'COALITION VICTORY IS CERTAIN'


(24/03/03)









STATEMENT BY THE PRIME MINISTER, TONY BLAIR, HOUSE OF COMMONS, LONDON



With permission, Mr Speaker, I shall make a statement on the European Council which I attended in Brussels on 20 and 21 March; and report on the conflict in Iraq.



This meeting was the fourth of the special summits on economic reform in the European Union.  But, of course, the summit was dominated by Iraq.



I should like to place on record what I know will be the heartfelt gratitude of the entire House for the valour of British servicemen and women.  



I send the deepest sympathy of the government and the whole House to the families of those who have died.  They gave their lives for our safety.  They had the courage to take the ultimate risk in the service of their country, and of those who value freedom everywhere in the world.  We owe them an immense debt.



I would also like to extend my condolences and those of our nation to the families of the American personnel who have sadly been lost in recent days.



CENTRAL OBJECTIVES



We are now just four days into this conflict.  It is worth restating our central objectives.  They are to remove Saddam Hussein from power and ensure Iraq is disarmed of all chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programmes.  But in achieving these objectives, we have also embraced other considerations.  We want to do this campaign in a way that minimises the suffering of ordinary Iraqi people, brutalised by Saddam; to safeguard the wealth of the country for the future prosperity of the people; and to make this a war not of conquest but of liberation.



For this reason, we did not, as some expected, mount a heavy bombing campaign first, followed by a land campaign.  Instead, land forces were immediately in action, securing oil installations, gaining strategic assets and retaining them, not destroying them.  The air campaign has been precisely targeted.  Of course there will have been civilian casualties.  But we have done all we humanly can, to keep them to a minimum.  Water and electricity supplies are being spared.  The targets are the infrastructure, command and control of Saddam's regime not of the civilian population.  And we are making massive efforts to clear lines of supply for humanitarian aid, though the presence of mines is hindering us.



By contrast, the nature of Saddam's regime is all too plainly expressed in its actions.  The oil wealth was mined and deep-mined at that.  Had we not struck quickly, Iraq's future wealth would even now be burning away.  Prisoners are being paraded in defiance of all  international conventions.  Those who dare speak criticism of the regime are being executed.



THE MILITARY CAMPAIGN



Let me now give the House some detail of the military campaign.  



In the south, our aim was to secure the key oil installations on the al-Faw Peninsula; to take the port of Umm Qasr, the only Iraqi port to the outside world; and to render Basra, the second largest city in Iraq, ineffective as a base for military operations by Saddam against coalition troops.  In the West, in the desert, our aim is to prevent Saddam from using it as a base for hostile external aggression.  In the North, our objective is to protect people in the Kurdish autonomous zone, to secure the Northern oil fields and to ensure the North cannot provide a base for Saddam’s resistance. 



Then, the vital goal is to reach Baghdad as swiftly as possible, thus bringing the end of the regime closer.  



There is a limit to how much I can say, about the detail of our operations, especially those involving Special Forces, as I’m sure the House understands.  But, with that caveat, at present, the British and US troops have taken the al-Faw peninsula.  That is now secure.  The southern oil installations are under coalition control.  The port of Umm Qasr despite continuing pockets of resistance is under allied control but the waterway essential for humanitarian aid may be blocked by mines and will take some days to sweep.  Basrah is surrounded and cannot be used as an Iraqi base. But in Basrah there are pockets of Saddam’s most fiercely loyal security services who are holding out.  They are contained but still able to inflict casualties on our troops and so we are proceeding with caution.  Basrah international airport has been made secure.  The Western desert is largely secure.  In the North, there have been air attacks on regime targets in Mosul, Kirkuk and Tikrit.  We have been in constant contact with the Turkish Government and the Kurdish Authorities to urge calm.



Meanwhile, coalition forces led by the American 5th Corps are on the way to Baghdad.  As we speak, they are about 60 miles south of Baghdad near Karbala.   It is a little way from there that they will encounter the Medina Division of the Republican Guard who are defending the route to Baghdad.  This will be a crucial moment.



Coalition forces are also advancing on Al Kut, in the East of Iraq.  The two main bridges over the Euphrates south of Baghdad have been taken intact.  This is of critical significance.



The air campaign has attacked Iraqi military installations, the centres of Saddam’s regime and command and control centres.  A total of over 5000 sorties has taken place.



Thousands of Iraqi soldiers have surrendered.  Still more have simply left the field, their units disintegrating.  But there are those, closest to Saddam that are resisting and will resist strongly.  They are the elite that are hated by the local population and have little to lose.  There are bound, therefore, to be difficult days ahead, but the strategy and its timing are proceeding according to plan. 



THE EUROPEAN COUNCIL



At the European Council, there were of course deep divisions over the coalition action.  That is well known.  But it is not that all of European opinion is one way.  On the contrary, there was both understanding and support for the British position from many nations represented at the Council and near unanimous endorsement from the 10 accession countries who joined our Council on Friday afternoon.  In any event, whatever disagreements about the conflict itself, Europe came together to set out clearly its wishes and responsibilities in post-conflict Iraq.



The Council agreed the need to be active in the humanitarian field and to ensure that the oil revenues are held for the Iraqi people by the UN and that the Oil for Food programme continues.



The Council further agreed that the UN Security Council should give the UN a strong mandate for post-conflict Iraq and make sure that the new administration is one that is representative, careful of the human rights of the Iraqi people and allows the people to live at peace inside Iraq and with its neighbours.



THE MIDDLE EAST PEACE PROCESS



In addition, the Council stressed the vital importance of the Middle East Peace Process and the publication of the Roadmap drawn up by the US, EU, Russia and the UN and now endorsed by us all.  I reported on the talks we had had both with the US Administration and the Palestinian Authority.  I welcomed the appointment of Mahmoud Abbas as Palestinian Prime Minister.  I also welcomed the US intention to publish the Roadmap for peace as soon as the Prime Minister and his government are in place.



I know it seems out of place but I should say one word on the conventional subject matter of the summit.  Though overshadowed by Iraq, this summit on economic reform regained some momentum.  In the last few months, energy liberalisation, a single Europe-wide Patent and a single Europe Sky policy have all been agreed.  An Employment Taskforce due to report on ways to cut unemployment without generating new regulation was agreed.  This marks progress, though much remains to be done.



CONCLUSION



To return to the conflict, there are, of course, difficulties that have arisen, tragedies and accidents.  We grieve for the lives lost.  That is in the nature of war.  And it is in the nature of today’s instant, live reporting of war, that people see the pain and blood in vivid and shocking terms.  But it is worth recalling the nature of what is not always apparent, what we do not see: a nation, degraded and brutalised by decades of barbarous rule, a country that is potentially rich but whose people go hungry and whose children die needlessly from malnutrition and disease; and a regime to whom repression, torture, the abuse of human rights and possession of WMD define their very nature.



That is why we must achieve our objectives.  Saddam will go, this regime will be replaced.  The Iraqi people will be helped to a better future.  The weapons of mass destruction – for which a peaceful Iraq has no use – will be eliminated.  That we will encounter more difficulties and anxious moments in the days ahead is certain.  But no less certain, indeed more so, is coalition victory.

Bolivia

DFID published a Country Strategy Paper (CSP) for Bolivia in 2002.  The aim of our strategy focuses on the three key themes of our Latin America strategy: social inclusion, pro-poor growth and pro-poor governance.  DFID in Bolivia has moved from funding sector projects to one of higher-level policy engagement linked to resource transfers to the public sector, combined with strategic support to civil society action at the national level. In that context, the goal of DFID’s future strategy is that state and society work together to achieve sustainable poverty reduction in Bolivia.  The purpose is to support the implementation of the Poverty Reduction Strategy.  The sustainability element of the goal statement will require a commitment from international cooperation and the Government of Bolivia to work for a reduction in the current high levels of aid dependency.  The DFID strategy will retain sufficient flexibility to respond to changing priorities and the continued evolution of the PRS

Foreign & Commonwealth Office crossroads for ideas

crossroads for ideas



What is it?






	








 



The 'crossroads for ideas' initiative aims to bring together talented young people from the United Kingdom and the eight countries of Central Europe which are joining the EU in May 2004. 






	


	
The Blairs with the 69 Rising Stars from Central Europe who will be participating in workshops in the UK







 The initiative provides new opportunities for exchanging ideas, experiences and skills, and for building new networks and partnerships. The name: 'crossroads for ideas' captures the idea of this new exchange. Crossroads for ideas includes a wide variety of innovative events and activities throughout 2004, taking place in all nine countries: the UK, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. The events range from business seminars to fashion shows; from film festivals to computer game design workshops. Those taking part include students and young professionals from the different countries working together on ideas as varied as space exploration and new collaborative architectural design projects.



	"The newly-enlarged EU will see an expansion of Europe’s collective brainpower. The new EU countries have been responsible for a wealth of inventions, ideas and creative talent, from the Rubik cube to the car seatbelt to Chopin. title: Response to the National Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy -…
text:
Response to the National Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy -…Response to the National Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy
1. The principles that should underpin the strategy
The Government should be involved in managing the harmful effects of alcohol
misuse for the following reasons:
§ The harmful effects of alcohol misuse need to be publicised through
public/national campaigns and it is the Government who are best equipped to
manage and co-ordinate such campaigns. An example of this are Drink Drive
campaigns.
§ Education aimed at raising awareness is most effective when managed or co-
ordinated at a national level. National media/public information adverts ensure
everybody gets the same message, which can positively affect behaviour.  The
Department of Health already have excellent information and has run campaigns
on the effects of Drug abuse. A similar approach would assist an Alcohol Harm
Reduction Strategy.
§ Alcohol misuse causes much crime and disorder
When Government intervention is justified
§ Government intervention is justified when the health or well being of individuals
or the general public begin to suffer.  For example, Drink Drive campaigns and
the legislation that accompanies this are a response to the devastating effects that
drink driving has had on thousands of people. Alcohol and drug misuse are a huge
cost to society economically and socially, and it is only through Government
intervention that this can be tackled effectively and in a consistent manner.
5. What principles should underpin a national alcohol harm reduction strategy?
§ The basic principle has got to be education, focusing on the health implications of
alcohol misuse.
§ It is also important to focus on how anti-social behaviour is linked to alcohol
misuse and the ramifications of such behaviour.
§ The principle of the primacy of crime and disorder reduction
21. How, in your experience, can we minimise and prevent the injuries that are
presented to A&E departments as a result of alcohol related assaults (often with
glasses and bottles) or home and workplace alcohol-related accidents?
§ Effective door keeping at licensed premises would go some way to reduce the
number of alcohol related assaults. Training to a national standard for door
supervisors would be part of the overall solution.§ Liasing with managers of problem premises and agreeing on good practice, such
as toughened or plastic glasses and setting a maximum number for the premises,
would also be part of the solution.
§ Encourage night-clubs to provide transport for customers to rail links etc, to move
drinkers away from town centres.
§ Local authorities to make provision for larger Taxi Rank parking in the late
evenings near town centre Public Houses, for ease of transport and to stop people
congregating.
23. What evidence is there about the links between alcohol and crime and the links
between alcohol and anti-social behaviour? Are there any pieces of evidence you
think we should be aware of? Where are there gaps in the evidence?
§ There is research, on the Home Office Crime Reduction toolkit website, which
illustrate the links between alcohol and crime, and alcohol and anti social
behaviour. In cases of Domestic Violence practitioners within Hertfordshire
Constabulary suspect that alcohol could be a contributing factor in 50% of
incidents. In a large percentage of these incidents, the alcohol is consumed in the
home environment. Again, education and awareness raising could have an
influence in this area.
www.alcoholism.about.com gives good information on the link between alcohol and
crime/anti social behaviour.
24. In your experience, is alcohol a factor in habitual re-offending? Does it lead to
particular types of crime? How far does it lead to one-off offences?
§ Alcohol does appear to be a factor in habitual re-offending.
§ Alcohol appears to be a major factor in offences of violence and criminal damage.
§ One-off opportunistic offences can and do occur as a result of excessive alcohol
consumption.
25. To what extent can alcohol convincingly be demonstrated to be a factor in
criminal and disorderly behaviour? How much is perception and how much is
reality? What fuels the perceptions and are they accurate?
§ Figures identified by the Portman Group www.portman-group.org.uk suggest that the
perception is higher than reality in relation to alcohol related crime.
§ Perceptions can be fuelled by local press reporting incidents of anti social behaviour,
or through general rowdy behaviour in busy town centres in the late evening, and
increased noise levels. 25. Alcohol is far from being the only factor in crime and
disorder. Other factors are involved-for example town centre disorder can be
influenced by lack of availability of transport or design of environment. What other
factors might be involved? How easy are these to influence? Who is responsible for
them?
26. Alcohol is far from being the only factor in crime and disorder. Other factors are
involved – for example town centre disorder can be influenced by lack of availability
of transport or design of environment. What other factors might be involved? How
easy are these to influence? Who is responsible for them?§ There are other factors involved in crime and disorder such as:
  late night take-a-way restaurants which can attract groups of youths etc.
  a lack of appropriate activity for young people in an area
  Environmental and building design i.e. uncontrolled stairwells to flats can be a
place for groups to ‘hang out’.
§ As long as there are resources available, these factors can be influenced relatively
easily. Strict licensing also plays a significant part in reducing problems in this
area.  Longer licensing hours may actually assist as people consume alcohol at
different times.
§ Responsibility falls on many people here, for example members of  Crime and
Disorder Reduction Partnerships, shopkeepers and residents.
27. How does the impact of alcohol on urban environments differ from its impact
on rural environments? What are the differences between urban and rural
drinking patterns and how do they affect those communities and surroundings?
§ There is a difference between the impact of alcohol on urban and rural
environments. For example, when licensing laws were more restrictive,
people who drank in rural areas felt safer drinking in licensed premises
outside of licensing hours. The reason for this was rural areas had less
policing and there was the belief there was less chance of being caught.
§ Usually, in urban areas there is a wide choice of drinking establishments such
as Public Houses, restaurants and bars, where people can move around to
consume alcohol, often causing disorder in the process. However, in rural
areas local inhabitants will have little choice other than the Public House and
will stay in their local area.
§ There are differences between rural and urban drinking patterns:
  In urban areas there is more opportunity to drink through the day,
whereas in rural areas in all probability, there would not be the
demand for longer opening hours.
  Because there are more establishments in urban areas, there is more
opportunity to move around, whereas in rural areas people are
confined to their ‘local’.
  Statistics show that Police tend to receive fewer complaints about
country public houses.
  In urban areas people often move from pub to pub. This can encourage
town centre disorder, whereas in rural areas people tend to stay in the
same place in the vicinity of their home.
  In some small towns in Hertfordshire there is evidence of anti-social
behaviour being linked to under aged drinking.  It would appear that
the alcohol is being obtained in most cases from local off licenses.
  Hertfordshire have entered into a joint protocol with Trading
Standards to use “test purchases” to target premises in problem
areas.  A partnership approach is used and these problems are
addressed through the Local Authority Crime and Disorder
Reduction Partnerships. Anti social behaviour contracts and in
serious circumstances ASBO’s can be applied for.
  There is also evidence in the Youth Lifestyles Survey (“63% of 16
and 17 year olds whom had drunk in the last year said that theyusually bought alcohol for themselves).  The Licensing (Young
Persons) Bill currently going through Parliament should impact
on these problems.
28. To what extent can impacts on the environment (including crime, disorder, noise
and waste) be designed out, for example by use of plastic drinking glasses? Are there
examples of good practice it would be helpful for us to be aware of?
§ Firstly, looking at established towns options could include:
  Closing down premises that are badly run.
  Enforcing legislation on the use of Identification to enter clubs and pubs etc.
§ Planning is easier in new towns.  Restaurants and other late night establishments
can be built in one area and situated near good communication links and away
from residential housing. Stevenage Leisure Park is a good example of this.  Other
Local authorities could be encouraged to look at ‘brown field’ sites that could be
developed in a similar way.
29. There are some examples of good practice where a range of organisations
responsible for dealing with different aspects of alcohol have successfully ‘combined
efforts’ and shared information to tackle alcohol-related crime and disorder together.
Should this approach be encouraged more widely? What inhibits organisations or
communities from taking such an approach?
§ It is essential that organisations combine efforts and share information; they all
have different expertise which can help to tackle the problem of alcohol-related
crime from different angles.
§ Concerns about the legality of information sharing often inhibits organisations and
communities from working together. Protocols for the exchange of information
need to be in place. Education Departments receive will have information on
pupils who consume alcohol regularly, but the issue remains “who owns the
response to the problem?”
§ Youth drinking issues need to be addressed in a partnership approach between
Police, Local Authorities, and Education working together. When communities
experience the benefits of partnership working, solutions will have more
credibility and will be better co-ordinated through a holistic and joined up
approach. We need to get rid of the lack of trust and suspicion between agencies
and the community which sometimes exists, by sharing information and working
together towards a common goal.
30. Is it right that anti-crime and anti-social behaviour initiatives need to be targeted
on young people?
§ Not necessarily.  Initiatives aimed at tackling anti-social behaviour have to target
a whole range of people. To simply target just one group is not addressing theproblem of anti-social behaviour. Nationally, ASBO’s have been enforced on
more adults than young people. It is not just young people who commit anti-social
behaviour.
31. Should we be encouraging different drinking patterns-in terms of time spent
drinking, location of drinking etc, in order to tackle alcohol-related crime and
disorder?
Already covered above. However, it would be essential to assess and evaluate longer
drinking hours after an appropriate period.
32. How can the law on, and policing approaches to public drunkenness and street
drinking help to tackle these problems? Are existing controls and powers (such as
those for local authorities to introduce drinking zones) effective. Are they sufficient?
§ The following could help to tackle the problem of public drunkenness and street
drinking:
  The law needs to be clear and consistent and, most importantly, location
specific.
  Policing approaches need to be specific, consistent and again location
specific.
§ Existing controls and powers have a limited effect. Drinking zones have proved
very difficult to “police”, one example is in St Albans town centre in
Hertfordshire. Although the Local Authority applied and was granted the bylaw
they have been reluctant to prosecute offenders identified by the Police.  Local
officers now seize the alcohol without attempting a prosecution.  Other Local
Authorities have resisted applying for the bylaw because of the cost of following
through a prosecution.
§ The laws on drunkenness are adequate. However, officers still have a problem
when they stop a person under 18yrs in possession of alcohol.  If the container is
unopened and there is no evidence of purchase officers do not have power to
confiscate. In some areas the alcohol is purchased by 18 year olds for siblings.
Recent new laws may impact on this.
34. Drink –drive policies are generally acknowledged to have been successful. What
can we learn from them?
§ Policies have been instrumental in making drink driving socially unacceptable and
have changed the culture of driving and drinking. This proves that awareness
campaigns do work, but only over a long period. There is no quick fix!
§ However, the numbers who drive under the influence of alcohol are still high.
Young people are now as likely to drive under the influence of drugs and drug -
driving testing needs to be developed to impact on this area.
§ We have to learn from past drink-drive campaigns and promote initiatives such as
free non-alcoholic drinks for designated drivers. Busy village licensed premisescould be targeted to provide these.  Roadside notices in “hot spots” such as
“Police breath tested 20 people here last Christmas” could also help.
35. Domestic violence is often associated with alcohol misuse – either by the
perpetrator, or, on occasion, by the victim. What in your experience, is the nature of
this link and what would you see as good practice in tackling the interrelationship
between violence and alcohol misuse?
§ The nature of the link between domestic violence and alcohol misuse is that
alcohol could be the catalyst to the violence. As already identified, it is believed
that alcohol is a factor in approximately 50% of domestic violence related
incidents.
§ The nature of the link is that alcohol changes behaviour.  Education and awareness
could assist here, as can effective support from domestic violence personnel. The
victim has got to be encouraged to speak up and obtain the necessary help; the
same can also be said of the perpetrator!
§ However in low income groups home consumption leading to domestic violence
appears to be a major problem. Highlighting this contributing factor through
domestic violence campaigns could assist in reducing the instances of alcohol
related violence.

title: Financial management and policy review (FMPR) of Groundwork: consultation paper
text:
Financial management and policy review (FMPR) of Groundwork: consultation paperFinancial management and policy review (FMPR) of Groundwork: consultation paper

The Groundwork federation comprises Groundwork UK and 43 charitable trusts. DETR pays grant of about £7.5m a year directly to the Federation to enable it to promote, develop and support a range of environmental regeneration initiatives. As a condition of such funding, Groundwork is subjected to some of the controls that would normally be applied to a non-departmental public body (NDPB). This includes conducting periodic reviews of DETR sponsorship using the FMPR framework as a guide. This consultation paper invites views on:

whether DETR should continue to support the Groundwork organisation centrally, through the Federation; or

move to focus its support on the Federation alone, with the Trusts eligible to compete for public funds regionally through the Regional Development Agencies or the Government Offices for the Regions; and

proposals for greater transparency and accountability in DETR's future sponsorship of Groundwork, covering the award of public funds, the setting of targets, the monitoring of performance and outputs, and the evaluation and sharing of good practice.

Further copies of the consultation paper can be obtained from the web site or from: Francesca Seymour Zone 4/H9 Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions Eland House, Bressenden Place LONDON SW1E 5DU Telephone: 020 7944 3722 Fax: 020 7944 3729 E-mail: francesca.seymour@odpm.gsi.gov.uk

Comments should be submitted in writing or by e-mail to Francesca Seymour by 28 July 2000. Copies of all responses will be placed in the DETR library unless respondents ask for them to be treated as confidential.

Summary

The Groundwork organisation consists of a national Groundwork Federation and a network of 43 Groundwork Trusts in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

DETR pays grant of about £7m a year directly to the Groundwork Federation to enable it to promote, develop and support a range of environmental regeneration initiatives being carried out by the Trusts. This represents about 13% of the total income of the Groundwork organisation. DETR currently sponsors the organisation as if it was a public body.

This consultation paper invites views on:

whether DETR should continue to support the Groundwork organisation centrally, through the Federation; or

move to focus its support on the Federation alone, with the Trusts eligible to compete for public funds regionally through the Regional Development Agencies or the Government Offices for the Regions; and

proposals for greater transparency and accountability in DETR's future sponsorship of the Groundwork organisation, covering the award of public funds, the setting of targets, the monitoring of performance and outputs, and the evaluation and sharing of good practice.

Comments should be submitted in writing or by e-mail to the address at the end of the paper by 28 July 2000. Ministers will take account of comments when deciding their policy on the Government's future support for the Groundwork organisation and the mechanisms through which this should be delivered.

Introduction

1. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) is conducting a Financial Management and Policy Review (FMPR) of the Groundwork organisation and of DETR's sponsorship of it. This paper sets out the background, discusses issues identified during the Review so far, and invites comments. Comments should be sent to the address at the end of the paper by 28 July 2000. The Department will make all responses publicly available unless respondents ask for their comments to be treated in confidence.

The purposes of an FMPR

2. It is Government policy that Departments should conduct FMPRs of the non-Departmental Public Bodies (NDPBs) they sponsor every five years or so, as a major component of a programme of continuous improvement. The purposes are to:

assess whether there is a continuing need for the functions or services provided by the NDPB, and whether these should continue to be provided by a public body (known as the "Prior Options" part of the FMPR); and

carry out a forward looking review of the operation and management of the NDPB and the sponsorship of it by its parent Department, to establish the best organisational options for delivering the functions and services and developing and improving performance in the future.

3. The Groundwork organisation is a federation of independent charitable bodies. It is not created by statute, nor do Ministers appoint its Board members. So it is not an NDPB or any other type of public body. Nevertheless, DETR and Groundwork have agreed that it is timely to conduct a review using the FMPR framework.

4. The "Prior Options" part of the FMPR has been largely completed following a study for DETR by Baker Associates (see paragraphs 13-15). This paper focuses mainly on the issues to be considered in the second part of the FMPR process.

Groundwork's mission

5. Groundwork was established in 1981. Its mission is to bring about sustainable improvements to the local environment, through partnerships, and to contribute to economic and social regeneration. This is supported by objectives on:

physical environmental improvements;

education and community involvement;

integration of the economy and the environment;

partnership development and promotion, and

fundraising and management of the organisation.

6. These objectives are delivered through 37 national and regional programmes, and in turn through local schemes which Groundwork estimates involve 60,000 adults and over 120,000 schoolchildren in sustainable development projects each year. Groundwork is the largest provider of placements on the Environment Task Force option of the Government's New Deal for Young People.

7. Further details of Groundwork's objectives and programmes can be found at Annex A and on the Groundwork web site.

The Groundwork organisation

8. The organisation currently consists of Groundwork UK which has offices in Birmingham, London and Manchester, and 43 Groundwork Trusts operating primarily in areas of social need and environmental degradation in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. But there are many such areas where there is no Groundwork Trust and some existing Trusts operate in areas which, while they may include pockets of need or degradation, do not rank highly overall on these criteria.

9. Each Trust is constituted as an independent charity and a company limited by guarantee and is managed by a Board of trustees. Groundwork UK is similarly constituted and managed, with the Trusts as company members. Groundwork UK and some of the Trusts have trading subsidiaries whose profits are covenanted to their parent charity.

10. In November 1999 the Groundwork organisation implemented a change in its structure to make Groundwork UK more responsive and accountable to the individual Trusts, and to empower them to elect the members of the Federation Board. At the same time the national body, known previously as the Groundwork Foundation, was renamed the Groundwork Federation. This serves to emphasise its role in delivering effective support to the Trusts in planning and implementing their programmes and in ensuring that good practice is identified and shared.

Current funding

11. Groundwork receives funds from many organisations. In 1998/99 their total income was £53.2 million, made up as follows:

DETR funding of the Groundwork Federation
£6.7m
13%

Other public bodies: Agencies and NDPB

6%

Regional Development Agencies (SRB funds)

Local authorities
£8.6m

£6.6m

12. This was almost £10m (24%) higher than in 1997/98. Groundwork is budgeting for more modest growth of £8m (11%) in 1999/2000. It is DETR's funding of the Federation that is the primary focus of this review. This funding supports many of the Federation's activities and enables it to give grants to individual Trusts to support theirs. DETR's funds also enable the Federation and Trusts to lever in funds from many of the sources listed above.

The status of Groundwork

13. Groundwork is a legally independent body from Government. However, it receives substantial public funding and, as a condition of such funding, it is subjected to some though not all of the controls that would be applied to an NDPB. Consequently, Groundwork's business is transacted through an annual Corporate Plan which is presented for discussion with DETR officials and the sponsor Minister. Within the framework of that Plan and a Financial Memorandum issued by DETR, Groundwork has considerable discretion over how it spends the funds granted by DETR; and DETR's Permanent Secretary has designated Groundwork's Chief Executive as an Accounting Officer. These well-tested arrangements provide proper accountability for the significant sums of public money granted to Groundwork.

14. Overall, this makes Groundwork one of DETR's "preferred partners" in the sense that the Department bids for funds specifically for Groundwork, rather than for "environmental regeneration", in successive spending reviews. Once an allocation has been agreed, it is rarely changed and Groundwork can be confident of receiving it subject only to broad justification in its Corporate Plans and continued progress in delivering the planned outputs. This is an unusual and privileged position for a charitable body.

15. The contrasting position is that of an organisation having a contractual relationship with DETR. This will be finite in time, the contract will have been awarded by competition and will specify in detail the work to be done, and the contractor will have to compete again on merit with others in the same business for future work. DETR does not wish to suggest that Groundwork should become an NDPB, nor that it should move to a purely contractual relationship with Groundwork. Apart from other objections, the former may extinguish Groundwork's valued status in the charitable sector, while the latter may risk inhibiting the innovation and flexibility that are amongst Groundwork's major strengths. However, DETR wishes to bring about a greater degree of competition in the way in which public funds are allocated to the Groundwork UK and trusts, and greater clarity in what such funds are "purchasing" on behalf of the taxpayer.

The Prior Options Stage of the FMPR

16. To inform the first part of the FMPR and to provide some evidence for the second stage, DETR commissioned Baker Associates to review:

the extent to which Groundwork delivers outputs that contribute to the achievement of the Government's regeneration objectives; and

the most effective mechanisms for delivering these outputs.

17. Baker Associates presented their Report in July 1999. It provides a detailed analysis of the many strengths that underpin Groundwork's approach and achievements, and identifies areas where its effectiveness could be improved. A copy of the Report's Executive Summary is at Annex B.

18. The Report's key conclusions in respect of the Government's regeneration objectives are that:

in practice as well as in aspiration, Groundwork is addressing most of the Government's regeneration priorities;

Groundwork has a particular ability to reach groups, including local businesses and the socially excluded, who are often not reached by other regeneration schemes; has a flexible and innovative approach to its work and can respond well to its partners' priorities; and is achieving multiple outputs on projects and programmes, working across institutional and cultural divides, and "delivering things that might not otherwise get done";

there is some evidence that Groundwork's schemes are of lasting benefit but that, in areas of high social deprivation and economic disadvantage, these may not be retained without continuing investment;

supporting Groundwork with non-project specific funding, as well as with project funding, is a very cost effective way of ensuring that effective regeneration is delivered in areas that need it most, and that new and effective approaches to regeneration are developed; and

much more benefit could be gained if Groundwork's innovations were better evaluated and a more systematic approach taken to spreading best practice.

19. Having regard to the findings of Baker Associates, DETR considers that Groundwork should remain amongst the key agencies delivering the Government's regeneration objectives. However, DETR also acknowledges a wide diversity of such agencies, each contributing their own particular strengths to the regeneration process. Urban greening and sustainable development, to which Groundwork brought a unique perspective and expertise in the early 1980s, are now necessary ingredients of mainstream Government programmes. It is therefore the DETR's role to promote the incorporation of relevant policies in all programmes and to ensure that the expertise needed to formulate and apply such policies is widely available to public, private and voluntary bodies.

20. The Government is also committed to supporting local delivery of sustainable development through policies for social inclusion and urban renaissance, and acknowledges that there are a number of organisations whose objectives and outputs include ones that are delivered by Groundwork. For example, the British Trust for Conservation Volunteers, Development Trusts, partnerships implementing schemes under the Single Regeneration Budget and the New Deal for Communities, Wildlife Trusts, the Regional Development Agencies and the Coalfields Regeneration Trust.

21. Against that background, the purpose of this second part of the FMPR is consider the scope for even greater transparency and accountability, effectiveness and best value in DETR's sponsorship of the Groundwork organisation. The central issues are:

the appropriate mechanisms for determining and delivering future DETR support for the Groundwork Federation and Trusts, and the extent to which this should be in competition with other agencies;

the scope for improving the monitoring of performance and outputs, and the evaluation and sharing of good practice within the organisation and more widely; and

DETR's role in the creation of new Trusts.

Strategic and project funding

22. A central issue is the distinction between the strategic or core costs of an organisation such as Groundwork and the funding needed to support specific projects. This was recognised in the Compact on Relations between Government and the Voluntary and Community Sector in England, published in November 1998. The Compact acknowledges that, in a competitive funding environment, many voluntary and community organisations can find it difficult to secure funding to support the core management and administration functions they need to operate efficiently and effectively. Government funding towards these core costs can help both Departments and the voluntary organisations achieve their strategic aims, providing the organisations with a base from which to develop and promote their objectives, lever in other funds, and ensure that these are used to best effect.

23. For bodies such as Groundwork, with a central Federation supported by and supporting a network of local Trusts, this distinction is mirrored in its own organisational structure. While each Trust necessarily incurs some management and administrative costs, the Federation provides a wide range of central services that the Trusts rely on to function effectively. These services include policy and programme development, advice on governance and financial management, fundraising, assessment of performance, and the identification and sharing of good practice. The Trusts in turn inform the work of the Federation, enhancing its effectiveness.

Future DETR support for Groundwork

24. With these considerations in mind, DETR invites comments on two options for its future funding of Groundwork:

a refinement of the current position, under which DETR continues to give direct support to the Federation and, through it, to individual Trusts; and

a "regional" option, under which individual Trusts would be eligible to compete for public funds regionally through the Regional Development Agencies or the Government Offices for the Regions. Under this option Groundwork UK would either be funded directly from DETR, or by introducing a subscription for individual trusts.

(i) Refinement of the current position

25. With this option, DETR would continue to provide funds specifically for the Federation, for its own use and to provide grants for which individual Trusts would compete. The main benefit of this option is that it would retain a well-tested sponsorship model and delivery mechanism for environmental regeneration which has proved to be effective. However, in adopting this option, there would be a need to consider ways in which its effectiveness could be improved to offer best value in the use of public funds for regeneration purposes.

(ii) The regional option

26. Under this option, DETR would invite the Regional Development Agencies set up in England outside London in 1999 and the Greater London Authority, or the Government Offices for the Regions to operate a grant scheme for environmental regeneration. DETR would transfer funds, at current levels, to the RDAs and GLA, or GO-Rs for this purpose. DETR would need to consider the extent to which suitable funding mechanisms could be established, the basis upon which allocations would be made to each region and accessed by individual trusts. The Department would also need to consider an appropriate transitional arrangement where such funds would be reserved or ring-fenced for use by existing Groundwork Trusts. Different arrangements would be needed to support the Trusts in Wales and Northern Ireland.

27. The Groundwork Federation would continue to be eligible for funds directly from DETR, subject to improved procedures and clarity as indicated above. Alternatively, the Federation might consider covering some or all of its costs by introducing a subscription for individual Trusts to belong to the Groundwork organisation. Such an arrangement would mirror Groundwork's organisational changes (see paragraph 10) by giving the Trusts the funding responsibilities to complement their greater control over the Federation. However, DETR recognises that introducing a subscription might be tantamount to increasing Trusts' own core costs and so open to the issues discussed at paragraphs 22 and 23 above. It might also cause some Trusts to review their membership of the organisation, so threatening its cohesion. Nevertheless, DETR would welcome comments on this option.

Funding the Federation

28. Under both options (i) and (ii), DETR would, however, wish to review the mechanism by and terms on which it awards public funds to the Federation, and how the Federation in turn passes such funds, and benefits that accrue from such funds to individual Trusts. The aim would be to achieve even greater openness and clarity of purpose and to avoid Trusts becoming overly dependent on public funds, thereby limiting the funds available for new Trusts or initiatives, and best value in the use of public funds. This is discussed further in relation to individual Trusts below.

Funding the Trusts

29. Under option (i), the Groundwork Trusts would continue to receive DETR funds through the Federation. Under option (ii) they would receive them, and later compete for them, from the RDAs or the GO-Rs.

30. From DETR: It would be for DETR to specify the terms on which the Trusts received public funds. This raises the issue of the "12 year rule", which the then Department of the Environment introduced in 1997 to reflect the view that regeneration initiatives should either meet their objectives within a set period or, in the longer term, become self-sustaining. The "rule" states that DETR funding to individual trusts for programme and development will normally only be available for a period of up to 12 years. This is intended to discourage Trusts from expecting public funds indefinitely, and ensures that some funds remain uncommitted and available to support new initiatives.

31. The "rule" is due to bite for the first time later in 2000, when some Trusts will have received DoE/DETR funds for 12 years. At the same time further experience of regeneration projects suggests, as Baker Associates' Report has found, that continuing investment may be needed to ensure that a scheme's benefits are retained in the longer term. Particularly where that continuing investment is for activities such as monitoring and evaluation, and learning lessons to apply to future schemes, Trusts may find it difficult to attract the necessary resources from potential funders keen to see tangible social and environmental improvements.

32. The provisions of "the rule" are flexible and enable the Department to consider cases for funding individual trusts beyond the 12-year period, in exceptional circumstances. DETR therefore accepts that, in some cases, longer term core funding of Groundwork Trusts from public funds may be justified, to ensure that full and continuing value is obtained from previous investment. Nevertheless, the Department maintains the view that Trusts should still aim for self-sufficiency from other sources in the longer term and should not expect public funding in perpetuity.

33. However, if the outcome of the FMPR is that DETR funds continue to reach individual Trusts through the Federation, DETR will consider whether there is a case for replacing the "12 year rule". A possible option could be a sliding scale for the maximum percentage support that its funds can give to a project or core activity at any given time. The precise approach and figures would need further thought, and would need to include some flexibility to cope with unusual or changing circumstances. But, the key principle is that the input of DETR funds should taper to a low level - possibly to zero in some cases, over a period of no more than 10 years.

34. From the RDAs or GO-Rs: If the outcome of the FMPR is option (ii) - that DETR funds reach individual Trusts via RDAs or GO-Rs, it would be for the RDAs or the GO-Rs to determine the appropriate grant conditions taking into account DETR and other guidance. This could lead to a diversity of priorities and practice between regions. It could also spur the regional partners, including the Groundwork Trusts, into preparing or enhancing their own regional strategies to support their bids for funds.

Improving monitoring, performance outputs evaluation and good practice.

35. The Baker report identified two areas where Groundwork's performance could be improved:

monitoring effectiveness and evaluating performance of projects; and 

disseminating good practice within and without the organisation.

36. The Government's approach to regeneration emphasises the need to develop effective partnership, which involve local communities. This recognises that the long term success and benefits of regeneration are more likely to occur when people work together in partnership. It also recognises the need to build-up the capacity of local communities and voluntary sectors so that they are able to become more involved in regeneration processes. A key to achieving these aims is the ability for all those involved in regeneration processes to learn from experience and to share good practice.

37. Therefore, the Department wishes to consider ways in which the performance of Groundwork could be improved by avoiding 'reinventing the wheel', and by building on successful practice. This suggests a need for better and more structured approaches to evaluating Groundwork projects. We also need to identify the approaches that have worked well and good and bad practice, and provide a better basis for disseminating transferable lessons.

38. It is necessary to develop more effective means of promoting and disseminating experiences gained from projects not only amongst Groundwork trusts but also to others involved in environmental regeneration. The Department would therefore welcome comment on possible ways in which the performance of Groundwork may be improved through better collection and dissemination of good practice and transferable lessons.

DETR's role in the creation of new trusts

39. The Grants Memorandum, which defines the relationship between Groundwork and the Department, outlines the criteria used when evaluating proposals for the establishment of new trusts (including mergers of and extensions to existing trusts). These provide that:

the trust would further the Government's regeneration aims based on the creation of local public and private partnerships, local identity and accountability;

there should be demonstrable need for regeneration initiatives (in terms of indices of socio-economic deprivation and physical dereliction), which is not being met in the activities of existing local organisations;

there are opportunities for attracting sufficient private resources for environmental regeneration in order to progressively reduce the level of support the Trust receives from central government, and that there will be value for money in the use of public funds; and

the level of grant support provided by the Department shall be expected to decline over the life of the Trust.

40. The assessment criteria, therefore, aims to ensure that new trusts should only be established where there is a real need for regeneration, where it is wanted by local partners and communities, and where there is a realistic prospect of available funding to support the trusts over a reasonable period of time.

41. Whilst the current distribution of Trusts is very closely correlated with the distribution of need, there are nonetheless many areas with severe deprivation where there are no Groundwork Trusts. The Department accepts however that it would not be realistic to expect Groundwork to be working in all these areas, and that there are areas which are unlikely to benefit from a Trust. For example, areas where there is no local authority support for one, and areas where there are pockets of deprivation but no strong urban concentrations to provide a focus for Groundwork activities. The Government also recognises that there can be pockets of deprivation, which could benefit from Groundwork activities, within relatively prosperous areas of good environmental quality.

42. Groundwork has sought to respond to such factors by proposing a "light greening approach". This approach would enable existing Groundwork trusts to provide their services to areas of whole counties or regions which are not currently served by a trust. It would be an alternative way of providing Groundwork services to 'pockets of deprivation' within a county or a region, which, in themselves, may not be capable of sustaining a new trust or the expansion of an existing one. The approach would enable:

Groundwork services to be delivered in a way which better complements its regional development strategies/action plans, which are supported by the RDA's;

Groundwork to be more responsive to national, regional and county priorities and local needs; and

local partners across counties and regions to benefit from Groundwork's expertise in community-led regeneration, and capacity and partnership building.

43. Whilst there may be merit in the light greening approach, the Department wishes to consider in more detail how it might work and its practical implications. The Department would therefore welcome comment on this light greening approach, and other issues related to the establishment of new trusts and alternative approaches to providing Groundwork activities.

Summary

44. The broad conclusions of the prior option stage of the FMPR is that the current arrangements for supporting Groundwork have been effective in delivering the Government's regeneration priorities, and it identifies particular benefits in retaining the current sponsorship and funding arrangements. However, in the light of an increasingly regional focus for planning and delivering regeneration initiatives, it would be consistent for DETR to consider supporting Groundwork Trusts via the RDAs or GO-Rs. This would initially be a ring-fenced fund for the Trusts but in due course as funds for which anyone could compete.

45. The prior option stage also identified that Groundwork's operations could be improved by more effective monitoring and evaluation of the performance of projects; and disseminating good practice within and without the organisation. It also found that although the current distribution of Trusts is closely correlated with the distribution of need, there are nonetheless many areas with severe deprivation which might benefit from Groundwork activities.

46. Accordingly, the Department would welcome comment on:

the relative merits of the two options for future DETR support to Groundwork - refining current arrangements or adopting a regional approach;

the desirability of reconsidering the 12-year rule and the proposal for tapering funding as outlined in paragraph 34;

ways to improve the monitoring of Groundwork outputs and performance of projects, and the evaluation and sharing of good practice; and

issues related to the establishment of new trusts and alternative approaches to providing Groundwork activities.

Comments

47. Comments on the points raised in this paper, and on any others that consultees wish to raise, should be sent to:

Francesca Seymour Zone 4/H9 Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions Eland House Bressenden Place LONDON SW1E 5DU  Telephone: 020 7944 3722 Fax: 020 7944 3729 E-mail: francesca.seymour@odpm.gsi.gov.uk

Annex B - Executive Summary of a report of a Review of Groundwork, prepared for DETR by Baker Associates - 1999

Study Task

1. This report has been prepared as one input to the FMPR of Groundwork (summer 1999). The brief for the study asks a number of questions, but two are central to the review. These are:

does Groundwork deliver outputs in line with Government's regeneration objectives?

is supporting Groundwork cost effective?

2. The work has been undertaken in a number of ways:

a postal survey of Trust Executive Directors (EDs) to assemble background information on all Trusts

a data handling and mapping exercise to explore the existing distribution of Groundwork Trusts in relation to areas of need

in-depth case studies at six Trusts chosen to provide a spread in terms of size and age of Trust, region, and types of regeneration problem

interviews with a wide range of relevant commentators including Groundwork partners, beneficiaries from Groundwork regeneration activities, alternative providers of regeneration initiatives/services, and corporate funders of Groundwork.

The Nature of Regeneration

3. It is now being recognised that regeneration is a process. Ideally, regeneration activities aim to reinforce and support each other, creating a critical mass of change, which will become self-supporting. Achieving this requires a long-term commitment.

4. A key change to be brought about through the regeneration process is from apathy to 'can do', empowering people and organisations to initiate and pursue the changes that they want to come about. Long term success and lasting benefits appear to be more likely when people work together in partnership rather than independently pursuing their own goals.

5. Government objectives for regeneration promote this wide-ranging approach. They incorporate thinking about environmental sustainability into regeneration, and cover a wide spectrum of activity, which seeks to integrate action to bring about social, economic and environmental change. Action on social aspects of the agenda is targeted on those in greatest need. Finally, the objectives promote how to do things as well as what to do, laying particular emphasis on partnership ways of working.

The Groundwork Organisation

6. Groundwork claims to be 'the leading environmental regeneration charity in the UK today', with a mission to bring about 'sustainable improvement in the local environment through partnerships and to contribute to economic and social regeneration'. It aspires to work with a wide range of local partners, very much in a 'bottom-up' style rooted in local needs and priorities, and expects to be a catalyst and enabler as much as a doer. The scope of their work includes local environmental renewal, involving local communities with a particular emphasis on the socially excluded, and action/training to better integrate the economy and the environment.

Groundwork and Government Objectives

7. The study has found that, in practice as well as in aspiration, Groundwork is addressing most aspects of the Government's regeneration priorities. There is a particular emphasis on groups who are often not reached through action at the local level, particularly local businesses and the socially excluded. An ability to make connections and to work in a variety of ways adapted to the needs of different parts of the community is a major contributor to the effectiveness of the outputs from Groundwork.

8. There is some evidence that the benefits from Groundwork action and involvement are of lasting rather than short-term benefit. However, in areas with high levels of social depravation and economic disadvantage, it is unlikely that these benefits can be retained without continuing reinvestment.

9. Other advantages that Groundwork brings include change at a significant scale, but achieved in an incremental manner in response to funding availability. In other words it is in the nature of Groundwork that it can operate in a flexible manner which is enabling the Government's complex agenda for regeneration to be translated into practical outputs. Many aspects of Groundwork provide a good model for changing practice amongst its partners, and the evidence is that the good practice is spreading in a manner somewhat akin to osmosis. Much more benefit could be gained from Groundwork if its innovations were better evaluated and a more systematic approach was taken to spreading best practice.

Groundwork Partners

10. The principal partners for Groundwork are local regeneration partnerships or trusts. Groundwork is setting an example with respect to partnership working and community involvement, which is helping to promote better practice amongst these partners.

11. Four reasons stand out why partners value Groundwork. The Trusts are seen as being good at accessing money from a wide range of sources, at working with the community in a committed way, in enabling their partners to achieve their own corporate objectives for partnership working, and at delivering fast, well, reliably and responsively. The support for Groundwork from its partners can reasonably be described as outstanding.

Cost effectiveness of supporting Groundwork

12. With straight comparators not available, only indirect assessment of Groundwork's value for money can be provided.

13. Groundwork is well located with respect to the distribution of need when assessed at a broad spatial level (i.e. in relation to areas defined by local authority boundaries) and is therefore focussing its attention in areas requiring significant action for regeneration. Within these areas it is delivering things that might not otherwise get done, is achieving multiple outputs on projects and programmes, and is working across institutional, social and cultural divides. Groundwork is an innovator and a provider of good example. These attributes are all valuable in the search for effective approaches to regeneration.

14. Groundwork itself perceives its effectiveness to be constrained by its funding regime. To an external observer, the perpetual search for funding keeps the organisation positive and creative. However, it is clear that there are problems for Trusts in securing funding which is not project specific and which enables new project development, extension of partnerships, and staff development. The Trusts feel that their potential is limited by these working arrangements and that reductions in non-project funding would reduce their effectiveness.

New locations and arrangements for Trusts

15. There are locations requiring regeneration where Groundwork is not working. It would be unrealistic, and almost certainly inappropriate, for Groundwork to be working in all of these. Groundwork should only be active where it is wanted by its partners, where there is a real need for regeneration, and where there is an availability of funding (e.g. SRB, Landfill Tax) which will make Trust action secure over a reasonable period of time.

16. Groundwork is considering a 'light greening' approach whereby Groundwork style action for regeneration is delivered without the need for establishing a new local Trust. This may bring advantages. A variety of models are in effect being tested in a number of different ways (e.g. work through trading companies, development work by regional offices) and there will be wide ranging lessons to be learnt from these approaches.

17. Notwithstanding these lessons, it appears there is unlikely to be one model to serve all situations. To be effective, the approach adopted in each area will need to reflect local needs and circumstances. There will be a significant challenge in establishing the right relationships with 'outreach' areas in order to ensure that the full benefits of a working relationship with Groundwork are established.

Conclusions

18. Like any organisation, Groundwork is not perfect and there are other organisations, which can and should deliver regeneration. Positive and effective regeneration is most likely to be served by having a variety of agencies involved, each contributing their own particular strengths.

19. Notwithstanding this, the study concludes that, at their best, Groundwork Trusts are effective agents for change, working in ways, which facilitate regeneration. Without them, the process of regeneration would be much more difficult in many of their local areas. In combination with local partners and with each other, Trusts are able to demonstrate that the challenges of regeneration can be met and that significant change can be achieved.

The First Gloucester was a Third Rate built as part of the great Commonwealth naval programme. She took part in an expedition against the Spanish in the West Indies early in her commission and was heavily involved in the Dutch Wars, gaining six battle honours. After an exceptional career, her end was equally spectacular.She was wrecked off Yarmouth in 1682 on the way to Leith, running aground due to a navigational error. Many of the crew were drowned, but among the survivors were His Royal Highness The Duke of York (laterKing James II) and John Churchill (later the Duke of Marlborough).
