is emptied of water. If you have a machine that empties through a hose into
the sink, take care that the end of the hose does not fall out of position and
so pour water onto the floor. If in a flat, this will flood the flat below.
Services
Gas and Electricity
You make your own arrangements with Southern Gas for gas, and with
Southern Electricity for electricity, and pay them direct.
All quarters with central heating have credit meters for both gas and elec-
tricity. You are not allowed to change these meters for the pre-payment kind
(ie coin-in-the-slot).
Many families quarters get their electricity from the Military Power Station
instead of from Southern Electricity. The cost is the same. The only differ-
ence is that OC ASU sends you the bill, and you pay through your pay
account, except when you leave the Service when you pay in cash.
Before takeover you must sign an agreement for gas with Southern Gas, and
for electricity with Southern Electricity unless your FQ is supplied by the
Military Power Station (your ASA can tell you if it is). Similarly you must
give Southern Gas/Southern Electricity at least 2 days notice of when you
are leaving your FQ so they can read the meter and charge your account.
Make sure that you pay your bills on time. DO NOT ignore warnings from
the Gas or Electricity Companies that they will cut you off if you do not
pay. They may do so. You will then have to pay a reconnection charge and
perhaps legal charges and a deposit against future bills. This could cost you
£50 or more. If you have had a final warning from the Gas or Electricity
Company, and either cannot pay it or are disputing the bill, go and see your
UFO at once.
Repairs to gas and electricity appliances are arranged through your EMO.
The only exception is a suspected gas leak. If you have reported a gas leak
and get a bill for it from Southern Gas pass the bill to your EMO with
details of what happened. But please note that this applies ONLY to gas
leaks or suspected leaks. If you get Southern Gas to do any other work you
will have to pay the bill yourself.41
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Television
If you have a television set you must have a current television licence. The
Services Sound and Vision Corporation (SSVC) have television sets to rent
or sell to service families; their office is near the Middle Hill NAAFI and
their telephone number is Aldershot 24022.
Television – Communal Aerials
Some estates have communal aerials with a socket in each quarter. These
aerials give colour or black and white reception on BBC1, BBC2, ITV
(Thames) and Channel 4. Some of these communal aerials also give recep-
tion on ITV (Southern) as well. If your quarter is connected to a communal
aerial you are NOT allowed to put up an individual outdoor aerial.
Television – Faults in Communal Aerials
If you think that there is a fault in the communal aerial you must first have
the set tested by a television firm to make sure that the set is not at fault.
(You may omit this step if two or more of your neighbours have the same
apparent aerial fault affecting their sets.) You should then report the fault to
your EMO, on a piece of paper, giving your address, saying what the fault
is, and either giving the name of the firm which tested your set and said it
was all right, or giving the address of the two other quarters suffering from
the same aerial fault. If you report the fault correctly and promptly it is
usually put right within one working day.
Private Telephones
If you want a private telephone in your quarter you should apply to British
Telecom, Freephone 150. There is no need to get permission.
If you have a telephone in your quarter you should, when you leave, tell the
Telephone Manager.  At the same time you should, if possible, find out if
your successor in the quarter wants to take on the telephone, and if so ask
the Telephone Manager to leave it for him. This will save the incoming
occupant the installation charge, and may save him a long wait for the tele-
phone.
If you have a telephone in your quarter and move to private accommodation
you are not allowed to have the telephone transferred to your new house.
When you have lived outside the UK for two or more years and, on return,
apply for a telephone to be installed in your home, BT has decided to ask
for a security deposit. Because many service families do live abroad for long
periods during their career the MOD has come to an arrangement with BT
that, so long as the following 3 criteria are met, the need for a deposit will
be waived:
1. A certificate of service identity is to be provided. This will originate
from BT once your application for a telephone is received and be
completed by your CO.
2. You arrange to pay the bill quarterly by direct debit.
3. The MOD will forward overdue bills to service debtors – to ensure
that bills are paid once the family is posted.
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
42 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Refuse Collection
The local authorities collect rubbish once a week. You can find out which
day they come from your neighbours. Any complaints should be actioned
through the EMO.
If there are items which will not go into the rubbish container stack them
neatly, in cardboard boxes, alongside the container. IT IS IMPORTANT
THAT NO FOOD OR UNHYGIENIC MATERIAL IS PUT IN THE CARD-
BOARD BOXES.
When the dustmen empty your container or plastic liner holder they leave an
empty sack. They may leave an extra sack if you ask them.
The dustmen will not take away large items like broken prams, bicycles etc.
You should take such items to the official tip, details of which are shown on
the following pages. If you cannot do this contact your EMO for help.
You can get rid of unwanted cars/Caravans etc through firms of car break-
ers. You should make arrangements through the RMP (Ext 2365) or MOD
Police (Ext 2542 or 2544). Do not just abandon or dump the car. This is an
offence under the military bye-laws, and disciplinary action is taken against
offenders. It is also an offence under statute law and offenders can be 
prosecuted.
Occupants Modifications
Occupants Modifications to Quarters
If you wish to make any structural alterations to your quarter, at your own
expense, such as installing a gas or fixed electric fire, or putting in extra
power points, then you must first get permission from the SAM, on a special
form (4 copies). Your unit can show you the Garrison Order about this,
which is No 22 (FQs).
Satellite Dishes
Occupants wishing to fit satellite dishes should do so on special occupants’
modifications forms obtainable through DHE SAM.
The dishes should conform to regulations which state that only one antenna
may be fitted and must be no bigger than 90 cm in diameter. The antenna
must not be higher than the highest point of the roof.
Miscellaneous
Visitors
If you occupy an MSQ and wish to have a visitor to stay for a period
exceeding four weeks, you must request permission from your CO. If you
wish to have a dependent relative to live with you, this request must be
passed through your unit to the DHE. No additional furniture etc may be
issued on account of visitors or dependent relatives and when permission is
given for a dependent relative to live with you, it carries no entitlement to a
larger quarter. Occupants are not allowed to take in lodgers or paying
guests.43
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Traders
No one is allowed to sell goods or ask for custom in FQ estates unless they
have a pass, with photograph, signed by the DHE office. You are advised
not to buy goods from, nor enter into insurance or HP contracts with, any
traders in the FQ estates unless they have a pass. If unauthorised traders
approach you, please report them (with vehicle number if possible) to the
RMP information room (Ext 3393), or the MOD Police (Ext 2542 or 2544).
Home Security
Please make every effort to discourage theft and vandalism. Make sure that
your quarter is secure when you go out. Check the credentials of any visitor
you do not know; if they have any official business in your quarter they
should be carrying a pass. Do not hesitate to ask to see the pass. Report any
theft, vandalism or untoward incident to the civil or MOD Police, or to
your EMO. See under Home Security in the Occupants’ Reference Section
for more details.
Insurance of Personal Effects
You are strongly advised to take out an insurance policy on your personal
property and the MOD accommodation stores in your quarter, especially
against loss or damage caused by burst pipes, fire or theft. (See the
Classified Index of Advertisers.) Where insurance companies will not insure
a quarter because the security arrangements of the quarter do not meet their
requirements, application can be made to the DHE for the locks to be modi-
fied.
Should damage to accommodation stores occur due to fire or flood, and
your carelessness caused the damage, you will be presented with a bill. A
simple ‘All Risks’ insurance policy can be effected. There is such a policy
available that covers HM Forces effects (as well as personal effects) which
has an optional liability extension. This would cover any bill raised by a
Service authority for accidental damage up to £500. Approximate cost is
£10 per annum.
Details can be obtained from any reputable insurance broker and ASAs can
advise on the value of accommodation stores in any quarter.
Clothes Drying
Attaching clothes lines to external fittings such as drainpipes, facia board,
etc is dangerous and is not permitted. Care should be taken with expanding
clothes airers which can collapse with the weight of clothes and, if wrongly
assembled, can be dangerous to children.
Pets
Dogs in Families Quarters. As a result of the ‘dog survey’ the Garrison
Standing Order referring to dogs has been rewritten and all dogs within
Deepcut Garrison must now be registered with the DHE Area Office ABRO.
A Code of Conduct for dog owners in the Garrison has been produced and
can be found below.
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
44 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
It has been decided that a maximum of one dog may be kept in a flat
(including ground floor) and up to two dogs in a house. Permission to
exceed these numbers will only be granted in exceptional cases by the DHE
Area Manager. Registration forms can be obtained from your Unit Families
Office, EMO or from DHE Offices at the Connaught Centre and Middle
Hill.
If you have not already done so please register your dog now. If you have
any queries please ring Aldershot Mil 8348 or Civ 01483 798348.
Code of Conduct
1. Occupants are to limit the number of dogs in a FQ as follows: • Flat
occupants (including the ground floor): one dog. • House occupants:
two dogs.
2. Occupants are not to exceed this number without permission (which
will only be given in exceptional circumstances).
3. Dogs are to be well cared for in every way and owners are to do as
much as possible to ensure they do not cause a nuisance to their
neighbours.
4. Dogs are not to be allowed to foul the stairwells and immediate sur-
rounds of flats. Owners are however to clear up if their dog fouls on
the estate and dispose of it hygienically. This is absolutely essential so
that the grassed area or pavements do not look an eyesore or more
importantly cause a health hazard for children. 
5. Dogs are to be on a lead whenever they are within the families
quarter estate. If dogs need free range exercise they should be taken to
appropriate areas out side the estate.
6. Dog owners must respond positively when told by a neighbour that
their dog is causing a nuisance and do all they can to improve the sit-
uation.
7. Any damage caused to the house or garden by the dog is to be made
good by the owners prior to handover.
8. Dogs are to wear a collar tag bearing the owner’s name, address and
telephone number when outside the FQ.
9. Dogs that cause a nuisance. Dogs that persistently cause a nuisance to
neighbours or owners who do not abide by this code will have the
privilege of being able to keep a dog in an FQ withdrawn.
10. For stray dogs contact the Dog Warden, Rushmoor Borough
Council. Tel: 01252 398166.
Cats. If on posting you are unable to find a suitable home for your pet cat,
the Cats Protection League will guarantee to look after your pet and to find
it another suitable home. This way is preferable to leaving the cat to fend
for itself or passing it onto neighbours who may, themselves, be posted
shortly after your departure. The Cats Protection League can be contacted
as follows:
Mrs R Young Frensham 825-3381 Mrs S Delima Aldershot 21385
Mrs S Warren Aldershot 28170
Names of veterinary surgeons may be found in the Index of Advertisers at
the end of this Guide.45
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Accommodation Services Matters
Furnishing
It is the task of the ASU to provide and maintain the furniture in your
quarter. You should remember that the items, both in quantity and quality,
which are issued are authorised by the MOD and have been agreed for all
three Services. A separate inventory is maintained for each quarter and your
copy is handed to you when you take over your quarter; you should keep it
in a safe place.
Exchanges
The ASU runs a system of exchange for FQ occupants. You should contact
your ASU to arrange for exchange of items.
The Wharf Scheme
If you have furniture of your own you may wish to have some of the Army
furniture removed. This is called the Wharf Scheme and can be arranged
when you move into the FQ. Prior notification should be given when your
Application for Families Quarters (AFA1132) is submitted.
The wharfing requirements of occupants are normally made known on the
Annex to AFA1132 in advance of any move to a new station. When these
are received at the ASU (for incoming occupants) arrangements will be made
to adjust furniture holdings in FQs to meet the new occupants’ require-
ments. The Scheme does not apply to the following:
(i) Carpets and curtains. (ii) Plug-in electrical equipment.
(iii) Safety equipment. (iv) Dustbins. (v) Fireguards.
(vi) Garden equipment.
Due to limitations of both labour and transport there may, at times, be
delays between time of request for wharf and the actual removal of furni-
ture.
You may wharf once only during a 3 year tour of duty. Once items have
been wharfed they cannot be rewharfed (reissued to your FQ) during your
stay in the quarter, except in exceptional circumstances.
Part Furnished Rate
A part furnished rate for families quarters was approved by the Armed
Forces Pay Review Body (AFPRB) and introduced in 1992. When a Part
Furnished Quarter is occupied the appropriate part furnished quartering
charge will apply. To qualify for the part furnished rate you must under-
draw or wharf furnishings to a total value of 50% or more of your entitle-
ment of families quarter furnishings. Contact your ASA for further details
relating to the calculation of the 50% requirement.
Unfurnished FQs in the UK
Definition. An unfurnished families quarter is one from which all accommo-
dation stores have normally been removed except for the following items:
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
46 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
a. Carpet and curtains. b. Refrigerators (where issued).
c. Cooker. d. Dustbins (when issued by ASU). e. Domestic vacuum
cleaners.
f. Portable heater (when issued). g. Fire extinguishers. h. Fire guards.
i. Any safety equipment issued (smoke detectors etc).
In effect this means that no other accommodation stores are supplied and no
provisioning action is made for this unfurnished quarter during the occu-
pancy of the tenant requesting the Wharf. 
Conditions of Eligibility
Any Serviceman/woman who is entitled to a families quarter in the UK may
opt for that quarter to be unfurnished without any pre-conditions of service.
Quartering Charges. When an unfurnished FQ is occupied the appropriate
charge will apply.
Storage and Removal Expenses. The quantities of furniture which may be
conveyed at public expense on moves to or from an unfurnished residence
are given in Chptr 7 of Regulations for Army Allowances and Charges
(Army Code No10). This also shows the quantities of furniture which may
be stored at public expense when an officer/soldier is posted overseas and is
accompanied by his family, subject to the provisions of Sect 3, Chptr 7 of
Regulations for Army Allowances and Charges.
Soft Furnishings
There is a fixed and limited amount of money available each year to buy
soft furnishings for families quarters. Carpets, curtains, covers and blankets
can be very expensive, as you will know if you have bought your own.
Please look after all the items in your quarter as if they were your own and
help to avoid the shortages which result from unfair wear and damage.
Cleaning and Washing Soft Furnishings
You are responsible for washing or dry cleaning the following articles:–
Sheets, pillow slips, blankets, bedspreads, underlays, rugs, mats, loose covers
and curtains. Mattresses and pillows are remade at public expense when
they become unserviceable due to fair wear and tear, but when this is neces-
sary through neglect the cost will be charged to the occupant. Carpets are
cleaned at public expense every 3 years, or on change of occupancy if
required. If you consider additional cleaning necessary, consult your ASA.47
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Married Accompanied
Defence Housing Executive (DHE)
The DHE is responsible for managing and maintaining all families accom-
modation on behalf of the housing Group in England, Scotland and Wales.
The DHE area office, which is the address for all Married Quarter applica-
tions, is at:
DHE, Aldershot Area Office D, Building 3, The ABRO Site, Ordnance
Road, Aldershot, Hants  GU11 2AA.
The Estate Office is located at Pirbright and the telephone number for the
DHE Sub Area Manager (SAM) Moira Waterston is on 01483 798348. The
address for the DHE local office is:
Sub Area A, Pirbright and Estate Office, Alexander Barracks, Pirbright,
Brookwood, Woking, Surrey  GU24 0QQ.
Officers and other ranks Families Quarters areas are located in Deepcut,
Pirbright and Mytchett.
Letting Agencies
Deepcut
Ravenswood Pilgrims Ltd., 132 Upper Chobham Road, Camberley
Tel: 01276 27119

Avenue, Camberley
Tel: 01276 21847

Howard Morley & Sons, 276 High Street, Guildford
Tel: 01483 575304

Tel: 01932 348620
See Yellow Pages for other Letting Agencies.
Stepping Stone Homes
Please see Army Welfare Service for referrals.
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
48 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
R E N D
T S
FURNITURE CENTRE
“You serve us,
we want to serve you”
Hundreds of beds and mattresses 
in stock at all times
We are your local Bedroom Specialist
FREE LOCAL DELIVERY SERVICE
AND WE TAKE AWAY YOUR OLD BED
Call at our showrooms at:

Also at Aldershot

Large Private Car Park at Rear

Hampshire  GU35 9AR49
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
1 Royal Anglians-Pirbright during the
Firefighters strike.
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
50 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Joint Service Housing
Advice Office
Why JSHAO was established
The Joint Service Housing Advice Office (JSHAO) was set up to provide
Service personnel and their families with information and advice on the
increasingly complex range of housing options.
The role of the JSHAO is to provide a focal point for housing information
and advice to all Service personnel and their families, in particular those
about to return to civilian life, and to ex-service personnel who are still in
Service Families’ Accommodation.
Local Authority Housing Information
JSHAO has compiled a comprehensive computer database which can
provide information on the housing policy and practice of each Local
Authority in England, Wales and Scotland. In particular it identifies their
policy in dealing with ex-regulars.
Housing Association opportunities
Housing Associations (HAs) are taking an increasingly significant role in the
provision of public sector housing. Some HAs specialise in the rental needs
of single people as well as family housing. JSHAO can provide contact
addresses for HAs throughout the UK.
MOD Nomination Scheme
MOD has established a referral scheme with Housing Associations to
provide rented accommodation for people coming out of the Services. The
Scheme is based on the sale of surplus families quarters and operates in
about 200 locations in England & Scotland (local connections are not
usually required). Service leavers (whether married or single) and 
separated partners occupying quarters as irregular occupants can apply.
Contact JSHAO for more details.51
DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
Shared Ownership
A number of housing associations build or modernise property for sale
under this government funded scheme. Initially, you buy a part of a property
offered for sale by a housing association, and rent the part you do not own.
Eventually, you can buy more shares until you own the property outright. If
you cannot afford to get a large enough mortgage to buy in the usual way,
shared ownership may be for you. 
Homebuy
This scheme is operated by selected Registered Social Landlords (RSL’s) in
England and Wales.
If you qualify for Homebuy you will need to contribute 75% of the pur-
chase price of the home through a mortgage and/or personal savings. The
RSL will lend you the remaining 25% as an interest free Equity loan. There
are no monthly payments on this loan. Instead, you repay it when you sell
the home. At that point you pay the RSL 25% of what the property is sold
for.  In Wales the RSL’s lend 30% of the initial value.
Private Sector House Rental & Purchase
JSHAO has various details on Private Sector options. We stock booklets on
house purchase produced by the Council of Mortgage Lenders which
contain useful information about the steps to follow when buying a house
and the pitfalls to avoid. We also have a comprehensive list of Estate Agents
and Residential Letting Agents. This information is especially useful to per-
sonnel serving abroad as it provides the opportunity to contact agents in the
UK before repatriation.
Long Service Advance of Pay Scheme
This is a Tri-service scheme to assist personnel in house purchase. There
are a number of basic criteria for eligibility and conditions which apply to
you and the property. Full details of the scheme should be available within
units (or in summary from JSHAO). Do not commit yourself to buying a
property until you receive confirmation of your eligibility from the Tri-
Service LSAP Centre.
Commercial Initiatives
A number of commercial organisations such as Banks, Building Societies,
Builders, Surveyors etc. put together special schemes and packages for
Service personnel. For current details contact the JSHAO.
Annington Homes, the purchaser of the FQ Estate, offer surplus Families
Quarters for sale to the general public. They often offer Service persons a
discount based upon length of service.
Self Build
A small number of Service personnel will consider the possibility of building
Housing Information & ServicesHousing Information & Services
52 DEEPCUT GARRISON 2003
or managing the building of their own house. Building your own house can
save a substantial amount of the cost of buying a new house from a tradi-
tional builder. Want to find out more? Contact JSHAO.
JSHAO Magazine
JSHAO produce a monthly magazine called ‘Housing Matters’. Copies are
available at units, HIVEs, RRC’s etc. Additional copies may be obtained
through JSHAO.
SSAFA Forces Help’s Housing Advisory Service
Once you leave the Forces and/or MOD accommodation, you can still get
information, help and advice with your housing problems from SSAFA
Forces Help. Contact their Housing Officer (Information) c/o JSHAO or
ring 01722 436400. NB: This service is also available to your dependants
and wider family (parents, etc.) whilst you are still serving.
Housing Associations with Service Links
Places for People is one of the largest Housing Associations in the country
managing over 38,000 properties. They have a specific commitment to
helping service leavers by aiming to allocate a proportion of the annual
vacancies in their rental stock to ex-regulars. They are also committed to
giving favourable consideration to Service leavers who are first-time buyers
and are interested in low-cost home ownership developments. Home
Housing Group also has strong links with JSHAO. Currently JSHAO has a
large nomination arrangement with the group.
SPACES
Single Persons Accommodation Centre for the Ex-Services
SPACES is designed to help single ex-regulars to find appropriate accommo-
dation when they leave the Service. Through this service the project reduces
the likelihood of ex-services personnel becoming homeless or sleeping rough
after discharge.
The project is based within the Resettlement Welfare complex at Catterick,
North Yorkshire.  It provides an accommodation placement service for
single personnel being discharged from all three Services. Run by English
Churches Housing Group in partnership with the MOD, who fund the
project.
Tel: 01748 833 797, Fax: 01748 835774, Catterick Mil: (94731) 2940.
How Can I Get More Information On These Options?
Joint Service Housing Advice Office, HQ LAND, Erskine Barracks, Wilton,
Salisbury, Wilts SP2 0AG. Tel: 01722 436575  Fax: 01722 436577.
Email: jshao@hqland.army.mod.uk
JSHAO online: www.army/mod/uk/jshao

Foreign & Commonwealth Office Press Releases

















Back to Full Graphics


















'WE MUST STOP PROLIFERATION,' SAYS MIKE O'BRIEN


(10/02/03)










Speaking to several hundred members of the Union of Muslim Students at a meeting held at the School of Oriental and African Studies (University of London) Mike O’Brien, Foreign Office Minister, said:



‘I do not want war, but we must ensure that Saddam Hussein is disarmed. We should support the United Nations resolution which was unanimously agreed. If we fail to stop Saddam developing weapons of mass destruction, other dictators will conclude that UN resolutions can be ignored, international law will not be enforced and other countries can develop similar weapons. WMD in the hands of a large number of countries, sometimes run by tyrants, with a lack of effective controls, would make the world a much more dangerous place. We must stop proliferation.



‘I hope Saddam will comply with the UN resolution and disarm peacefully. If we disarm Saddam the message will be, UN resolutions matter, international law will be enforced, and other dictators will get the message that they cannot proliferate nuclear, chemical and biological weapons with impunity.’



On suggestions that this was a war on Islam, Mike O’Brien said:



‘With two million Muslims living in Britain the idea that we would declare war on our own people is absurd. Islam is a mainstream British faith and adds to the richness of our society.



‘In Kosovo, Britain helped stopped Milosevic’s ethnic cleansing of Kosovo Albanians who are Muslims. In Afghanistan, which I visited recently, we have been welcomed by Muslims as removing the yoke of Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Today Afghanistan is a Muslim country with three million children in schools, half of these are girls - something unthinkable under the Taliban. Neither of these conflicts involved oil or material gains for us. Yet we got involved because it was the right thing to do. Muslims benefited in both instances, due to our intervention.’



To those who say ‘it’s all about oil’ Mike O’Brien replied:



‘Oil is an internationally traded commodity. If we wanted to buy Iraqi oil we could just cut a deal with Saddam today. He would be happy to sell oil to finance his building of WMD. Britain does not import oil from Iraq and we don’t need to. The US has made it clear that it has no plans to seize Iraq’s oil. Iraqi oil should belong to the Iraqi people.



‘In fact, Saddam Hussein has creamed off 10% of oil revenues from the Oil for Food programme to rob his people of vital goods and spend some money on luxuries and components for WMD.’

Justice system to engage with communities

The criminal justice system of the future should be about local justice and engagement with the community, according to Home Secretary David Blunkett.

The Home Secretary said that social order and the development of a just society must grow from the bottom up, rather then being imposed from above:

"The criminal justice system has to be firmly rooted in, and reflect, the community it serves to have people's trust. While we are making good progress in improving the level of public confidence in the criminal justice system, we still have a way to go."

Speaking ahead of a speech to Community Service Volunteers, he suggested that local visibility of police leaders and others responsible for tackling crime and disorder should be increased:

"I am interested in exploring options for strengthening local accountability and engagement, such as whether police authorities have a directly elected element or even be entirely elected?"

He said that despite the Police having a highly visible role in society and communities, research showed the public had little understanding of just how the service was accountable.

"I am calling on the police, police authorities, Crime and Disorder Reduction Partnerships and others who care about policing in this country to join in the debate on how past good work can be built on to clarify and strengthen community involvement and accountability. It is difficult to engage and reassure people if they do not know who they are being policed by and how to have their say."

He added that the Attorney General is looking at ways to boost the profile and widen the role of local senior public prosecutors. The goal is to generate the sort of status they have in the US, and become much more visible to the communities they serve. 

The Government's aim should be a society in which individuals and their families are empowered, enabled and supported to take part as active citizens, Mr Blunkett said. He added:

"In practice this means spreading assets across society, reforming the state and our public services so that they facilitate community involvement and help individuals to help themselves, and strengthening accountability and engagement with key services."

The Home Secretary also announced:

	a further ?4 million will be available to the Adventure Capital Fund - a new fund which supports a range of projects such as ensuring community safety to waste composting.
	?1 million for a new Centre for Active Citizenship to examine future policy development. The Centre will operate as a consortium of organisations, university departments and think tanks

		Oakum - Oyster

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					








  	
        'Oakum' to
        'Oyster'

      
	
 OAKUM	 
Unravelled tarred rope used for packing seams and caulking. A prisoner in the ship's cells is required to pick two pounds of tarred hemp (or 6 lbs of tarred sisal) into oakum daily, Sundays excepted the material to be weighed in his presence morning and evening. 
      
	
 OFF	
        Off and On
Old naval expression meaning occasionally. The expression originally denoted keeping close to the shore by sailing off and on it.
      
	
 OFFICER 
      	
        Officer Strength
At the end of the 1939/45 war, naval officers were about 14%
        R.N., 12% R.N.R. and 74% R.N.V.R.
      
	
 OFFING	
        In the Offing
Old naval expression meaning near at hand; originally it meant a distance from the shore - i.e., towards the horizon.
      
	
 OGGIN 
      	 
The Oggin
Modern sailors' slang for the sea; it is said to be derived from Hogwash, though some assert that it comes from a mispronouncement of Ocean. Synonyms are The Ditch, The Pond, The Drink, all three of which words are used by officers more often than
Oggin. 
      
	
 OGILVY 
      	 
The Ogilvy Medal
This medal was instituted in 1912 in memory of Captain F.C.A. Ogilvy who died on 18th December, 1909, from typhoid fever while in command of H.M.S. NATAL. The dividends from a sum of money given by officers of the Navy and certain friends and relatives are employed in providing a medal which is awarded annually, at the discretion of the Admiralty, to the officer who takes first place in the examination to quality for Lieutenant (TAS). Any balance that remains may be handed over to the winner of the medal. 
      
	
 OIL 
      	 
 Oil Fuel
H.M.S. CRICKET was the first
H.M. ship to be designed and built for oil burnings; she was launched in 1906, as one of five "Insect" class coastal destroyers, later reclassified as Torpedo Boats. Her displacement was 225 tons and her engines developed 3750
h.p.

 The first British battleship KING EDWARD VII burned both coal and oil in 1905; H.M.S. QUEEN ELIZABETH (launched 1913) was the first British battleship to be designed and built to burn oil fuel only.  
      

	
 OILY 
      	 
Oily Wads

Naval nickname for the first British oil-burning torpedo boats (Nos. 1-36).
	
 OLD 
      	
        The Old Man
Naval slang name for the Captain or Admiral. It is an expression borrowed from the Merchant Navy.
	
 OLERON 
      	
        The Laws of Oleron
The Laws of Oleron were the first code of laws for naval service; from them has descended the Naval Discipline Act of today. The Laws seem to have been instituted in Castile by King Alphonso X in the XIII century derived from the code founded in the republic of Rhodes and adopted by the Romans and other maritime powers of the Mediterranean. King Richard Coeur de Lion introduced these laws into Great Britain, having met them during the Crusades where the forces included a strong contingent from the island of
        Oleron. The Laws were undoubtedly harsh - as they probably needed to be in their day; among them appears. "If a robber be convicted of theft, boiling pitch shall be poured over his head and a shower of feathers shaken over to mark him"; a murderer was to be tied to his victim's corpse and buried alive with it, either in land or in the sea. See the introduction to the Admiralty Memorandum on Court-Martial Procedure -
        B.R. 11/1954.
	
 OPPO 
      	 
Naval slang - short for opposite number - for the person doing the same job as one's self in another watch or ship. In the former case, since you relieved each other (in the old two-watch days), it behoved you to become friends; thus the word Oppo came to mean Chum. On a two-watch
watchbill, the name of a man's 'opposite number' in the other watch was shewn against his own name in the opposite column.
	
 OSBORNE 
      	
        Royal Naval College, Osbourne
Called for by the Selborne Scheme the college was built at Osborne House (Isle of Wight) on the site of the old stables. It was opened in September, 1903, well within a year of its inception. It was utilitarian rather than comfortable.
 Cadet entry at 12? started under the Selborne Scheme and ran till 1913; this gave cadets 2 years at Osborne followed by 2 years at Dartmouth. In 1913 this was changed to 1 year at Osborne and 3 years at Dartmouth. The R.N. College, Osborne, finally closed down in 1923; its ship-name had been H.M.S. RACER.
      

	
 OUTSIDE 
      	 
Outside-Walkee
Chinese pidgin-english for a Paddle steamer: a screw ship is an
"Inside-walkee" ship.
	
 OVERCOAT	
        Overcoat : Oilskin : Raincoat
Until 1954 an overcoat was given to all new entries into the Navy and also an oilskin to men dressed as seamen (raincoat to men dressed in 'force-&-aft' rig). On 1st January, 1955, the issue of overcoats and oilskins was stopped, a double-breasted blue raincoat, with detachable warm lining, being issued instead to all new entries. The overcoat remains an optional item of kit; the oilskin is to disappear by April, 1957. Overcoats may be supplied on loan to ratings for wear on ceremonial occasions in the U.K. Foul weather wear will continue to be issued on loan to men whose duties make this necessary.
      
	
OWNER 
      	
        The Owner
Naval slang name for the Commanding Officer - much more used in the Merchant Navy (whence the
        R.N. borrowed it) than in the R.N.
      
	
 OYSTER 
      	
 Bombay Oyster
A old maritime name for a laxative draught consisting of a double dose of caster oil in a glass of milk; a more modern name for such a laxative would be
"elephant-rouser".
Prairie-Oyster
A morning-after reviver composed of port wine, worcester sauce, red pepper, mustard and the unbroken yolk of an egg.

	Submariners in ride for hope



Sailors from the Devonport-based submarine HMS Talent have used pedal power to raise money for Hope House hospice for children in Shropshire



Starting out from Land’s End in Cornwall the team of seven riders took turns to ride the 350 miles to the hospice in Oswestry via the submarine’s affiliated town of Shrewsbury, taking just three days to complete their challenge.  Despite a brief detour to bike suppliers for running repairs, the team managed to cover 120 miles on the first day alone.  



On arrival at Hope House the team presented a cheque to the hospice for £1,000 raised by members of HMS Talent’s ship’s company through various fund-raising events including a sponsored Bungee Jump.  The team also supported the hospice’s Fun Day by manning some of the attractions raising a further £320.



Team leader Chief Petty Officer Nigel Bouckley said:  “We felt it was an ideal opportunity to get the guys out exercising and at the same time raise money for Hope House.”



HMS Talent is currently undergoing a refit at Devonport Naval Base in Plymouth.

Foreign & Commonwealth Office UK Position on the Status of Jerusalem















Back to Full Graphics


























UK Position on the Status of Jerusalem
























	
Q: 
	

What is the Government's position on Jerusalem?


	
A: 
	

In line with the Declaration of Principles of 13 September 1993 and the Interim Agreement of 28 September 1995, both agreed by Israel and the PLO, the Government regards the status of Jerusalem as still to be determined in permanent status negotiations between the parties. Pending agreement, we recognise de facto Israeli control of West Jerusalem but consider East Jerusalem to be occupied territory. We recognise no sovereignty over the city.


Jerusalem has a unique religious and cultural importance for Christians, Jews and Muslims, and we attach great importance to ensuring access to Jerusalem and freedom of worship there for those of all faiths.

Three meals a day we supply to the crew.

You say “Is that all you do on that boat.”

You hear an alarm, as the fire bell rings.

The shout fire, fire, fire, through the ship sings.

We go to our posts, first aid and HQ.

The exercise is over, and back to work we go.

	PRESS BRIEFING: 11AM WEDNESDAY 26 MAY 2004 
 
IRAQ

Asked if the Prime Minister was going to the United Nations next week the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman (PMOS) told journalists that he had nothing further to add to yesterday's answer but it was important to bear in mind that we were still awaiting the report by Lakhdar Brahimi, due at the end of the month, which would set out the next stage of developments in Iraq. The PMOS reiterated that even though events were picking up momentum as 30 June approached it was still important to take the process step by step. 


 


Asked if there was a difference between the Government and Colin Powell over who would command troops after 30 June, the PMOS responded that there absolutely was not. It was important to be clear about what the draft UN Resolution said and there were two key words. One was "consent" and the other was "co-ordination". As Colin Powell had himself said 10 days ago if the Iraqi Interim Government wanted the multi-national force to leave, then it would leave, that was what consent meant. President Bush had underlined that full sovereignty meant full sovereignty as the PM had reflected yesterday. The Prime Minister had also reflected that there was a two level split over command: one was at the strategic level and the other the operational level. That split was a division that we in this country were very familiar with. It was a division that had operated in Northern Ireland for 30 years for example and in other areas where coalitions had worked as partners such as Bosnia, Afghanistan and Sierra Leone. The division was clear. If you were at the wrong end of a rocket-propelled grenade now you didn't have to phone a committee to ask how to respond. After 30 June whether you were British, American, Iraqi, Dutch or any other coalition member for that matter this would still be true.  Operational control would remain at the level of local decision making. US commanders would be in control of US troops. British commanders would remain in charge of British troops and Iraqi commanders would be in charge of Iraqi troops. What would change, as President Bush had said, was that after 30 June the CPA would disappear and not be replaced, instead there would be the Iraqi Interim Government. It would have a mechanism such as a national security committee that would agree and coordinate with the multinational force the broad strategic approach to security. It would decide the profile and balance of forces in particular areas. The change after 30 June would be that the Iraqi Interim Government would work in close coordination with the multinational force to decide these strategic issues. 


 


Questioned as to how the attack on Falluja would be have been classified, the PMOS said that the Prime Minister had made his view absolutely clear in his press conference yesterday that it was a strategic decision. However once an operation began then the operational control was at the level of the local commander. The PMOS again drew attention to the wording in the resolution that recognised the importance of the consent of the sovereign government for the presence of the multinational force and the close coordination of the multinational force and the Interim Government. It was true that there were still technical arrangements that would have to be made, but that was true of any operation. What the resolution could not do was set out in black and white the precise arrangements for every eventuality and it was totally unrealistic to expect it to do so. What it did do however was set out very clearly the principles by which everyone would operate: consent by the Iraqi Government, and coordination between it and the multinational force.


 


Asked about the composition of the national security committee mechanism the PMOS said that the precise make up of the mechanism was still being finalised and therefore yet to be decided. It would also have to be agreed by the incoming Interim Government, but what we may have was an Iraqi National Security Council that met with and coordinated security with the multinational force. If the Iraqis did not want a particular operation then, as the Prime Minister had said yesterday, they could of course say no. Equally however the Iraqis could not ask the multinational force to carry out an operation it did not believe to be right or believed too dangerous, it worked both ways. Asked if the veto applied to US troops the PMOS pointed out that that was the position for the multinational force. In response to further questioning the PMOS suggested that people needed to get away from the idea that the multinational force would have a different agenda from the Iraqi Interim Government. They would be precisely the same, namely stability and to increase the capacity of Iraqi security forces to take on responsibility as quickly as possible. The two sides shared the same goals and would therefore work out the best way of achieving those goals. Practical issues would come up and be debated and discussed, but practical issues would be resolved through practical arrangements rather than trying to find some ideological divide which was not there. The aim was to build on our experience and form the strongest ever level of cooperation between a sovereign Iraqi government and a coalition force, but as Colin Powell said we would only stay as long the Iraqis wanted us to. There would always be practical issues but the principles of consent and coordination were there in black and white in the UN resolution.


In response to the suggestion that this had still not reconciled Colin Powell's comments yesterday on Iraqi sovereignty and US troops with the Prime Minister's the PMOS read out what Colin Powell had said, "They are sovereign. We are there at their consent, with their consent." Colin Powell had further said, "U.S. forces remain under U.S. command and will do what is necessary to protect themselves." The PMOS reiterated our agreement with this point that if an agreed operation was started then of course you finished that operation. Operational control meant operational control and that was a concept everyone was deeply familiar with in this country and there was no disagreement with that. The key question was the strategic decisions about the balance of forces, the kinds of operation taken, the profiles, the balance between the growing capacity of the Iraqis and the role of the multinational force.


Asked whether more British troops would not be sent till after 10 June the PMOS reminded journalists that a decision would be taken whenever the various elements involved had been taken into account and not based on any artificial deadlines.


PRIME MINISTER


 

Asked if he agreed with the Deputy Prime Minister that it was a question of if rather than when the Prime Minister fights the next election the PMOS said that the Prime Minister had set out his view of this yesterday at his press conference and as such he had nothing further to add.


 


DAVID HILL


Asked if the Prime Minister agreed with David Hill's alleged comments about the French airport disaster as reported in the press the PMOS told journalists that David had explained in his statement to the Daily Mail that his comment had been flippant and that this was where the matter should be left. Asked if David Hill would be apologising to the families of those who had died the PMOS said that as David had said in his statement as anyone who knows him would recognise that the last thing he would want was to cause offence to anyone. That was not his intention.

Microsoft Word - 031212 
Speech to National Housing Federation Annual 
Conference 
Check Against Delivery 
Richard, thanks for that warm welcome. It's great to be back here in the International Conference 
Centre in the heart of Birmingham.  
What a great European city this is! Go and take a look! It's been transformed from a city of the motor 
car to a city for people. It's now got a heart.  
And it's got the wow factor - with great new architecture, from Brindleyplace to the new Bullring. 
They're reusing the canals, the warehouses, the workshops - the old wasting assets brought back to life 
to serve the community. 
It was here that we held the successful Urban Summit 2 years ago - where I set out the Government's 
new agenda for housing and sustainable communities. At Manchester, next year, we are holding an 
international Sustainable Communities Summit, which will spell out our ideas for the future.  
Many of you had a big part to play in shaping these new agendas and driving them forward. You've 
been delivering the decent homes, building more affordable homes, helping the homeless and the 
vulnerable, tackling low demand, providing more homes for key workers. 
Can I congratulate the housing associations and the Housing Corporation for what you've done. 
When I started this job back in 1997, I remember meeting Sir Brian Pearce and his team from the 
Housing Corporation. They spoke to me in some weird housing language.  
They told me that the TCI's too small. The HIP needs to be bigger. The RTB and the RTA are 
reducing our stock. And the ADP is not enough. Of course I said. Yes. Exactly. Precisely. And I said 
what about the SC? There's no SC!  
No sustainable communities! 
Well, now I see the Federation are on board for SC! 
But housing's not about jargon - it's about creating sustainable communities: 
null mixed communities,  
null prosperous communities,  
null cleaner, safer, greener communities  
null sustainable communities in places where people want to live.  
That's what we're about.  That's why we're here. That's why we're in business together. In business for 
neighbourhoods. 
It's not always been like that.  
Don't forget the mess we inherited in 1997: 
null Boom bust economics. 
null A £19 billion backlog of housing repairs.  
null Over 2 million homes in the social sector failing to meet a decent standard. 
null Capital spending on housing cut in half. 
1 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
null House building at its lowest level for 70 years. 
null More families in bed and breakfast. 
null Over a million council houses sold off at knockdown prices, costing us billions in subsidy 
And top it off with the Housing Minister, Sir George Young, with his infamous complaint about 
tripping over rough sleepers on his way from the opera.  
That's the legacy we inherited.  
A Government policy which was against social housing. It meant - 
null Fewer houses in the public sector 
null Higher rents 
null More on housing benefit  
null More homelessness 
null More repossessions and negative equity.  
null And ever more revenue subsidy. 
In the first 2 years, we adopted the Tory Government's spending plans.  
We had to make tough decisions because we had to get economic stability, we had to get the national 
debt down, and we had to get the public finances right. 
Spending was tight, but we did have the capital receipts which weren't being used for housing. You 
only had to see the state of the housing stock to see that repairs were urgently needed. 5 million 
people were living in substandard homes in the public sector.  
That's why we launched our decent homes programme and it's been a huge success. We've invested 
over £13 billion of public money on decent homes.  
Through the transfer programme, you've levered in another £5 billion of private money. That's a total 
of £18 billion invested in our decent homes programme. You've done a great job and thanks for that.  
As you know we also introduced ALMOs and the housing PFI scheme.  
They've all got a part to play.  
We've shown that public private partnerships work.  
In fact, we've cut the number of non-decent homes by over a million.  
They may not be new houses, but they're new homes to the people who live in them.  
650,000 homes fitted with new central heating, 240,000 new kitchens and 180,000 new bathrooms. 
Those are the figures, but you only realise the true impact if you visit people like Molly, who I went 
to see in her council house in West London.  
I was expecting to see a traditional bathroom- but she now had a specially converted wetroom which 
allowed her disabled husband, Joe, to have a bath in his disabled chair, in his own home. Before that, 
he had to go to the centre down the road.  
That's the difference a decent home has made to him and Molly. 
But we've still got a lot of work to do to make every social home decent by 2010. It's an ambitious 
target. We've made the money available - including a new £180 million gap funding scheme to 
support transfers where the homes have negative value. 
2 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
It's a double challenge. You've got to repair the stock you have and help improve homes transferred 
from local authorities.  
Thanks for the progress you're already making and I've every confidence that together we will meet 
the target.  
That was the first phase of our programme, and it was from there that we started to develop the 
Sustainable Communities Plan. 
We needed a strategy that addressed the different housing problems in different regions:  
null high demand in the South,  
null low demand in the North,  
null and the need for sustainable communities rather than housing estates. 
We needed to tackle the desperate shortage of homes in the South, as well as the problem of empty 
and abandoned homes in parts of the Midlands and the North. 
And it's much more than bricks and mortar. That's the lesson we've learnt from the past, when we built 
soulless housing estates and tower blocks with their walkways in the sky. 
Yes, housing is important - but it's more than that - it's about sustainable communities which provide 
jobs, regeneration, transport, better public services, cleaner, safer, greener places to live. And we need 
the raise the quality bar, and make sure that we get better planning, better architecture, better design, 
and better eco-efficiency. 
It can be done.   And, I don't see any reason why we should settle for second best - when we know we 
can match the best in the world. 
That approach is at the heart of what we're trying to achieve in the £38 billion Sustainable 
Communities Plan which I launched in February last year.  
It's under that Plan that we are: 
null Doubling investment in social housing 
null Doubling investment in key worker housing 
null Doubling the money for affordable housing in rural areas 
null Trebling investment in tackling low demand 
null Increasing spending on decent homes 
null Increasing spending on our most deprived areas 
null And creating a new 'Safer and Stronger Communities Fund' to pay for more wardens, more parks 
and more green spaces. 
So a lot's being done, and housing's right at the top of the political agenda.  
But as Kate Barker said in her Housing Review, the imbalances in our housing markets can't be 
solved overnight.  
But for the first time a Government is facing up to the failure of housing markets and the challenge of 
low demand and abandonment in parts of the North and Midlands. 
Our investment in housing market renewal is concentrated on the 9 Pathfinders and will triple to £450 
million by 2008. This will help create sustainable communities in these areas of decline. It's a tall 
order but it can be done with your help. 
3 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
In the London and the South East, there's a different set of challenges. We're faced with a huge 
shortage of homes that has built up over decades. House prices have been rising much faster than 
wages, and the market has failed to deliver. 
That's why we are building 200,000 extra homes in the Thames Gateway - the largest brownfield site 
in Western Europe -  and the other 3 Growth Areas. 
And it's why we are providing resources for an extra 10,000 social rented homes a year by 2008 - a 
50% increase compared with today. 
Indeed, over the next 3 years, we will provide over 115,000 new affordable homes for rent and low 
cost homeownership. 
We're beginning to make an impact. The number of affordable homes is at last increasing again. With 
the 4 new Growth Areas  - and our additional investment in housing - we will increase the supply of 
new homes from 146,000 a year to 175,000. 
But that is at the lower end of Kate Barker's recommendations. She said that, in order to create 
equilibrium and stability in the market, we might need as many as 100,000 more houses each year on 
top of that! 
What we're doing is a huge improvement but this really shows the scale of the challenge that faces us. 
And the scale of this task means that we have to get the maximum number of quality homes built for 
the money we have available. 
The lack of affordable homes has a knock on effect on homelessness.  It's bound to. The numbers 
have risen - but they've risen because we've widened the safety net and moved people off the streets 
and out of B&Bs and into better temporary accommodation. At the last count we'd reduced the 
number of children in bed and breakfast from over 6,000 to virtually zero. 
And the number of rough sleepers is down by nearly 75%.  
But, it's not just about giving people a roof over their head.   
We want to give them a permanent home of their own. 
You've a big role to play in this, but it does mean much closer co-operation with the local authorities. 
We have to ask to ourselves what is the best way to use our money to create sustainable communities.  
It is too evident that you can have housing estates and no community, but you cannot have a 
sustainable community without housing - houses to rent, houses for sale, public and private. And 
much more of them. 
However it is now overwhelmingly clear that the market system alone cannot provide sufficient 
affordable housing. And that social housing provision involving public finance subsidy is needed in 
one form or another.  
The extent of subsidy can be seen in the discount provided for Right to Buy - which cost over £40 
billion. Whilst this increased home ownership by 1.7 million houses, the cost was a reduction of social 
housing by 1.7 million homes, and a massive £19 billion disinvestment in the remaining public 
housing. 
The difficulties have become even more acute in our rural areas. I agree with your manifesto for 
neighbourhoods about more affordable homes in rural areas, where your efforts are well appreciated.  
I do recognise the forceful demand for more land and more flexible use of housing funds which I am 
happy to discuss further with you - and of course the Treasury. 
As you are aware, we will continue the Right to Buy, although we have acted to restrict its abuse and 
have reduced discounts in housing crisis areas.  
4 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
But it has helped raise homeownership to 70% and make estates more mixed in their tenure. More 
mixed tenure.  Different types of tenants.  Private housing and social housing side by side. Some 
100% homeownership. Some part owned. Some rented. That will help make social housing more of a 
positive. Make it more attractive and more acceptable. 
Our challenge is to create communities where people want to live. Not places they want feel trapped. 
That means we need more houses and more choice. 
It's why I asked the Housing Corporation's previous Chairman Brenda Dean to produce a report on 
how to develop a greater range of choice in the way people purchase a home, particularly people on 
lower incomes and first time buyers. 
Brenda said we could do a lot more to bring together the different types of programmes we have to 
promote homeownership. And she also said we can be a lot more creative in the ways we encourage 
homeownership and still protect the existing social housing stock. 
That's the kind of thinking I want you to develop and work on. 
We need new thinking and new ideas.  
But this is not just for the policy mekons -  it's also about the hard economics. 
We've got to drive down costs and we need to be more efficient. 
It's costing more and more to build housing - and particularly, social housing. 
I have looked at the figures.  They're not pleasant. In fact, they're completely unacceptable. Despite 
sustained low inflation and low interest rates, the cost of building new social housing has risen by 
63% since 1997. That's more than three times the rate of inflation! 
The average subsidy going into each Housing Association home for rent has more than doubled - 
from £27,000 in 1997 to £66,000 in 2004. 
And even then, I know you still have to top up with your own money, to make the sums add up. 
In London, it's even worse. The average grant there has  increased to nearly £100,000.  That's every 
10 houses needing a subsidy of £1 million to meet this ever increasing housing inflation. It's 
unacceptable. 
Indeed the total amount of housing subsidies and grants amounts to over £14 billion, just to keep up 
with the market price. 
Just compare our costs with our international competitors. In the last 7 years, building tender prices 
have gone up by less than inflation in France and Italy. 
In our own islands, Scottish homes cost a quarter less to build than English homes, because they use 
modern methods of construction. 
We've got to get better value for money. There must be a different way of doing things.  
A similar story is evident in land prices which have been increasing at a rate of more than 15% a year. 
That's bad for house prices, good for the phenomenal profits being made by the building industry - but 
supported by ever increasing public subsidies. 
So the Government has a part to play. We've got the Housing Corporation and English Partnerships 
working hand in hand for greater efficiency and effectiveness. I thought about merging the two 
organisations, but instead I put the chairmen on each other's boards. That's certainly made the sparks 
fly! And together they're doing very well. 
And now we've set the Housing Corporation some pretty tough efficiency targets for the next three 
years.  By 2008, we expect the whole social housing sector to deliver efficiency gains worth at least 
5 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
£830 million a year. That includes an 8% real saving on the cost of new supply - which means 
switching more money from administration to the provision of new and better housing. 
I know Jon Rouse is on your tail about this, with his Operating Costs Index.  And he's right to do so. 
We need more efficiency for the sake of tenants and all those people who are in your homes and on 
the your waiting lists. 
I don't want to play the numbers game, and maintaining quality is vital, but in some areas there are as 
many as 50 or 70 housing associations.  Sometimes half a dozen in one street. Each with their own 
offices, their own maintenance, their own building contracts, their own management. We have to ask 
ourselves - is this really the best way to do things? Does that deliver the maximum number of homes? 
And it's right to question whether we are managing our land supply in the most efficient way. Land is 
a considerable part of the costs of providing homes, and I'm convinced that we can use land more 
effectively.  
With land prices so high, there must be a better way of doing it. It's crazy that we have been 
subsidising housing for key workers in our hospitals, our schools and our police - because you can't 
have sustainable communities without these essential public service workers  - and yet we've been 
selling off NHS and other public land to the highest bidder!  
I then have to go to the Treasury to ask for more subsidy to provide more housing. We do need a more 
efficient and more effective way of using public land - a more comprehensive form of land 
management. 
That's why we're now making use of surplus NHS and Ministry of Defence land for new housing. And 
there's certainly more we can do with local authority land. 
Land's an important factor, but we've got to get construction costs down as well. Modern methods of 
construction is one way of doing this. 
I'm encouraged by your response to the £250 million Challenge Fund to encourage more innovation.  
We're building schemes in half the time - that's good - but why are the costs still the same as a 
traditionally built house.  That doesn't make sense. Surely time is money? Where are the economies of 
scale? Where are the efficiency gains? There seem to be too many one-off schemes. 
Together, we've got to be sharper and smarter. 
You already working with the rest of the public sector, and delivering extra homes through 
imaginative new partnerships with local authorities.  
That's great, but we need to go further. I will be setting out new ideas about joint working in my 5 
Year Departmental Plan which I'll be publishing shortly. 
Some of the ideas are in the Housing Bill, which, as you know, allows the private sector to bid for 
funds from the Housing Corporation. That shouldn't be seen as a threat, but as an opportunity to do 
new business with new and established partners. 
Some of you are already creating new partnerships, not just with new housing, but with regeneration 
and neighbourhood renewal schemes. I want to support that and I particularly want to congratulate 
you on the first anniversary of "In Business for Neighbourhoods".  
In Business for Neighbourhoods is a great idea because it about linking housing with jobs, welfare 
services, health, care in the community, and education. It's about creating safer, cleaner, greener 
places to live. 
It puts tenants first.   
So let's not forget what you've achieved. 
6 Speech to National Housing Federation Annual Conference 
I was reminded of what we've and how things have changed when I went to the Housing Corporation' 
40th Birthday. They showed Cathy Come Home - I've got the DVD. 
You know it brought back memories of what it was like in the 60's. 
Nearly 40 years ago 'Cathy Come Home' shocked a nation. It powerfully showed the devastating 
consequences of living in a society where there was little support and no choice. 
Cathy got married and was really enthusiastic about the future. You remember, she wanted a family, a 
nice house of her own, and even a Jag!  
It all started to go badly wrong when a child arrived.  The kid wasn't welcome. 
She put herself on the waiting list, but it didn't make any difference. 
She was then forced into short term emergency accommodation, where she had to separate from her 
husband. He went off looking for work and she was left on her own. In desperation, she ended up with 
her child in a caravan, but that wasn't safe. The residents didn't like it and set the caravan on fire. The 
last scene was heart breaking when she was left to sleep on the street and in the railway station - and 
when they took the child away from her. And left her homeless and all alone. 
That doesn't happen today. We don't kick people out on the street, we don't take kids away from 
families, we don't leave people without support. 
Today Cathy would want a decent home, and to have choice between a home to rent, if she wants, and 
the opportunity to buy a home, or even part-buy, a home of her own.   
She wants choice and a community to live and work in. We're making that happen. We're working 
together to give the Cathys of today the home and the choices they deserve. 
I'm proud of what we've done. But the Cathy of today wants more choice, and place where she can 
feel proud, safe and secure. 
Our task is not to just give Cathy a home, but to give her a community.  
A sustainable community.  
That's the challenge for all of us.  
Thank you.  
22 September 2004

Telephone helplines



The Department of Health runs or supports the following telephone helplines, which can only be called from within the UK.


Blood donor telephone service

08457 711 711

Available 24 hours, 7 days a week

The blood donor telephone service offers advice to people who would like to become a blood donor or who want to know where their nearest blood donor centre or session is.

British Allergy Foundation helpline

020 8303 8583

Available 9am - 5pm, monday to friday

A helpline staffed by a specialist nurse to provide information and support for people with allergies and their carers, the general public and health professionals. The helpline is run by the British Allergy Foundation.









Carers line

0808 808 7777

Available monday to friday 10am - 12pm and 2pm - 4pm

Supporting carers in their role by providing complex advice and information on welfare benefits and community care issues.


ChildLine

0800 1111

Available 24 hours, 365 days a year, ChildLine is a free, national helpline for children in trouble or danger.

Children living away from home can also call a special helpline called 'The Line' on 0800 884444. The service operates 3.30pm - 9.30pm monday to friday and 2pm - 8pm at the weekend.

A minicom service for children who are deaf or have impaired hearing is available on 0800 400 222. This service operates 9.30am - 9.30pm monday to friday and  9.30am - 8pm at the weekend.


Churches' child protection advisory service

08451 204 551

Available monday to friday 8.30am - 5pm 

The helpline exists to help leaders/workers in churches, children's groups and other organisations deal appropriately with issues of abuse and child protection. It is also available to parents and children/young people direct.


Contact a family helpline

0808 808 3555

Available monday to friday 10am - 4pm

This is a sensitive and sympathetic listening service for parents whose children have been diagnosised with a disability. It provides information on all medical conditions affecting children, including the rare disorders. Families are directed towards  local and national support groups, many of which provide help on a one-to-one basis.

Contraceptive eduaction service

0845 310 1334

Available 9pm - 7pm, monday to friday

The contraceptive education service provides information and advice on all aspects of pregnancy planning and prevention.









Doctors' supportline

0870 765 0001

Available evenings 6pm - 10pm, tuesdays 9am - 2pm and sundays 10am -10pm. Closed saturdays.

This service is for doctors with personal concerns such as burnout, work problems, anxiety and depression family worries. Trained volunteer doctors offer friendly listening and support which is confidential and anonymous


Drinkline

0800 917 8282

Available 9am - 11pm monday to friday

Drinkline is a national alcohol helpline providing counselling, support, advice and information.








Elder abuse response line

020 8679 7074

Available monday to friday 2pm - 4pm

The elder abuse response line provides a confidential information and support service for anyone concerned about the abuse of an older person.

Frank Campaign helpline

0800 776600

Available 365 days a year, 24 hours a day

The Frank Campaign helpline provides information and advice about drugs and information on local services. The service can take calls in over 120 languages via a three way call with a translator. There is also a website providing information and an email service for users to send in questions which will be responded to.


Gingerbread advice line

0800 018 4318

Available monday to friday 11am - 4pm

The Gingerbread advice line provides advice and emotional support to all lone parent families by telephone. Calls are confidential.

Health literature line

0800 555777

Available monday to friday 8am - 6pm (voicemail at all other times)

The health literature line is the telephone ordering service for free Department of Health publications on a range of health issues.

Help with health costs advice line

0800 9177711

Available monday to friday 9am  – 6pm  and saturdays 9am – 12pm

The advice line provides advice to NHS patients and professionals about entitlements to prescription charge exemptions and the evidence needed to authenticate exemption claims in pharmacies and dispensing chemists.

Kidscape

08451 205 204

Available monday to friday 10am - 4pm

The helpline offers practical advice to children, parents, and carers on child safety, sexual abuse, abduction by strangers, child abduction, and bullying.

Learning disability helpline

0808 808 1111

Available 9am - 5pm

The helpline provides information and advice on learning disability issues to callers including people with learning disabilities, their families and carers, and professionals working in the field.

Menopause and hormone replacement therapy (HRT) helpline

01293 413000

Available monday to friday 11am - 6pm

The menopause and HRT helpline advises women on queries about the menopause from trained menopause health counsellors.


Miscarriage association helpline

01924 200799

Available monday to friday 9am - 4pm (answerphone all other times)

The miscarriage association helpline offers support and information to those who have lost a baby during pregnancy.

National asthma helpline

0845 7010203

Available monday to friday, 9am - 7pm

The national asthma helpline is staffed by specialist asthma nurses to offer support, advice and counselling to people with asthma and their carers. The helpline is run by the National Asthma Campaign.


NHS asian tobacco helpline

0800 169 0 881 (Urdu)

0800 169 0 882 (Punjabi)

0800 169 0 883 (Hindi)

0800 169 0 884 (Gujerati)

0800 169 0 885 (Bengali)

Available tuesdays 1pm - 9pm

The NHS asian tobacco helpline offers friendly, practical advice in the appropriate mother tongue language (or English) to South Asians wanting to give up smoking and/or chewing tobacco paan.








NHS Careers helpline

0845 6060655

Available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week

The helpline provides information on NHS careers. A dedicated team is available monday - friday 9am and 6pm.

NHS Direct

0845 4647

Available 24 hours, 7 days a week

NHS Direct provides advice and information about health and the NHS so that people are better able to care for themselves and their families. The service aims to provide clinical advice to support self-care and appropriate self-referral to NHS services, as well as access to more general advice and information.

NHS pregnancy smoking helpline

0800 1699169

Available 7 days a week, 12pm - 9pm.

Offers practical, helpful and friendly advice to pregnant woman wanting to give up smoking as well as details of local stop smoking services. A call back service is also offered, whereby the individual receives calls from a specialist counsellor for the duration of the pregnancy.


NHS smoking helpline

0800 1690169

Available 7 days a week, 7am - 11pm

Offers practical, helpful and friendly advice to individuals wanting to give up smoking as well as details of local stop smoking services. Health professionals can order a range of literature from the helpline.

Organ donor line

0845 60 60 400

Available 7 days a week, 7am - 11pm

Provides information about becoming an organ donor together with a registration form to join the NHS Organ Donor Register and a donor card, and other organ donation literature.

Parentline

080 88 00 22 22

Parentline provides a confidential telephone helpline for anyone in a parenting role. They offer a safety valve and a source of information about a whole range of parenting issues. The helpline workers are all parents who have undergone training to help callers find answers to concerns ranging from bad behaviour to bullying, depression or parental access.


Prescription prepayment certificate (PPC) order line

0845 850 0030

Available monday to friday, 8am - 8pm

This helpline is run by the Prescription Pricing Authority (PPA) and exists to enable the public to buy a PPC by phone using a credit of debit card. It also provides general advice about entitlement to free prescriptions, in particular medical or maternity based exemption from prescription charges and how to obtain an exemption certificate. Calls are at local rate.









Prescription pricing authority public enquiry line

0845 601 8076

Available Monday to Friday 8.30am - 5.30pm

This helpline is run by the Prescription Pricing Authority (PPA) and exists to deal with queries about specific cases relating to prescription prepayment, medical or maternity exemption certificates. It will also deal with more complicated queries where the Prescription Prepayment Certificate Order Line could not advise. Calls are at local rate.

Saneline

0845 767 8000

Available 12pm - 2am

Saneline is an out-of-hours telephone helpline offering practical information, crisis care and emotional support to anybody affected by mental health problems.

Sexual health line

0800 567123

Available 24 hours, 365 days a year

The sexual health line provides advice and information about HIV, AIDS and sexual health/local services. Calls to the helpline are confidential.

Social work recruitment campaign helpline

0845 604 6404

8am -10pm

To handle response from the national recruitment campaign for social workers

Stillbirths and neonatal deaths helpline

020 7436 5881

Available Monday to Friday 10am – 5pm 

The stillbirths and neonatal deaths helpline provides an opportunity for parents to express their grief with trained counsellors.

Support line for survivors of professional abuse

08454 500 300

Monday to Friday 10am - 12.30 pm and 1.30pm - 4pm

The Prevention of Professional Abuse Network (POPAN) provides a free and confidential service to people who have been abused by social and/or healthcare professionals. POPAN workers listen carefully as people relate their experiences of abuse. POPAN also provides information about the various options open to clients and supports them as they decide what to do.

Welfare foods helpline

0800 0562665

Available Monday - Friday 9.30am - 4pm 

The welfare food advice line enables customers to obtain general advice on the welfare food scheme and to enable abuse of the scheme to be reported. Calls are free of charge.

Winter warmth advice line
0800 0857000 (telephone)
0800 0857857 (minicom)

Monday to Friday 8am - 8pm Monday to Friday (1 October - 31 March)

The winter warmth line provides advice and information to older and vulnerable people on keeping warm and well during the winter months. Information is also available on benefit entitlements, cold weather payments, and grants for energy efficiency improvements to the home.

Women's aid national domestic violence helpline

08457 023 468

Available 24hrs

To offer support, help and information to women who are experiencing, or who have experienced, domestic violence.

Women's health concern helpline

01628 483 612

The women's health concern helpline advises women on gynaecological problems, the menopause and HRT.

Women's Health enquiry line

020 7251 6580

Monday to Friday (except Tuesday) 10am - 4pm 

Women's Health offers a confidential, non-judgmental enquiry service providing information on a wide range of women's health topics.

      YORK 
        MEDICS TRAIN FOR SIERRA LEONE

      Soldiers from York 
        are to set up a field hospital in Sierra Leone later this month. 

      Thirty-three soldiers 
        from 34 Field Hospital normally based at Queen Elizabeth Barracks, Strensall 
        have packed their medical equipment ready to deploy to Freetown 

      The soldiers are undergoing 
        two days of special training in preparation for their departure. They 
        are to set up a ten-bed hospital to provide routine treatment for the 
        British soldiers stationed in Sierra Leone.

      The field hospital 
        unit is deploying to provide short-term medical cover whilst the Indian 
        UN hospital departs and the next hospital sets up. British soldiers will 
        then continue to make use of the UN hospital once the changeover is complete.

      "We will also be trying 
        out a new computer patient data tracking system which sends the notes 
        with the patient and enables us to see which stages they are at in the 
        medical system and which they have been through," said Major Jem Langley, 
        the hospital's physiotherapist.

      When they arrive in 
        the country they will have to acclimatise themselves to the heat and humidity. 
        At present the temperatures are reported to be in the high eighties Fahrenheit 
        and the humidity about 95 per cent.

      34 Field Hospital 
        sends individuals on a regular basis to the Balkans and deployed as a 
        unit to Kosovo in December 1999. The small ten bed hospital deploying 
        to Sierra Leone will include a number of specialist medical staff such 
        as consultants, doctors, theatre nurses and accident and emergency staff 
        normally employed in military hospitals by the Defence Secondary Care 
        Agency.
