Explanatory Memorandum On The Exchange Of Notes Between The United Kingdom And The Netherlands Concerning Privileges And Immunities For The Liaison Officers At Europol


(01/03/99)









      EXPLANATORY MEMORANDUM ON THE EXCHANGE OF NOTES BETWEEN THE
      UNITED KINGDOM AND THE NETHERLANDS CONCERNING PRIVILEGES AND
      IMMUNITIES FOR THE LIAISON OFFICERS AT EUROPOL

      Title of Treaty

      Exchange of Notes between the Government of the United Kingdom
      of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the Government of the
      Kingdom of the Netherlands containing an Agreement regarding the
      execution of Article 41, paragraph 2, of the Convention based on
      Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union on the establishment
      of a European Police Office (Europol Convention), signed 26 July
      1995.

      Command Paper Number: Cm 4290

      Subject Matter

      The main purpose of the Exchange of Notes is to provide, in the
      Netherlands, the privileges and immunities necessary for the
      proper performance of the tasks of the UK Europol Liaison
      Officers.  These officers, and those representing other States
      Parties to the Europol Convention, will work from the Europol
      Headquarters in The Hague, but will be employed by and remain
      under the administrative control of the national criminal
      intelligence services they represent.  The Exchange of Notes
      implements the obligation in Article 41(2) of the Europol
      Convention.

      The main obligations are on the Netherlands (the Host
      Government).

      Similar Notes are in the process of being exchanged between the
      Netherlands and other States Parties to the Europol Convention.

      Ministerial Responsibility

      The Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs is
      responsible for agreements between the United Kingdom and other
      States and for policy in relation to the granting of privileges
      and immunities.

      Policy Consideration

      (i)  General

      United Kingdom support for the establishment of a European
      Police Office was signified by HMG's accession to the Europol
      Convention signed on 26 July 1995 (Cm 3050).  The role of
      Europol and Liaison Officers in exchanging and developing
      intelligence between Member States should help to make a
      significant impact on international drug trafficking and
      generally on organised crime.  Privileges and immunities in the
      Netherlands are necessary to facilitate the performance of the
      functions of the Liaison Officers.

      (ii) Financial

      None for FCO but NCIS have made budgetary provision for #250,000
      to cover the costs of sending three Liaison Officers to the
      Hague and of setting up a small office there.

      Implementation

      The Exchange of Notes shall enter into force on the first day of
      the month following the day on which both the United Kingdom and
      the Netherlands have notified each other that the legal
      requirements for entry into force have been complied with.  No
      implementing legislation is required in the United Kingdom.

      Consultations

      The Home Office, HM Customs and Excise, the National Criminal
      Intelligence Service and the Police Federation of England and
      Wales have been consulted.  All are in agreement with the text
      of the Notes.

      Presented to Parliament

	HMS Campbeltown Visit To Campbeltown 15-18 Jun 04


HMS Campbeltown visited her affiliated town for the first time in 4 years. Campbeltown is the capital of Kintyre and is beautifully set within a deep loch, sheltered by Davaar Island and picturesque surrounding hills. The town sits on the south end of a peninsula bordered on one side by the Atlantic and on the other the Firth of Clyde.



The ships company mixed well with the local population and enjoyed the fine hospitality on offer, each mess reacquainting their connections with affiliated bars. Indeed a football match was arranged between the ship’s team and Whiskey Macs, a local pub affiliated to the sailors’ mess. Whiskey Macs came out on top with a 5-3 victory. HMS Campbeltown’s goals were scored by hotshots CPO(WEA) Andy Davy with 2, and OM(W) Rob Nelson.

A cocktail party took place on the flight deck for members of the ship’s crew and local dignitaries witnessing a ceremonial sunset on the first night in.



During the three-day visit many local associations were invited onboard. TS Campbeltown and the local Dalintober Primary School thoroughly enjoyed their tour around the ship, with the children hugely impressed by sitting in the Captains chair on the Bridge and visiting the mess decks. The children were also shown the ship’s fire fighting and damage control equipment and allowed to practice wearing Breathing Apparatus sets. The tour concluded with an entertaining party including a quiz and hot dog buffet.







A careers forum was hosted by the wardroom involving teachers from Campbeltown’s Grammar School and members of the Careers Advice centre in Glasgow. Led by ship’s gardener CPO(MEA) Roy Burdon, 20 members of the Ship’s Company over a 2 day period, used their green fingers to help with a community garden project. The Kintyre Environmental Group have been working as part of Kintyre Healthy Living Partnership to develop a garden as a community resource for the production of organic fruit and vegetables. The garden is being set up within the extensive walled garden at the rear of Auchinlee Church of Scotland Eventide Home. John and Gail Aiken have been instrumental in running the project and were impressed with the help offered by the ship to the local community. 



HMS Campbeltown left her hometown for NATO exercises, but before that the ship took part in Scottish Navy Days in Helensburgh. Fifteen veterans, that the Petty Officer’s Mess had met in Caen a couple of weeks earlier at the D-Day commemorations, had the chance to visit the ship whilst at anchor. They where treated to a fine display by the Red Arrows whilst enjoying a glass of Champagne and a plate of strawberries!

	History of 40 Commando Royal Marines



40 Commando Royal Marines


Formed in 1942, from A Commando, 40 Commando was the first RM Commando Unit. It saw early action during the raid on Dieppe in August of that year. From 1943 to 1945 the Commando was involved in the Italian Campaign, at Termoli, Lake Comacchio and subsequently in Yugoslavia. For its decisive action the Commando was awarded the Termoli battle honour. 



Following the second world war the Commando was deeply involved in Palestine acting as the rearguard in the Protectorate, leaving in 1948. They subsequently undertook security duties in Cyprus, Hong Kong and Egypt before moving to Singapore in 1961, where it was involved in operations during the confrontation with Indonesia throughout the following decade. 



In 1971 the Commando left Singapore and re-established itself in Seaton Barracks, Plymouth. Over the next decade the Commando found itself deployed to Northern Ireland four times and also undertook an unexpected two month tour in Cyprus after the invasion by the Turkish Army. 



In 1982, following the Argentinean invasion of the Falkland Islands, the Commando deployed on Operation Corporate. On 21 May the Commando were among the first troops ashore and secured the beachhead at San Carlos. The Unit was subsequently split having two companies attached to the Welsh Guards, preparing to attack Port Stanley, when the Argentinean surrender came. 



On their return the Commando spent the rest of the decade involved in a variety of tasks including two Northern Ireland tours to South Armagh, a six-month Peace-Keeping tour in Cyprus and a six month operational tour in Belize. During the tour in Cyprus the Commando was awarded the Wilkinson Sword of Peace for the third time. Also during this period, in 1983, the Commando relocated to Norton Manor Camp near Taunton. 



In 1991 the Unit undertook its first Norway deployment but found itself undergoing a dramatic climatic change when, due to the Gulf War, it deployed to Northern Iraq to ensure the security of Kurdish refugees. Northern Ireland tours, Norway winter deployments and a major Asia-Pacific Exercise kept the Commando busy through the following years. 



In 1998 a substantial part of the Commando deployed to the Congo to ensure the safe evacuation of UK nationals from Kinshasa City. 



The new millennium saw the Commando deploy to Northern Ireland and on their return they were the first Commando to reorganise under a new structural concept called Commando 21. 



The Unit deployed in its entirety in January 2003, initially part of the Naval Task Group (NTG) 03 in HMS Ocean, Ark Royal and RFAs Sir Galahad and Tristram.  The group sailed through the Mediterranean, after a brief stop at Cyprus, continuing through the Suez Canal bound for the Arabian Gulf.  The United Nations were engaged in diplomatic efforts to avoid the need for military intervention in Iraq as the Unit was busy rehearsing in the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait for possible operations against Sadaam Hussein’s repressive regime.

In March 2003 a coalition force, under the overall command of the United States, entered Iraq with the expressed intention of liberating its population from persecution and removing the intolerable threat to global security posed by its dictator.



During Operation TELIC, the liberation of Iraq, on the night of 20 March 2003, 40 Commando, under the command of Lt Col G K Messenger OBE, mounted an amphibious helicopter assault to seize key Iraqi oil infrastructure on the Al Faw peninsula.  As the first conventional troops on the ground, the strategic significance of the operation was immense and, as the Divisional Main Effort, the assault was supported by a vast array of coalition firepower.



The Commando Group’s role in the success of the coalition operation in Iraq was pivotal and profound.  In a two-week period of intense operations, it secured key oil infrastructure, cleared a large expanse of enemy held terrain, and defeated a major enemy stronghold on the periphery of Basra, killing over 150 Iraqi soldiers and taking 440 prisoners.



2004 has seen the Unit’s return to Iraq as part of a multi-national division peace-support operation.  Under the command of Lt Col R W Watts OBE, it has been instrumental in maintaining the security of the country’s infrastructure with particular attention being paid to the oil-pipelines in the southern region that keep the economic ‘life-blood’ of Iraq flowing.  Additionally, the Commando has been responsible for convoy protection, counter insurgency and border security operations.



As the role of the Commando develops it is increasingly contributing to the development of the fledgling security forces within Iraq and the Unit’s commitment, in-theatre, until early 2005, will see it well placed to assist in the country’s forthcoming landmark elections.

Tue  2 Nov 2004

CHARITIES






	
	

Charities


	HMS PORTLAND's Adopted Charities



Introduction



HMS PORTLAND’s adopted charities were selected by the Ship’s inaugural Welfare Committee during her first year of operation.  The principle underlying selection was that the charities should include representation from our affiliated regions of Weymouth and Portland, our base port of Plymouth and a Royal Naval charity. 





The Islanders Club for Young People

	

Based on the Isle of Portland, this charity sets out to raise funds for disadvantaged young people in Portland, Dorset and was the adopted charity during his tenure of the former Mayor of Portland Councillor Les Ames.  The Ship’s first charitable earnings prior to commissioning, from a horseracing evening during Contractors’ Sea Trials in the Summer of 2000, were presented to Les during his visit to the Ship whilst still in build on the Clyde in October 2000.





Westfield College, Weymouth



Westfield College cares for and educates autistic children from the Weymouth Area.  The Ship hosted a lively visit by a party from the College during her first visit to Portland in June 2001 and looks forward to future exchanges whenever possible.  Westfield College was the recipient of the Ship’s first fundraising in commission, a sponsored beard-growing competition! 





HCPT[RN]  - The Pilgrimage Trust



HCPT – The Pilgrimage Trust was founded shortly after the Second World War by a former Royal Naval Medical Officer.  Each year some 2000 handicapped children, assisted by around 3000 helpers, spend Easter Week in Lourdes for a Pilgrimage Holiday, providing them with a week to remember as well as a valuable period of respite for their families and carers at home. 



The Trust consists of several hundred groups established up and down the United Kingdom, with three made up of Royal Naval personnel, in Devonport, Portsmouth and Faslane.  The Royal Naval Groups set out to enable handicapped dependants of serving RN personnel to participate each year, supported by serving RN personnel acting as helpers.





The Fighting Spirit



Based in HMS PORTLAND’s base port of Plymouth, The Fighting Spirit was founded by Dr Sheila Cassidy.  The organisation sets out to provide therapeutic support to sufferers of breast cancer in Devon and Cornwall and to promote the power of positive thought as a means to overcome the condition.

Press Briefing: 3.45pm Wednesday 26 May 2004 
Briefing from the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman on: Iraq, Amnesty Report and Deputy Prime Minister.
Iraq 
Asked about comments by the Professor of International Law at Oxford who had said there was still a difference in the US position as set out by Colin Powell and the Prime Minister's, the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman (PMOS) pointed that he didn't think the professor had been part of the conversations held between the President and the Prime Minister. 
Asked what British forces would do if when engaged on a mission they were in a situation where they had to go against the wishes of the Iraqi Government the PMOS pointed out that this was a hypothetical question which people would be working very hard over the next few weeks and months to ensure that did not occur. The important thing was that there was consensus and coordination. Reality would no doubt be complex enough without having to invent hypotheticals. We would deal with reality in the same ways as we had dealt with reality in Bosnia and in the same way we had dealt with reality in Afghanistan and other areas where these issues had been faced. As he had mentioned in his morning briefing the important point was that the UN resolution had it in black and white that we were only there after 30 June with the consent of the Iraqi Government and that we would be working to coordinate the multinational force with the wishes of the Iraqi Government. There was a clear distinction in any military operation between setting the broad strategy and the operation of that strategy on the ground. The PMOS set out again that people should not have the idea that somehow or other the goal of the multinational force was different from that of the Iraqi government. The goal was the same: stability on the ground and as quick a transfer of responsibility to the Iraqi forces as they are capable of taking. 
Asked if Jeremy Greenstock had been saying at lunchtime that the rules governing US and UK troops in relation to what was operational could be different, the PMOS thought that what he had been saying was that clearly there have to be arrangements made, but these technical arrangements would be made. The principle of consent was one that was reflected in the comments of President Bush and in the comments of Colin Powell and they were there in black and white in the resolution. Asked if the exchange of letters between the US and UK Governments with the Iraqi Government would cover these sorts of technical rules of engagement the PMOS said that the technical arrangements would be covered in those letters. However, you cannot set down in black and white every eventuality, you have to recognise that practical issues would arise which would be address at a local practical level. If difficulties arose there would be a mechanism at the national security level and an interface between it and the multinational force for resolving those issues. Every operation took into account a strategic framework and that strategic framework took into account the sort of sensitivities that are out there, but we would not deal in hypothetical scenarios because the reality was always more complicated and more multifaceted than those scenarios. 
Amnesty Report 
Asked what the Prime Minister's reaction to the amnesty report that criticised the war on terror as being the worst attack on human rights since the second world war the PMOS said that the Government would no doubt want to study the report in full before making any response and he would not comment on phrases seemingly designed to make headlines. If it came to considering the worst atrocities against human rights one would have to take into account what Saddam did in terms of 400,000 mass graves in Iraq and you would also have to take into account what Al Qaeda did in one day in America. 
Deputy Prime Minister 
Asked if the Prime Minister would react to being compared to Harold Wilson by the Deputy Prime Minister the PMOS said that he had not seen the DPM's comments and the comments are a matter for the DPM. The Prime Minister would be carrying on his job as normal. In response to further questioning the PMOS restated that the Prime Minister had set on his position on the matter and that he had nothing further to add.

	09 Jul 04




A busy and eventful couple of months have passed since HMS Kent completed her second port visit to Chatham.  During a week when the ship was alongside in Portsmouth,  the Marine Engineer Officer, Lt Cdr Ned Kelly, organised a sailing expedition in the Solent aboard one of the Navy?s yachts.  A small crew of 8 volunteers had a fantastic week learning how to sail a yacht, visiting several picturesque harbours and fully living the life of a ?yachtie?.  







While the budding yachtmasters were ?messing about in boats? other members of the Ship?s Company were busy making a small piece of Naval history by becoming the first warship to enter a crew in the Royal Navy Field Gun Competition.  



















In over 100 years of competition, heralding from the Boer War, no Ship-of-the-line has ever entered a Crew and for a lean-manned Type 23 frigate this was no small achievement.  A 30 man squad trained hard for 4 weeks prior to the competition learning how to manoeuvre the gun strip it down and reassemble it as fast as possible or as sailors would say, ?at the speed of naval gunfire?.  At the end of the 4 weeks the final 18-man crew was achieving competition winning times and expectation was high around the Fleet.  However, luck was not on the Ship?s side on the day of the Competition as the 2 crew members were injured during the first 2 timed runs which had to be abandoned.  This automatically placed the Kent Crew in the Runner-up Final. Amazingly, they had only a couple of hours to train a substitute in a critical position but, MEM Smith was up to the challenge and the crew ran home in a very commendable 2nd place.  Their courage and determination was a fine example of what can be achieved with proper planning and personal effort however, the Ship is also very thankful for the support provided by our Sponsors, Shepherd Neame Brewery, the Mercers Company and the staff of the Naval Base Commander at Portsmouth.



Immediately following the Field Gun Competition HMS Kent set sail for Pre-Deployment training with Flag Officer Sea Training (FOST) Staff.  Cobwebs were firmly swept aside as KENT, along with other Frigates and Destroyers, conducted numerous imaginary wars off the coast of Devon and Cornwall and after two weeks of late nights and very early mornings, the Ship has re-emerged as a ?sharp? fighting unit.  Ready for action, HMS Kent can now look forward to sailing for a NATO Deployment in the Mediterranean which will commence in Aug.  HMS Edinburgh is currently on task in the Med and will be keenly awaiting our arrival which will allow her to return home for a  well deserved rest.



Before departing UK the Ship?s company will be busy stocking the ship with everything that we will need for a the 4 month trip and making personal preparations to ensure our homes and families are properly looked after whilst we are away.  Everyone will also get 2 weeks Summer Leave to get fully rested before we go. Gibraltar will be our first port of call as we make our way into the Med and the next update to this website will be published from there.  Between now and then we would like to wish all our readers a peaceful, pleasant and happy Summer.

                            Policies of Deceit (4)
                        
	
                            Forum: 
                            
                            Draft EU Constitution
                        



                	
	
                            The provenance of the European Constitution.

The terms of reference for the Convention on the Constitution for Europe were to define the respective powers of the Union and member states, simplify the rules and create ‘more democracy, transparency and efficiency’ with particular reference to the national parliaments. In the event, the Constitution is in almost total contravention of the terms of reference. 

The Bruges Group commissioned a leading Barrister, Leolin Price, CBE, QC - to give a legal opinion on the draft Constitution. He concluded that it was “unacceptably centralising, authoritarian and unaccountable” and that there were no conceivable amendments that could make it acceptable to a responsible UK Government. 

Britain submitted over 200 amendments to the Convention; only 11 were accepted. Those rejected include all of our vital issues – the ‘red lines’.

Tony Blair never objected to the highjacking of the Convention; his vital amendments were rejected, yet he tells us that the Constitution is 95% acceptable!



Evolution of the Constitution.

The British Government has passed power to Brussels either directly or through Qualified Majority Voting (about 180 areas). The Constitution defines changes far more fundamental than the concessions to date. David Heathcoat-Amory MP, who served as a member on the Convention, states that most domestic policy areas will be opened up for legislation at Union level; national vetoes will largely disappear. Part One, the Constitutional Structure, will be almost entirely new. The sections on foreign policy and defence, criminal justice and immigration are unrecognisably different from the existing treaty articles. (For example, on immigration the Union will decide who goes to what country and on what terms; only the Commission can make proposals and voting is by qualified majority). 

There is no way in which this can be just a ‘tidying up’ exercise!



The Future.

Germany and France have stated that they expect no major changes to be made to the concept of the Constitution. Mr Heathcoat-Amory is convinced that the essential architecture of the Constitution and new Union is settled. So Tony Blair has little chance of winning on his vital issues of taxation, foreign policy, etc 

Yet Tony Blair insists that, as there will be no large constitutional changes, a referendum is unnecessary



To quote Mr Heathcoat-Amory: “The Government’s refusal to admit a referendum is based on deceit and cowardice: deceit, in trying to disguise the importance of the undertaking; cowardice, in not having confidence in their own arguments. This must be challenged by all who believe that democracy is more important than expedience, and that Constitutions must be decided by the people”.

The Passage South

With the outstanding defects from marine engineering trials still to be proved, the ship sailed for the passage south with two members of the Babcock trials team and one member of MTAU to prove the machinery had been rectified before arriving in Portsmouth.  Initial trials whilst still in the Firth of Forth were in the main successful and the Babcocks staff were boat transferred off to Berwick within a matter of hours.  There remained a problem with too many leaks from both main engines however which would not be able to be resolved until the ship was alongside in Portsmouth.



During the passage south the Deputy Marine Engineer Officer, CPO ‘Cheesy’ Chesson, qualified as engineering Officer of the Watch, having completed his final set of machinery breakdown drills.



Fleet Date Inspection

We arrived back in Portsmouth on Thursday 27th May, the day before our big inspection.  With such a short time to prepare and a Base Logistics Inspection going on that same afternoon it was all hands to the pumps.  The Fleet Date Inspection was conducted by Captain David Dickens Royal Navy, Captain Surface Ships to the Commodore Portsmouth Flotilla.  It was a close call but despite the ship looking very smart we failed the Inspection due to the as yet unresolved main engine leaks.  This was disappointing but with most of the following week to effect the repair had little impact on our Programme.  The leaks were fixed and proved at sea allowing us to sail as planned on 4th June and return to the Fleet 6 days later than planned.



We are currently enroute to Faslane for Operational Sea Training but took the opportunity to stop at anchor overnight off the Isle of Man for an evening of ‘Horse Racing’ on the Flight Deck. This was an excellent event, kindly organised by the Senior Rates Mess and much enjoyed by all.  The girls syndicate, with Chef McDowell as an honorary member for the night, seemed to do particularly well although the real winner was the ship’s charity for which we raised £180.  



Future Programme

Looking ahead post three weeks of Operational Sea training in Scotland we will return to Portsmouth for a Base Maintenance Period and aviation trials.  We are then very much looking forward to Re-dedication and families day before proceeding on a well earned summer leave.



Personnel

Besides the new Buffer we also welcome Petty Officer Communications ‘Pony’ Moore who joined in Rosyth to take over from Petty Officer ‘Spike’ Hughes who left to join the Sea Training Team in Plymouth. 



Leading Weapon Engineer Mechanic (Radar) ‘Kenny’ Kenworthy joined as part of the Falkland Island manning alongside our new Leading Medical Assistant Dave Edwards and Leading Steward Yvonne Jordan.  OMs Allon, Barnes, Poulton and Rothwell have also recently joined us from HMS Ark Royal.



In addition Lieutenants Meredith Scanlon and Joanne Culshaw joined us from HMS Collingwood for six months of Navigation training before commencing their first complement jobs as Warfare Officers.

Press Briefing: 11am Tuesday 31 August 2004
Briefing from the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman on: Anti-Social Behaviour, Northern Ireland, Fox Hunting, Olympics/EU Flag, Prime Minister/Holiday and Reshuffle.
Anti-Social Behaviour
Asked for further statistical information about Anti-Social Behaviour Orders (ASBOs), the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman (PMOS) said that more than 2,400 ASBOs had been issued since being introduced in 1999, with 1,323 taken out in the year to March 2004. The use of ASBOs had therefore increased by 50% in the last year. It was clear that the powers were starting to take grip and were being used more widely up and down the country. However, the purpose of the Prime Minister's visit to Harlow today was to encourage their use more widely. The PMOS pointed out that 422 ASBOs had been issued in Greater Manchester since 1999 - up 232% since 31 March 2003. 59 ASBOs had been issued in Liverpool - up 139%. 122 ASBOs had been issued in Leeds - up 430%. 48 ASBOs had been issued in the London Borough of Camden - up 182%. These figures showed that local councils, local authorities and the police were beginning to see how effective the powers actually were and were starting to use them more widely. 
Asked how the ASBOs were being used, the PMOS pointed to the use of Fixed Penalty Notices. He also noted that Harlow had been the first council to use dispersal orders to break up gatherings of people. The powers were clearly beginning to bite. Asked if there was a sense of frustration that some councils, such as Lambeth and Hackney, were not using the powers that were available to help combat anti-social behaviour, the PMOS said that part of the problem was the fact that some local authorities remained to be convinced of the effectiveness of the powers. The purpose of the Prime Minister's visit to Harlow today was to highlight their value as a tool to tackle anti-social behaviour. It was also why a team of 'ambassadors' and experts had been appointed to show councils what could be done. In some areas, pressure from the local community had led to the powers being used. That could only spread. Asked whose job it was to issue ASBOs, the PMOS said that they were issued by the local authorities. The areas covered included environmental crime, nuisance neighbours and supporting witnesses.
Northern Ireland
Asked about the latest round of talks on Northern Ireland, the PMOS said that this week would see preliminary discussions taking place between the Secretary of State and the local parties on a bilateral basis, leading to intensive talks at Leeds Castle between 16 and 18 September. The aim was to come up with a deal. We believed that the parties had engaged seriously since the Assembly elections in preparing the ground for such a situation and that it was worth going for a deal rather than delaying the process. As anyone who had been following what people on both sides had been saying over the summer would recognise, there was a common agenda on the devolution of policing and how to handle the timescale of such issues as decommissioning and bringing paramilitarism to an end. These were now being openly discussed between the parties in a way which would have been inconceivable a few years ago. Today was the tenth anniversary of the IRA ceasefire. We had clearly come a long way since then. That said, we had yet to complete the journey. Both President Clinton and Senator Clinton had underlined during their visit to Northern Ireland last week that delay would only result in a political vacuum, which was clearly a very dangerous thing.
Asked for a reaction Mark Durkan's concern that there was too much compromise was being made to benefit the extreme end of Northern Ireland politics at the expense of the moderates, the PMOS said he did not think it would it would be helpful to comment directly on what Mr Durkan had said. However, it was important to recognise the very clear criteria which the Prime Minister had set down in a speech in Belfast two years ago in which he had underlined that any deal would have to result in a complete end to all forms of paramilitarism and to a genuine inclusive democratic Government. That was a goal towards which the SDLP had played a very constructive role in helping to achieve. It was true that different parties would have different approaches to the talks. However, the important point was that there was a shared agenda. Asked if he would agree that the SDLP had been 'comprehensively shafted' by political forces, despite the role it had played, the PMOS said that it wasn't his job to comment on election results. As we had said at the time, electoral support and electoral responsibility went hand in hand. That principle applied to all sides. 
Asked if it remained the Prime Minister's intention to call for new elections in Northern Ireland should the talks at Leeds Castle fail, the PMOS said that it was important to be clear what the Prime Minister had actually said. He had simply been making the point that there was no reason to delay the process and that we would sit down and see if a deal could be reached. If that was not possible, then that was clearly something on which we would have to reflect. However, at the moment we were focussing all our energy and attention on achieving a deal.
Fox Hunting
Asked how urgent the Prime Minister considered the fox hunting issue to be in terms of when it would be brought forward in Parliament, the PMOS said that he had nothing further to add to what had already been said about the issue. Asked if it would be discussed in Cabinet on Thursday, the PMOS pointed out that there was no Cabinet meeting this week. Asked the Government's latest position on the issue, the PMOS said that it had not changed. As everyone was aware, the matter had been up for discussion. When we had anything further to say about it, we would let people know.
Olmpics/EU Flag
Asked for a reaction to reports today suggesting that the outgoing President of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, was proposing that European athletes should sport the EU flag in commemorating their sporting victories, the PMOS said that he was not aware of any plans to introduce such an idea. The Great Britain team would continue to fly the Union Jack whenever the opportunity arose. He took the opportunity to congratulate Team GB on its performance in the Olympic Games in Athens. Asked if a victory parade would be arranged for them, the PMOS said that, as with England's Rugby triumph, we would talk to the athletics authorities and decide what they wanted to do. Asked if the Prime Minister liked the idea of a victory parade, the PMOS pointed out that the Olympics had only just finished and the athletes had only just returned home. We would let them catch up on their sleep before talking to them. 
Prime Minister/Holiday
Asked if the Prime Minister felt relaxed and 'raring to go' after his summer holiday, the PMOS said yes. Asked about a reported incident relating to a football game involving the Prime Minister and Prime Minister Berlusconi of Italy, the PMOS said that his days as a football commentator were long gone. Those who had read his match reports in the Belfast Telegraph would know why. Questioned further, the PMOS declined to comment on a game he hadn't attended. 
Reshuffle
Asked to rule out the possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle before the Party Conference season, the PMOS said that he was impressed with the remarkable restraint shown by journalists in waiting until the end of the briefing to ask about this matter. As they knew very well, however, it wasn't his policy to respond to reshuffle questions.

The advice in this paper supplements the guidance given in the SRB Round 5 Bidding Guidance, and should be read alongside it. Its purpose is to inform bidders about regional needs and priorities, as the Government sees them. It also gives an indication of the level of resources likely to be available regionally to support new schemes.

Regional Overview
The South West is the largest region in England with 18% of the country's area and 8% of its population (4.8 million). It is predominately rural in character and has an attractive natural and built environment. 

The region is relatively prosperous with a diverse economic base, though it has higher than average dependency on defence industries, tourism, agriculture and financial services. While small firms predominate in the region, there are also notable large and international businesses with significant supply chains. Some of the smaller towns are traditionally associated with one major employer, many of them vulnerable to economic change.

The region has a strong higher and further education sector. There is a broad skills base, though there are skills shortages in the faster growing areas and problems for the low skilled in obtaining employment. Unemployment is unevenly distributed, with significant clusters in disadvantaged areas of Bristol and Plymouth and structural unemployment in Cornwall. Market towns face a changing role as a more mobile population finds jobs and facilities elsewhere.

The main problems of social exclusion in the South West are related to:

underachievement and low skill, particularly amongst youth 

lack of employment opportunities, and access to facilities and training, especially in Cornwall and rural areas 

particular issues of drug abuse, criminality and homelessness 

ethnic minorities

Resources
The indicative total allocation for new schemes under Round 5 in this region is: 

	year 1 1999/2000
	each subsequent year

	£2-4 million
	£5-8 million


Priority Areas
Ministers have indicated that they wish to see 80% of SRB Round 5 resources targetted towards comprehensive schemes in those local authority district areas which are included in the top 50 on one or more of the four measures of deprivation shown in Annex C of the Bidding Guidance. This means that most of the available resources nationally will be allocated to a small number of regeneration schemes in those specific priority areas. In the South West, there are two urban areas in this category - Bristol and Plymouth.

The remainder of the regional allocation will be available for other areas or disadvantaged groups which have significant need. We would particularly welcome local area proposals from Penwith, Kerrier and Torbay (which fall within the 100 most deprived districts in the country on the district-wide degree measure). Rural Development Areas and other areas which can demonstrate significant pockets of deprivation that have not yet benefitted from SRB support may also be candidates for funding. In addition, wider area, or thematic, bids will be considered provided they can demonstrate that they would make a material impact on a clearly defined disadvantaged group, particularly those identified in the work of the national Social Exclusion Unit.

 Scheme content
Outside Bristol and Plymouth, schemes should generally be seeking less than £2m by way of total SRB contribution. All schemes should clearly address social exclusion and seek to enhance opportunities for those at greatest disadvantage. Local area schemes should offer sustainable community based responses to local need. They should demonstrate clear linkages with other regeneration activity and the active involvement of local residents in both the preparation and implementation of the proposals. All the bids should be supported by the relevant public agencies and private and voluntary sector interests. All bids must show that effective local management systems will be put in place and that projects will be rigorously appraised. Wider area or thematic bids are most likely to be successful where they create new ways of working among existing agencies to provide a more cohesive approach to combatting disadvantage.

Linkages with other Government, and publicly funded, programmes and initiatives (including regeneration initiatives) should be clearly demonstrated in all bids. Schemes that include employment measures should explicitly state how they link in to New Deal. Proposals that include employment, training and education projects should indicate how they relate to the relevant TEC, Careers Company and Local Education Authority plan and programme. In the case of Plymouth, clear links to Health, Employment and Education Action Zone initiatives should be demonstrated.

In drawing up bids, partnerships should reflect opportunities for funding from the European Union for their schemes. ESF Objective 3 (support for the long term unemployed and disadvantaged) and ESF Objective 4 for employees 'at risk' are cross regional. Additionally, in this region, Cornwall, much of Devon and parts of West Somerset have Objective 5b status; Plymouth has Objective 2. Much of the region is also eligible for funding under specific European programmes such KONVER, LEADER and PESCA. Further details of these programmes can be obtained on request from Government Office for the South West.

Community Initiatives
Ministers are keen to encourage the active participation of local communities in their areas. As explained in the national Bidding Guidance, up to 10% of the resources made available for each scheme may be used to support capacity building activity1. There is also provision for free standing schemes devoted to capacity building, provided that they lead to a sustainable regeneration plan. In considering such bids in this region, priority will be given to the most needy communities where there is the clear prospect of developing active involvement and ownership. 

Bids for community enterprise and investment schemes (see national Guidance) should demonstrate that they meet a genuine gap in the availability of capital funding and are based in an active but needy community. The SRB contribution will be limited to 50% and to £50,000 per scheme. 

Regional Development Agency
Subject to legislation, control of the SRB will pass from the Government Office to the South West Regional Development Agency (RDA) during the course of this bidding round. On 29 July, it was announced in Parliament that the Chairman designate of this Agency is Sir Michael Lickiss. Other Board members and the Chief Executive will be identified in the next few months, and the RDA will begin operation in April 1999. Prior to April 1999, the SRB will continue to be administered by the SRB Team of the Government Office for the South West (see contact details below), involving the RDA Board designate as appropriate. We will aim to ensure a smooth transition. Details of the new arrangements will be supplied before the final bid stage.

Bidding Process
The national Bidding Guidance indicates that expressions of interest must be submitted to the Government Office by Friday 27 November 1998, but potential bidders should get in touch with the Government Office as early as possible to discuss their proposals informally. To do this, please ring the SRB Team, Government Office for the South West (tel: 0117 900 1873). You will then be given a lead contact, with whom you should discuss your proposals.

1. For further advice on this, including examples of community based regeneration activities, see Annex E of the national Bidding Guidance.

 1.     This note is one of a series being produced by each Government Office for prospective bidders under SRB Round 5 in their Region. It supplements the national Bidding Guidance and should be read alongside it.

2.     Resources for Round 5 schemes in the Region are approximately £1-2m in 1999/2000, and £3-5m in each of the further 6 years for which schemes may run. Against that background we are likely to be able to support only 5 or 6 new schemes at most (not including any bids to top up existing schemes). This note indicates the areas from which bids are likely to be sympathetically considered, bearing in mind that the aim of the SRB is to assist in regenerating areas suffering from social, economic and environmental deprivation.

3.     Eastern Region is large and diverse, incorporating London commuter suburbs, free-standing towns, ports and seaside resorts, and extensive rural areas. There are no major conurbations, Southend, Luton/Dunstable, Norwich and Peterborough being the largest urban areas.

4.     Most of the region is fairly prosperous. In the 1980s East Anglia, especially Cambridgeshire, was the fastest-growing part of the UK, and growth resumed as the recession ended. County unemployment rates are all now below the UK average. The Cambridge area and much of Hertfordshire are especially buoyant. Felixstowe is the fastest growing major port in the UK. Peterborough retains high growth potential, and Stansted Airport will increasingly be a focus for growth. Much of the region, especially the southern and western parts, has high quality road and rail connections, and the southern parts benefit from the strength of the London economy.

5.     There are however areas of deprivation. Many of these areas suffer from multiple problems, including unemployment, low educational attainment, high crime, poor health, homelessness and bad housing, pollution and environmental degradation, and inadequate infrastructure. They include substantial parts of:

Luton/Dunstable, with a narrow industrial base hit by vehicle manufacturing closures in the early 1990s, now again under threat from the possible loss of manufacturing capacity, and severely affected by the housing market downturn of 1989-93; there is a large and disadvantaged ethnic minority community;

Norwich: major sub-regional centre, but relatively isolated, with a low-wage economy, and suffering from recent job losses in confectionery and other industries, and with a substantial need to invest in renovating its council housing stock;

Southend: affected by the long-term decline of domestic seaside holidays, with a low-wage economy and poor private housing with extensive multiple occupation;

other port/fishing/seaside resort towns, including Harwich (with the region's highest unemployment rate), Wisbech, King's Lynn, Great Yarmouth, Lowestoft, Clacton, Grays and Tilbury - all suffering from decline of their former economic base, with high unemployment and low wage rates, and many poorly served by road and rail;

inner areas of older industrial towns, including Bedford, Ipswich, Peterborough and Watford, characterised by loss of local employment, poor environment and run-down private housing, some with deprived ethnic minority communities;

some former New Towns, including Harlow, Basildon and Stevenage, and former GLC/LCC overspill estates, with ageing infrastructure, low educational attainment, high levels of benefit dependency and high crime rates.

6.     Though less apparent from employment statistics, there are also weaknesses in the structure of the local economy in some of the more remote rural areas, where communications are poor, there is little local economic activity other than farming, and CAP reforms may cause further job losses.

7.     The above analysis is largely confirmed by DETR's Index of Local Deprivation, which updated and revised the Index of Local Conditions, and is used in allocating resources for the SRB between regions. Six districts (Norwich, Luton, Great Yarmouth, Harlow, Ipswich and Thurrock) fall within the 100 most deprived districts in the country on the district-wide 'degree' measure, which measures deprivation averaged across the district using 12 indicators, many of them updated as part of the 1998 revision. Small area statistics (still mainly based on the 1991 Census) also reveal pockets of severe deprivation elsewhere, notably in Peterborough, Bedford, Waveney (Lowestoft ), Kings Lynn, Southend and Tendring (Clacton and Harwich). The table attached at Annex A shows the national ranking of the districts in the region on the four measures used in the ILD.

8.     Paragraph 3.1 of the national Bidding Guidance indicates that about 80% of SRB resources at national level will go to support large schemes in those districts that rank in the top 50 on one or more of the four ILD measures (65 districts in all). 12.     SRB schemes approved in Rounds 1-4 bidding rounds have benefited almost all of the disadvantaged areas listed in paragraph 5.  Background Following the Regeneration Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR), DETR Ministers have announced that local regeneration partnerships in the areas of greatest need can submit proposals for additional resources through SRB Round 5. These proposals should be prepared in response to the national guidance and this regional regeneration framework, and in discussion with the Government Office (GO-EM).

SRB Round 5 proposals should address social exclusion and enhance opportunities for those at a disadvantage in the areas of greatest need. They should add value to existing partnership activity in these deprived areas, through the development of sustainable, community-based responses to local need and the more effective targeting of existing and proposed programmes and services. The proposals should demonstrate clear linkages with other regeneration activity. Local partnerships will be expected to demonstrate the active involvement of relevant public agencies, private and voluntary sector interests and local residents in the preparation and proposed implementation of their proposals. They will also need to ensure that effective local management systems will be in place and that projects will be rigorously appraised.

Regional allocations for new schemes will depend on the level of existing commitments. Present indications are that up to £4m in 1999/2000 and up to £9m in each of the following 6 years will be available for new schemes in the East Midlands.

Regional Priority Areas Ministers have indicated that they wish to see SRB Round 5 resources targeted towards large, comprehensive schemes in the most deprived districts nationally (according to the Index of Local Deprivation). They have also signalled their strong commitment to tackling need in the former coalfield areas and other "pockets of deprivation".

In the East Midlands, this will be reflected in twin priorities:

i.   Proposals from Nottingham, Leicester, Lincoln and Derby, which are the most deprived local authority areas of the region, according to the national Index. About half of the regional allocation will be available for good quality comprehensive proposals to address deprivation and social exclusion in these districts. As indicated in the national guidance, these comprehensive schemes should be based on an agreed local strategy with commitments secured from local partners. Where appropriate, local partnerships might wish to use proposals developed in response to the LGA's New Commitment for Regeneration as a starting point for developing their local regeneration strategy.

ii.   Tackling the needs of the most deprived parts of the former North Nottinghamshire/Derbyshire coalfield (within the districts of Mansfield, Bolsover, Chesterfield, Ashfield, Bassetlaw, North East Derbyshire and Newark & Sherwood). Local partnerships are encouraged to develop an integrated response to the issues raised in the recent Coalfield Task Force report.

The remainder of the regional allocation will be available for good quality local schemes of generally less than £2m, including:

a.   smaller scale community initiatives in the above regional priority areas. In particular, SRB funding of up to £50,000 will be available as match funding for innovative community enterprise and investment schemes.

b.   the regeneration of particularly deprived neighbourhoods in otherwise relatively prosperous districts. For this purpose, priority will be given to proposals which address the needs of those wards of Northampton, East Lindsey and Erewash, which are among the 10% most deprived nationally. A list of relevant wards is attached.

c.   innovative responses to significant rural deprivation within the region's Rural Development Areas as defined by the Rural Development Commission.

Many parts of the East Midlands are benefiting from schemes funded under previous SRB rounds, including those areas identified above. In determining which schemes to support under SRB Round 5, account will be taken of these existing schemes and the effectiveness of the partnerships responsible for their implementation. Local partnerships might wish to take advantage of SRB Round 5 to consolidate existing SRB activity within the context of a single agreed local regeneration strategy. 

Priority Themes As indicated above, Ministers expect future SRB schemes to address social exclusion and enhance opportunities for those at a disadvantage. Local partnerships are best placed to determine how to meet local needs most effectively. However, activity proposed under the SRB should particularly target the most vulnerable groups, including young people and, where relevant, ethnic minorities.

In addition, SRB schemes could address competitiveness and innovation in the local economy. Local partnerships should look to take advantage of inward investment activity undertaken by EMDC and English Partnerships. However most new jobs will arise from the growth of local businesses, particularly SMEs, and SRB resources could be used to add value to local TEC and Business Link activity.

Activity proposed under the SRB should increase the capacity of local partnerships and communities to tackle their needs. Proposals should aim to be self-sustaining after the initial period of funding. 

Integration SRB proposals should be developed within wider local regeneration strategies. These strategies should show how the proposed SRB activity would add value to: 

a.   mainstream public sector programmes and services, especially those delivered by local authorities and the TECs, 

b.   Government initiatives, especially Welfare to Work, but also, where relevant, Employment, and Health and Education Action Zones, and the New Deal for Communities Pathfinders

c.   the regional and local strategies of agencies, such as English Partnerships and the Rural Development Commission

Proposals should also be consistent with policies set out in the Regional Planning Guidance for the East Midlands (RPG8), the Regional Competitiveness Strategy and the region's Single Programme Documents.

Liaison with GO-EM Local partnerships will need to work closely with GO-EM in the preparation of their bids. In particular, partnerships in the regional priority areas should involve GO-EM in the development of the local regeneration strategies and the proposed comprehensive schemes. Partnerships looking to access European funding to support their SRB bid should first contact the European Secretariat within GO-EM to discuss the likely availability of resources. A list of contacts is attached.

Subject to the necessary legislation, responsibility for SRB will transfer to the East Midlands RDA on 1 April 1999. Outline SRB Round 5 proposals will be assessed by GO-EM in consultation with the RDA Shadow Board. Final bids will be appraised by the RDA, with decisions taken by Ministers. Details of the proposed hand-over arrangements will be provided later.

 Introduction
The purpose of this guidance is to provide a regional assessment framework within which SRB Round 5 bids in the North-East will be considered. It gives an indication of the resources that will be available to support schemes, an analysis of the target areas for different elements of the budget and also highlights the key regeneration needs and themes that should be addressed.

The objectives of the SRB programme are to: 

enhance the employment prospects, education and skills of local people;

address social exclusion and enhance opportunities for the disadvantaged through community development;

promote sustainable regeneration, improving and protecting the environment and infrastructure;

improve the quality of life of local people and their capacity to participate in regeneration activities;

encourage more effective integration of programmes through partnerships and the involvement of local communities and voluntary groups;

support and promote growth in local economies and businesses.

Resources
Indicative SRB resources available for new Round 5 Schemes in the North-East are :

	1999/2000
	around £10m

	2000/2001
	around £20m

	2001/2002
	around £20m


This round provides more than twice the resources available in Round 4.

The total new resources over the three years amount to around £100 million. The resources shown above for Round 5 would thus leave sufficient headroom in the programme for further SRB rounds starting in 2000 and 2001. It is too early to say how much will be available beyond 2002 but the working assumption is that most expenditure on large schemes would take place over 5 years and consequently that support for projects agreed under SRB Round 5 will be available (but at a lower level) in years 4 and 5 (i.e. beyond 2002).

The national guidance (para 9.1) refers to over 50 schemes worth £20-25m in SRB funding that can be supported in the lifetime of this Parliament. This includes expenditure on schemes started in earlier SRB rounds where Round 5 resources provide some additional support. The North East budget is likely to be able to support one or two completely new schemes of this size, with on-going schemes attracting top-up funds for expansion of existing projects that show promise.

Target Areas
The national guidance makes clear that a high percentage of SRB resources nationally will go to support large, comprehensive regeneration schemes in those areas which are included in the top 50 on one or more of the measures of deprivation in the Index of Local Deprivation (ILD) (see footnote1). In the North East, the following local authorities meet this criterion:

	Gateshead Hartlepool Middlesbrough Newcastle upon Tyne Redcar and Cleveland South Tyneside Stockton-on-Tees Sunderland


It is anticipated that around half of the resources available under Round 5 will be targeted on these areas.

Given the resources available, and the emphasis on large comprehensive schemes, it is unlikely that resources will be allocated to more than one scheme in any local authority area.

A significant level of resources will be available for those areas which, while not demonstrating the concentration of deprivation exhibited in those authorities in the top 50 on the ILD, nevertheless have significant pockets of need or are facing particular problems. Bids are invited particularly from those communities highlighted in the recent Coalfields Task Force report and those areas where major industrial closures have been announced in recent weeks.

The remainder of the regional allocation will be available for good quality local schemes which are generally more focused, covering a smaller area and calling on a lower level of resources. Bids are particularly invited which address priority needs and opportunities within rural areas. Annex D to the national guidance sets out the criteria for bids in rural areas and lists the Rural Development Areas where bids are encouraged. Schemes which demonstrate a well-developed partnership approach to economic and social regeneration are likely to have a greater chance of success.

Although the main emphasis for SRB support will be on key target areas, there will still be scope to consider well directed thematic bids which cover a much wider area.
