 Priority Themes
The SRB provides resources to support regeneration initiatives carried out by local partnerships. 'Regeneration' embraces both physical regeneration projects and those aimed at promoting economic development and industrial competitiveness. It is a pre-requisite of SRB that schemes should make a real and sustained difference in deprived areas.

In the North East, we will be looking for bids that meet the objectives of the SRB programme set out at the beginning of this guidance and particularly those that aim to promote sustained economic regeneration in the region and tackle the problems of social exclusion.

The national guidance (Section 4) stresses the importance of linking SRB proposals with other Government programmes and initiatives. SRB proposals which draw more effective contributions from mainstream programmes (i.e. 'bending') into the area will get higher priority than proposals which simply supplement existing measures such as New Deal and mainstream local authority activity. Equally, social measures (such as programmes dealing with health, housing or crime) will be given higher priority where they are integrated with economic measures which seek to overcome underlying social problems.

Competitiveness
Regional partners recently produced a competitiveness strategy for the North East - Competing in the 21st Century - which will make a key contribution to the regional economic strategy of the RDA. In developing schemes, partners should ensure that, wherever appropriate, their objectives are consistent with this strategy, particularly in relation to supporting North East business and raising educational aspirations and skill levels. Proposals for area-based business support should involve collaboration with the relevant Business Link and should be aimed at the growth of established firms.

Complementarity
Over the last 12 months there have been a number of government initiatives (e.g. Employment Zones, Health Action Zones, Surestart, Education Action Zones) aimed at co-ordinating the delivery of a wide range of programmes and policies on the ground. Where SRB proposals are looking at similar areas and target groups, there should be a clear read-across with these new initiatives to ensure added value.

SRB schemes should also ensure that they are consistent with central and local government strategic policies and plans, particularly in the areas of sustainable development and regional/local planning guidance.

Community Involvement
We recognise that all SRB schemes should be developed through a bottom-up approach with local partners and communities agreeing to tackle issues of local concern in a co-ordinated and effective fashion. Indeed the effective commitment of partnerships to community capacity building (especially at the outset) is a criterion for SRB support and Ministers would like to see a significant proportion of funding going to such projects. In encouraging community economic development, community-based enterprise schemes will be given priority. Business start-ups will be considered for SRB support where they are part of wider measures for community enterprise development. Access to finance for community businesses will be encouraged through support of credit unions, where possible in collaboration with other financial institutions.

It is expected that partnerships will demonstrate a clear willingness to share best practice in this and other related SRB areas of activity, including attendance at relevant seminars and conferences.

Developing Proposals
Expressions of interest must be submitted to GO-NE by the end of November 1998. Last year we encouraged partnerships to discuss their proposals with the Government Office and to continue the dialogue up to the point at which the final bid was submitted. We want to build on this process this year. It is essential that partnerships develop their schemes through an interactive process in order to meet identified needs in priority areas. Schemes should be developed in close dialogue with the Government Office for the North East and the other partners who will form the North East Development Agency from next April. Where appropriate, schemes should demonstrate a clear link with the findings of the Coalfields Task Force and the groups established to co-ordinate the response to major closures.

Full bids are not required until the end of April 1999. They will be assessed and approved by the Regional Development Agency. Further advice will be available nearer the time.

 This note is one of a series being produced by each Government Office for prospective bidders under SRB Round 5 in their Region. It supplements the national Bidding Guidance and should be read alongside it. It gives an indication of the resources likely to be available, highlights some key points about the bidding process, and describes the overall approach to regeneration and the key areas and issues which we are looking at SRB Round 5 resources to tackle in London. This Framework has been discussed with members of the London Development Partnership and agreed by the LDP's Board.

RESOURCES
In London, subject to commitments from existing Challenge Fund schemes and other SRB programmes, the assumption is that the resources available for distribution in Round 5 of the SRB will be approximately £19-22m in 1999/2000 and £44-48m in 2000/01 and each subsequent year that schemes may run. (Individual schemes may run from one to seven years. The bulk of the expenditure on major, comprehensive regeneration schemes will be expected to take place within five years. However, capacity building at the neighbourhood level and the creation of effective routeways to broader opportunities is not a quick process, so a full seven years expenditure on such elements will be expected.) 

We are seeking, within the lifetime of this Parliament, to support major comprehensive regeneration schemes in the most deprived boroughs as identified in the national Bidding Guidance and reproduced at Annex A. In Round 5 we believe there is scope for the Government Office to support a small number (perhaps 6 or 8) of major comprehensive regeneration bids of around £20-25m from the boroughs listed. In addition, we shall be looking to support a number of smaller bids which will consolidate existing regeneration activity in these boroughs.

Outside the most deprived boroughs in Annex A, we shall be looking to support a small number of modest bids that will tackle need in identifiable pockets of severe deprivation. Also, whilst it is expected that the majority of bids in this Round will be area based, there is scope for thematic bids which address single themes where there may otherwise be gaps in provision regionally or sub-regionally. All such bids should however relate to one or more of the priority issues set out in this framework and should take into account the need to concentrate resources on combating deprivation and social exclusion.

Community based initiatives such as credit unions, development trusts and Local Exchange and Trading Systems (LETS) have been a feature of regeneration activities over a number of years. The Government also wants to support the growing movement towards innovative community enterprise and investment schemes, including those which encourage innovative approaches to access to capital. There is scope within London's allocation for providing up to around £500,000 for such schemes on a match funding basis, but potential bidders should note that this sum is not ringfenced. The SRB contribution will be limited to no more than £50,000 per scheme.

Successful bids, unless they are by established partnerships and build on existing initiatives, are likely to have only modest project costs in Year 1, reflecting the requirement to provide support to ensure the active involvement of the community and the need for partnerships to have established management systems in place prior to the release of SRB funding. Bids from established partnerships will be expected to have significant levels of spend in Year 1, commensurate with the profile of available resources discussed above.

Bids that do not represent broadly based partnerships directly involving local communities and comprehensive approaches to the priority needs set out in the guidance are unlikely to be favoured for the SRB resources available.

A key issue in assessing bids will be the extent, quality and importance of the outcomes that are planned and the significance of the impact the bid would have on the problems it identifies.

PROCESS
It is important that anyone proposing to work up a bid to submit to GOL in Round 5 should discuss initial proposals with the Government Office as soon as possible and prior to submitting initial outline proposals to meet the 27 November deadline. Bids which have not been the subject of informal discussion ahead of the deadline are much less likely to succeed. A list of the appropriate GOL contacts, who will be pleased to offer advice on developing proposals, is at Annex B.

Submitted proposals will be assessed, both against the criteria in the Bidding Guidance and the priorities in this Framework, by officials in GOL and by members of the London Development Partnership. Final decisions will be made by Ministers.

OVERALL APPROACH TO REGENERATION
Partnership development and management will be particularly important in any evolving regional strategy. The emphasis remains on the structured development of real partnerships representing the key sectors involved, public, private, voluntary and community. Partnerships will increasingly need to develop consultative structures with those that regeneration objectives seek to touch and serve, and to respond to community needs and aspirations rather than dictate top-down solutions. Bids will normally be expected to contain proposals to support community capacity building. Bidders will be expected to check and demonstrate the sustainability of their proposals.

The complexity of regeneration in London is not a prescription for endless proliferation of partnerships. Careful thought will need to be given as to whether new regeneration initiatives could add value within existing partnership structures. There is an equally strong case for developing linkages between partnerships to establish better integration of local economic, environmental and community regeneration agendas.

To assist in working towards a more effective integrated approach, it will be particularly important for partnerships to ensure that they recognise and address the complexity of funding programmes (available from both the Government and Europe), linking up with existing and planned area based initiatives. Resources targeted through initiatives such as Education Action Zones, Health Action Zones and the New Deal for Communities pilots will require integration and coordination with any proposed new SRB programmes. Partnerships will also need to consider linkages with European funding from the Structural Funds through Objective 2 and Community Initiatives in the London region and through Objectives 3 and 4 of the European Social Fund.

A central theme to bids should be the concept of an integrated approach to sustainable development1, as developed by London partners in the work of the London Study. Such an approach would highlight the need to address sustainable development in three respects: economic competitiveness, social cohesion and environmental sustainability. Bids should adopt an integrated approach to sustainable development that identifies the potential impact of activities on all three key areas. In taking an integrated approach to sustainable development, while bids may focus on only one or two of the key components, they should identify potential impacts on the other key aspects.

1. sustainable development is defined in the London Study as "A development that offers fundamental, social and economic services to all the residents of a community without compromising the proper functioning of the natural settlement and social system on which the supply of these services depends"
 PRIORITY ISSUES FOR SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY REGENERATION
London's most deprived communities are in a particularly acute position: they are affected by global/regional competitiveness issues, often experience poor environmental conditions and have not been effectively engaged in the regeneration process. In this context, multiple deprivation undermines the viability of such communities, creates poor quality of life and impedes their ability to create their own opportunities or engage effectively with broader opportunities.

A focus on communities is a key element of Government regeneration policy. There is a recognised need to encourage a bottom-up approach to regeneration rather than imposing priorities from above. It is important that partnerships should support and develop structures which operate on a scale individuals can identify with. As part of this process, community enablement is an important factor in an on-going programme of sustained regeneration.

Area regeneration programmes should develop coordinated packages to address the specific needs of priority communities. Such programmes may include a range of initiatives. A primary focus will be to address community enablement, capacity building and widening participation in education, and to demonstrate mechanisms by which this can be brought about. In addition, a number of key priorities should be addressed:

Population Diversity It is important to develop programmes to take on board the needs of the whole community, including those of women, young people, older people, disabled people and a broad range of ethnic minority groups:

London is home to 45% of Britain's ethnic minorities and 1 in 5 Londoners come from an ethnic minority group, higher than any other region; 

Women make up over half of London's population, and the percentage of younger women in the population is greater than elsewhere in the UK;

Estimates of disabled people will vary with the definition used: 12% of London households are in receipt of incapacity or disablement benefits, with identical percentages in inner and outer London, but around a fifth of the population report suffering from a limiting long-standing illness, with the highest rates recorded in inner London boroughs; 

London's population is generally younger than the rest of the country, and young people continue to be a primary consideration in regeneration policy;

Older people, although conversely fewer than elsewhere in the country (15.5% are at retirement age compared to 18.2%), often have particular needs, e.g. around community safety or employment.

We will be looking in Round 5 for schemes which will help these groups share more in the prosperity of the region. Bids which clearly demonstrate the involvement of these communities of people as committed partners in the planning and delivery of schemes will be particularly welcomed.

Education, Skills and Lifelong Learning. Learning is the key to prosperity and the aims of the SRB reflect this. Pre-school care is a primary consideration and quality provision for those in greatest need can add an important element to local community regeneration programmes.

In terms of educational performance London has some of the best and some of the worst schools in the country. At GCSE only eight boroughs exceeded the English average of 44.5% pupils achieving 5+ passes at grades A-C. GOL will be looking for bids which seek to raise educational attainment, increase the diversity and flexibility of learning opportunities for young people, and enable them to pursue the qualifications they need. It will be important to address disaffection and exclusion to achieve local community regeneration. It will be important in addition to address the educational need of some pupils from ethnic minority backgrounds or with special educational needs. SRB 5 may bring opportunities for complementary programmes in London's four Education Action Zones.

Training for skills and lifelong learning opportunities remain a priority beyond compulsory schooling. Although London has performed better in working towards the national Targets for Education and Training than other parts of the country, there is still much progress to be made. Skills and lifelong learning proposals in SRB5 should in particular address skills gaps and lifelong learning opportunities and complement developments flowing from the Government's Green Paper. "The Learning Age", including those being funded from sources such as the FE Collaboration Fund, ADAPT and Objective 4 of the European Social Fund.

Voluntary Sector The voluntary sector has been increasingly involved in the SRB and other regeneration programmes. There are an estimated 30,000 organisations employing about 50,000 staff in the capital. The figure increases to 60,000 plus if organisations operating within communities, often with unpaid staff, are included. This is a valuable resource and we shall be looking for bidding partnerships, particularly funding agencies in the public sector, to demonstrate in Round 5 that they are working more closely with and actively supporting local voluntary and community organisations, ethnic minority and faith communities.

Unemployment Unemployment is an acute problem in many of London's most deprived communities. Levels of unemployment in London remain high with over 315,000 unemployed, with some 196,000 having been out of work for more than six months. Of that total, some 68,000 are aged 18-24 (34,000 for 6 months+). Round 5 bidders should consider carefully how their proposals will meet the Government's Welfare to Work priorities, consulting those involved in the delivery of New Deal programmes as appropriate, and address the needs of the target groups.
Growth of local economies Business has a key role in regeneration. In the longer term, lasting regeneration of communities can only take place through competitive businesses in an area contributing to the growth of a local economy. Schemes which promote opportunities for, and reflect the needs of, business leading to sustainable economic development are, therefore, of considerable value. Proposals, where appropriate, should take into account local Business Links strategies. Such schemes need not be confined to the most deprived districts as defined in the national Bidding Guidance as these districts can also take advantage from schemes in surrounding areas which encourage wealth creation. 

Community Safety Crime and fear of crime are near the top of most Londoners' concerns. The Crime and Disorder Act places a new duty jointly upon local authorities and the police, with others, to develop strategies to reduce crime; the Government has also taken special measures through the appointment of a UK Anti-drugs Coordinator, to better focus action against drugs misuse. We will be looking for bids which contain projects addressing these major public concerns in London.

Housing and Regeneration London has about two-thirds of the nation's most deprived housing. Of the local authority stock, more than 7 out of every 10 properties is ether unfit or in disrepair; 1 in 4 properties were built before 1945; and 1 in 4 properties are in blocks of flats greater than 5 storeys. Many of the most deprived communities will live in Council accommodation and SRB bids which complement housing investment programmes will be welcomed.

Public Health and Child Care The key factors that influence health in London are: those associated with economic and social developments affecting employment, income and opportunities; diversity of different population groups; and physical environment. These factors interact with behavioural and lifestyle practices which then give rise to the inequities in health status that exist in different parts of the capital. For example, premature mortality (dying before the age of 65) can differ between boroughs by a factor of 50. Cardiovascular disease remains the biggest cause of premature death amongst Londoners.

The younger aged population of London gives rise to pressing health concerns. For example: mental health - especially amongst young men in the inner city; accidents; substance misuse; unintended pregnancies - abortion rates are the highest in the country; and higher levels of HIV/AIDS - AIDS related mortality is now the most common cause of death in men aged 15 to 54 and the second most common cause in women of the same age in Inner London.

Some communicable diseases, notably tuberculosis, are on the increase with notification and mortality rates in some Boroughs being six times higher than the national average.

SRB proposals which demonstrate ways to reduce the inequities in health that exist in London are particularly welcome.

Over one quarter of London's residents are aged 0 to 19 - a total of 1.8 million - the proportion varies from borough to borough and is highest in Newham (33%) and lowest in Westminster (19%).

The areas that present the biggest challenges and opportunities for child health are: reduction of infant mortality, particularly in the poorer sectors of the population; reduction in childhood accidents; changes in behaviours such as smoking, substance misuse and physical activity; reduction in teenage pregnancy; and mental health. The social and economic conditions in which children find themselves will impact on their health and the need for health and welfare services.

SRB bids which consider London's children will be welcome, particularly bids which address ways to reduce inequalities and improve: inter-agency working for children; appropriateness and accessibility of children's services; and child friendly employment practices. Bids concerned with social exclusion, transport, housing, education, training and future employment will also impact on child health.

Environmental Sustainability Environmental problems associated with urban areas reflect the damage caused by economic growth which failed to take account of environmental impacts. London is one of the world's most pressurised urban environments, where the challenge of sustainable development is particularly acute. The challenge is to develop strategies which link environmental sustainability with policies aimed at achieving economic competitiveness and improving social cohesion. All three components of sustainable urban development should be represented, with the two components of social cohesion and environmental sustainability not treated as secondary to the pursuit of economic growth or as constraints to growth not treated secondary to the pursuit of economic growth or as constraints to growth.

European Funding
Objective Two and European Community Initiatives Over the period 1994-99, parts of London will benefit from around £140 million in grants from the European Community's Structural Funds (European Regional Development Fund and European Social Fund).

About £116 million is distributed under the East London and Lee Valley Objective 2 Programmes 1994-96 and 1997-99, which seek to promote the economic regeneration of the most deprived parts of six north and east London boroughs through an integrated package of business support, infrastructure, and training activities. Under the second Objective 2 programme, ESF grants for vocational training projects in 1997 and 1998 are now committed. Around £26 million in ERDF grants will be formally committed to business support and infrastructure projects during the autumn. Further ERDF and ESF bidding rounds are expected to be launched towards the end of this year.

Parts of London are also eligible for Structural Funds grants under smaller, more narrowly defined, "Community Initiative" programmes. The "Urban" initiative addresses the needs of excluded communities in 9 wards in 5 London boroughs by developing their capacity for bringing forward solutions for the economic regeneration of their local areas. About £11 million in ERDF and ESF grants has been allocated. Local Action Plans, identifying needs and priorities, are currently being finalised. When these have been agreed, expenditure will be committed locally. The "Retex" initiative addresses problems caused by the loss of textile and clothing jobs in the Objective 2 area. The full programme allocation of £800,000 has now been committed. The "Konver" initiative targets areas affected by the run down of the defence industry in 5 London boroughs. Around £9 million has been allocated to the programme. A final bidding round will be held in autumn 1998. The "SMEs" initiative aims to encourage small businesses within the Objective 2 area to be more competitive internationally, thereby increasing export potential. Around £1.7 million is allocated to the programme. Discussions are currently taking place on how the Programme might best be delivered.

Objective 3 and 4 Objective 3 funding aims to assist the long term unemployed and young people into work through the provision of guidance, vocational training and wage subsidy schemes. Around £90m will be spent in London by the non-Government sector in the 1997-99 programme period on such measures. In addition, there is funding available to support projects which help to equalise workplace opportunities between men and women and projects which aim to increase access to Objective 3 support by groups which suffer particular disadvantage in the labour market. Objective 3 is available all over London but in 1999 projects which target priority community areas will attract a few extra points in the scoring process. The deadline for bids for 1999 funding is 19 October 1998.

Objective 4 is a new programme for which around £16m is available in London in 1998-99. It aims to help facilitate the adaptation of workers to industrial change, focusing on those employees of small and medium-sized enterprises who are threatened with unemployment or affected by industrial change or changes in production systems. It will support the strategy for workforce development set out in the Green paper 'The Learning Age'; thus, Objective 4 projects may support such initiatives as the University for Industry, Individual learning Accounts and Investors in People. Bidding for 1999 funds will open on 4 January and close in Mid-to-late February 1999.

Both Objective 3 and 4 ESF monies can be used to match SRB funds. A new programme for 2000 and beyond is still under negotiation but may see Objectives 3 and 4 merged into a single new Objective.

PHYSICAL AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES
The pattern of business activity and employment in London is dominated by Central London, and the series of corridors radiating out from the inner area. Lea Valley, to the north, and Thames Gateway, to the east, pivot around Stratford and are clearly defined. West London opportunities fan out along a number of road, rail and canal corridors, underpinned by Heathrow and Park Royal. Those in South London are focused on the Wandle Valley. Clusters of small enterprises are also scattered throughout inner south and east London, often grouped around local town centres.

These are the key target areas for new development, business growth and the creation of new jobs. Investment , particularly in East London, is required to modernise and restructure less competitive areas to attract sustainable mixed use development and diversify the economic base. Integrated area management strategies, based around key nodes, should define new economic roles, link land availability to new sources of growth, and develop pathways between the job opportunities being created and associated areas of deprivation and high unemployment.

- Central Area
Sustaining London's world city functions, based in and around the City and West End, are fundamental to the City's future prosperity. Bringing forward for development the major sites which ring the central area, at Kings Cross, Paddington and Bishopsgate/ Spitalfields is a key objective, both to facilitate growth and link inner city communities to central area job opportunities. 

The development of successful entry points and clear pathways to central area employment will continue to be crucial; also the need to develop stronger outreach between central area employers and inner city communities. The City Fringe and South Bank are particularly important in this respect. The City Fringe offers opportunities based around the consolidation of its traditional functions, and the development of new business services, cultural industries and media sectors. The successful regeneration of the South Bank is not only a key priority in its own right but also provides an essential stepping stone in integrating inner South London communities more closely with Central Area opportunities. Elephant and Castle is strategically positioned to consolidate and extend the regeneration process.

- Thames Gateway
Thames Gateway contains a significant proportion of London's brownfield development land, and is a focus for future London growth. The sites often have significant problems of access, dereliction and contamination. A key challenge will be to bring forward proposals for major mixed use development on these sites which integrate new communities into the existing urban structure. The enhancement of transport linkages will play an important part in the long term achievement of Thames Gateways potential, together with the development of supportive environmental and social infrastructure.

The area needs to consolidate its existing industrial base, notably at Fords Dagenham and Belvedere, and to acquire new economic and business sectors to underpin development on the north side of the river, and establish new sources of employment for communities on the south side such as Woolwich where past structural decline has led to widespread deprivation. Considerable progress is being made in the growth area of leisure and tourism and needs to be consolidated.

The regeneration of Thames Gateway will inevitably take place over a long period of time. Some of the key sites are more advanced than others and careful planning and interleaving of the phasing on individual sites will be required.

-East London and Lea Valley
East London and the Lea Valley contains a series of well defined employment nodes centred around the green axis area provided by the River Lea and the Lea Valley Regional Park, and flanked by high density deprived communities particularly at the southern end.Added importance derives from its designation as an Objective 2 area under the European Regional Development Fund.

The consolidation of its remaining manufacturing areas continues to be of key importance, through infrastructural improvement, business innovation and technological development. At the same time area needs to diversify its economy and secure a greater share of London's growth sectors, particularly in services. The expansion of Stansted Airport provides an important potential new source of growth and jobs for the area and demands an integrated response.

Stratford, with its extensive associated development lands, and pivotal transport role enhanced by the Jubilee Line and International Passenger Station, is a key opportunity to create a new character for the area, based upon high quality development. The large scale commercial development at Canary Wharf provides a further opportunity , together with the exhibition centre/technology and business park initiatives in the Royal Docks.

- West London
The continued vitality of the West London economy is essential to London's long term economic health and prosperity. Heathrow is a key element, both as an employer in its own right, and as a generator of airport related services and industries, and attraction for international headquarters. There is scope to focus these benefits further on deprived parts of West London in relatively close proximity to the airport; notably Hayes and Feltham.

Park Royal is the other major anchor in the West London economy. Consolidation of its position through development of key gateway sites, public transport access, and infrastructural improvement, is of particular importance to deprived west London communities within its hinterland.

Restructuring of other major nodes, including Wembley and Southall/Parkway is also important, to improve their economic competitiveness, attract sustainable development and create new employment opportunities 

-South London
Employment areas in South London are significantly less well developed than in the other sectors. Aside from the Thames Gateway the principal economic axis is the Wandle Valley linking a chain of older industrial estates and development sites between Wandsworth and Croydon. Improving the competitiveness of these areas and attracting, new sources of employment is the key priority.

Transport and Accessibility
Mobility and the reduction of barriers to isolation are vital factors in the regeneration of London's most deprived areas. Low levels of car ownership, wide variation in accessibility in Inner London and strong imbalances between priority communities and employment opportunity all serve to underline this point. Critical journeys affect the employability, social inclusion and quality of life of those in priority regeneration communities.

The Government has recently outlined its Transport Priorities in the Integrated Transport White Paper. In London, there is a clear need to address the need for improving the attractiveness and scope of public transport through interchanges and upgrading of infrastructure.

Particularly important are those transport hubs and local access strategies which will secure the consolidation of key regeneration areas within the City Fringe, Park Royal and Willesden, Heathrow and Hayes/West Drayton employment opportunities, the Lee valley and the Royal Docks.

 SUMMARY

Bids must be based on the following principles:

have a clear focus, based on thorough research and consultation with the local residential and business communities, and set out the key problems they are addressing and the impact they intend to achieve;

be submitted by a broadly based partnership involving local authority, education and training providers, private, voluntary and community sectors;

be designed to deliver a broad range of outcomes and outputs to address the needs of the area as a whole and demonstrate an integrated approach to sustainable development in three respects: economic competitiveness, social cohesion and environmental sustainability.

have a clear exit/forward strategy to ensure proposals are sustainable; 

have linkages with other housing and regeneration initiatives and Government funding e.g. existing SRB programmes, Welfare to Work, Estates Renewal Challenge Fund, European funding programmes etc. and demonstrate added value;

The prime emphasis in London in Round 5 will be on bids which :

address youth and long term unemployment directly in priority communities, including opportunities for education and training;

demonstrate clear and stable pathways from local communities to London's broader opportunities; 

directly address the retention development or expansion of employment in the key economic areas discussed in this Framework; 

seek to raise educational attainment, particularly in the Education Action Zones; 

address skills and lifelong learning, including widening participation in education; 

fully integrate business support, training education and employment initiatives with demonstrable transfer of benefit to local communities; 

address crime and the fear of crime;

offer equal opportunities for all Londoners and tackle the needs of London's ethnic minorities and other disadvantaged groups; 

demonstrably reduce the social, cultural, economic, learning and physical isolation of priority communities: the effective commitment of partnerships to community capacity building will, for most types of scheme, be a requisite for approval;

realistically address the improvement of physical and environmental quality in both the community and the workplace.

 INTRODUCTION
1.    This guidance has been produced by Government Office North West for prospective bidders under SRB Round 5. It supplements the national bidding guidance and should be read in conjunction with it. The purpose of this document is to set a strategic context within which the bids for 1999/2000 will be considered by GONW and the Regional Development Agency.

2.    The Framework has been informed by discussion with the Rural Development Commission, the NW RDA Secretariat, English Partnerships, INWARD and the NW Regional Chamber.

Background - Regional Issues
3.    The North West is a major region, with the largest economy in the UK after London, and the South East, producing almost 11% of the UK Gross Domestic Product. GDP per head is however 11% below the UK average, and 13% below the European average. It contains 6.9 million people, 1 in 8 of UK's population and 1 in 50 of the EU urban core. Outside Cumbria the North West Region is 6 times more densely populated than the EU average and 4 times more densely populated than the UK average. Even including predominantly rural Cumbria the North West is 3 times more densely populated than the EU average. Most of the population (58%) lives in the conurbations of Greater Manchester (2.6 million) and Merseyside (1.4 million), but 80% of the land area remains open countryside.

4.    One of the World's first industrial regions, it is still a major manufacturing centre but has experienced steady decline in traditional manufacturing employment over the last four decades. The region has consequently experienced high levels of unemployment especially in its urban centres, where despite progress, under-achievement in basic literacy, numeracy and IT skills needs remedying. There is also a legacy of poor quality housing conditions, a close mix of residential areas and heavy industry adjacent to the West Coast Main Line, pollution, and outdated surface and underground infrastructure. The region's substantial rural areas, ranging from South Cheshire to the remote North Pennines, also have problems ranging from local income to high levels of crime. The narrowness of the economy and general access are main concerns.

Regional Development Themes
5.    The broad consensual themes for the future development of the North West are well established in key strategy documents such as North West Partnership's Economic Strategy and Regional Competitiveness Strategy. They are that the North West should become:

a world class centre for the production of high quality goods and services;

a Region where profitable, successful companies able to compete on a global scale are increasing;

a Region that attracts new business by providing a choice of suitable sites and premises;

a Region seeking to raise the standards and achievement levels in education and training to world class levels;

a Region dedicated to the recruitment, retention and effective use of highly skilled people within North West Businesses;

a Region characterised by the widespread availability and use of leading-edge information and communication technology;

a Region that is attractive and safe to live, work and invest in, and to visit;

a Region with a well managed, balanced and efficient transport system which contributes to national sustainability objectives;

a Region determined to tackle the huge problem of housing unfitness and supportive of the Government's target for more brownfield housing development.

a region amongst the very best in Europe and elsewhere and achieving greater cohesion within the region by addressing the needs of deprived areas and the needs of the least advantaged of its residents.

SRB resources will be used to help the North West work towards these aims.

7.   Ministers have indicated that they wish to see the majority of SRB Round 5 resources targeted towards large, comprehensive schemes in the most deprived districts nationally according to the Index of Local Deprivation and as identified in the national Bidding Guidance (see extract at Annex A (Annex C in the Bidding Guidance)). In Round 5 resources will be concentrated on a small number (5 or 6) of comprehensive regeneration bids of about £20m-£25m. There may be exceptional circumstances where bids of a lesser value would be considered. Partnerships should contact the Government Office about funding levels. Individual schemes may run from one to seven years. The bulk of expenditure on comprehensive regeneration schemes will be expected to take place over five years. However, capacity building at the neighbourhood level and the creation of effective ways to broaden opportunities is not a quick process, so a full seven years expenditure on such elements will be expected.

8.   Outside the most deprived areas identified in Annex A, it will be possible to support a small number of modest bids from identifiable pockets of need in other rural and urban areas in the region. These will include bids from coalfield, rural and coastal areas.

9.   Successful bids, unless they are by established Partnerships and build on existing initiatives, are likely to have only modest project costs in Year 1. New or Community led Partnerships should regard Year 1 as a development year to ensure that Partnership and management systems are in place with significant expenditure commencing in Year 2. Established Partnerships, especially those building on existing initiatives, are expected to bid for and incur expenditure in Year 1. All Partnerships should include realistic expenditure in their financial profiles. With the need for Delivery Plans to be agreed and appraisals approved, SRB resources are unlikely to be released before September/October 1999.

North West Priority Issues
10.   It is expected that the majority of Round 5 bids will be area based. There is scope for thematic bids which address single themes but they will need to clearly concentrate resources on combating deprivation and social exclusion.

11.   Priority activities for the North West remain similar to those for Round 4, and those issues emerging from key regional strategies. Many of these issues will be reflected in the Regional Economic Strategy which will be prepared by the Regional Development Agency. The RES will provide a framework for Regional and economic development and establish priorities for programmes including Round 5 SRB. In the meantime bids, whether for comprehensive or local regeneration schemes, should aim to tackle social exclusion and community capacity building. In addition they should address one or more of the following priorities:-

reflect the needs of the urban areas of the Region, particularly those communities suffering from multiple-deprivation requiring action on the health and education fronts as well as tackling poor living standards;

enable innovative health activities which tackle inequalities associated with social and economic circumstance;

tie in with priorities identified by the Coalfields Task Force and address the problems associated with former Coalfields areas;

address the needs of Rural Development Areas, such as low wages, SME competitiveness, diversification of the local economy, access to services and facilities and the needs for balanced communities meeting the needs of young and old;

tackle educational progression and achievement from childhood onwards, including an emphasis on parenting skills;

propose effective partnership-based methods for achieving the wider regional objectives of improving educational attainment including those for Welfare to Work, contributing to local capacity building via ethnic minority, voluntary and community sector activities, and involving young people in the pursuit of sustainability through environmental task forces;

promote imaginative and value for money routes into employment beyond traditional job creation measures through, for example, support for intermediate labour market measures to improve confidence and extend opportunities of job and training choice particularly the socially excluded; through expanding the tourism industry in the Region; developing appropriate public transport in line with the objectives of the Transport White Paper;

address the needs of areas and/or residents suffering from crime and the fear of crime through the development of innovative schemes involving local communities, the unemployed and ethnic minorities as well as the police and the local authority. Proposals should be consistent with the measures in the Crime and Disorder Act;

demonstrate that SRB will bring added value to resources released for housing and through New Deal for Communities;

demonstrate that SRB, probably in conjunction with other forms of funding and private investment, is needed to ensure that some small and medium-sized enterprises become competitive as a result of being willing and able to embrace new technological methods, and link the benefits of that to local communities;

develop business support, particularly business start ups with particular emphasis on using innovation in technology and knowledge to increase economic competitiveness;

the development of city and town centres to create safe and thriving areas across the region, particularly building upon town centre management experience;

take forward the environmental sustainability agenda at the local level and activities which deliver direct benefits to business competitiveness;

recognise the importance of heritage and the arts in regeneration;

 Synergy
12.   SRB proposals should be developed within wider local regeneration strategies. These strategies should show how the proposed SRB activity would add value to:

a.mainstream public sector programmes and services, especially those delivered by local authorities and the TECs and Business Links;

b.Government initiatives especially Welfare to Work but also, where relevant, Employment, Health and Education Action Zones, and the New Deal for Communities Pathfinders;

c.the regional and local strategies of bodies such as English Partnerships, the North West Regional Chamber and the Rural Development Commission;

d.the priorities identified by the Coalfields Task Force;

e.housing strategies and priorities addressed in New Deal for Communities;

f.European Funding particularly Action Plans and Pathways.

13.   Proposals should also be consistent with policies set out in the Regional Planning Guidance for the North West, the Regional Competitiveness Strategy and the region's Single Programming Documents.

Assessment of Bids
14.   Successful bids will need to show that they represent broadly based Partnerships directly involving communities and provide comprehensive approaches to the priority needs set out in the guidance.

15.   Partnership development and management will be particularly important in the assessment of bids. Partnerships will increasingly need to develop consultative structures with those people that regeneration objectives seek to touch and serve, and to respond to community needs and aspirations rather than dictate top-down solutions. Bidders will normally be expected to check and demonstrate the sustainability of their proposals. This will be important in the evaluation of bids by GONW/RDA. Evidence that Partnerships have considered their Forward Strategies will be a key part of each bid's sustainability.

16.   The content of bids will be assessed with careful regard to their proposals to address social exclusion and enhance opportunities for those at a disadvantage in the areas of greatest need. They should add value to and not duplicate any existing partnership activity in these deprived areas. This could be achieved through the development of sustainable community based responses to local need and more effective targeting of existing and proposed programmes and services.

17.   Community based initiatives such as credit unions, development trusts and Local Exchange and Trading Systems (LETS) have been a feature of regeneration activities over a number of years. The Government also wants to support the growing movement towards innovative community enterprise and investment schemes, including those which encourage innovative approaches to access to capital. There is scope within the North West's allocation for providing up to £50,000 SRB on such pilot schemes on a match funding basis. Potential bidders should note that this sum is not ringfenced. Any Partnership should contact GONW if they wish to consider a community based initiative to discuss available resources.

18.   The proposals should demonstrate clear linkages with other regeneration activity and main programme priorities. Local partnerships will be expected to demonstrate the active involvement of relevant public agencies, private and voluntary sector interests and local residents in the preparation and proposed implementation of their proposals. Public sector partners such as English Partnerships should be contacted by bidders whilst outline proposals are being developed to ensure their active commitment. They will also need to provide assurance that effective local management systems will be in place and that projects will be rigorously appraised.

19.   Partnerships should ensure that outputs are clearly defined as "core" or "complementary" depending upon whether the Partnership has control over their delivery. GONW will be able to provide specific advice on individual definitions.

20.   A key issue in assessing bids will be the extent, quality and importance of the planned outcomes that are planned and the significance of the impact the bid would have on the problems it addresses. It is particularly important for bids to identify a clear baseline position. Bids will also be assessed against the emerging priorities of the North West Regional Development Agency as responsibility for SRB will transfer to the NW RDA on 1 April 1999. Outline Round 5 proposals will be assessed by GONW in consultation with the RDA Shadow Board. Final bids will be appraised by the RDA, with decisions taken by Ministers. Details of the proposed hand over arrangements will be provided later in the year. The assessment timetable is shown in Chapter 6 of the National SRB Guidance.

Liaison with GONW
21.   Local partnerships will need to work closely with GONW in the preparation of their bids to ensure that they receive the best possible advice and guidance. In particular, Partnerships in the priority areas should involve GONW in the development of local regeneration strategies and the proposed comprehensive schemes. Partnerships looking to access European Funding to support their SRB bid should contact the European Secretariat to discuss the likely availability of resources (subject to the necessary legislation) and ensure linkages with CED's. It is equally important that potential bidders in rural areas liaise closely with the Rural Development Commission as well as GONW.

22.   Bids which have not been the subject of informal discussion ahead of the 27 November deadline are much less likely to succeed. Bidders will wish to discuss their proposals and spending profiles with GONW to ensure that they build flexibility into their profiles and activities.

 Statement of Regional Regeneration Priorities
1.    The purpose of this statement is to supplement the national bidding guidance for the SRB Challenge Fund (SRBCF) : the Bidding Guidance document for SRBCF Round 5 issued on 9th September 1998

2.     It sets out the priorities which the South East England Development Agency (SEEDA) will apply in addition to national guidance, when assessing proposals for awarding funding under SRBCF Round 5.

3.     Successive SRBCF Rounds have been very competitive and Round 5 continues the trend, with more emphasis placed on quality of partnerships and agreed local vision. The level of resources available in Round 5 is significantly more than in Round 4.

4.     The indicative allocation for the South East under Round 5 breaks down to:

Year 1 (1999/2000)    £ 4 - 5 million Each subsequent year    £ 9 - 11 million

In the case of the large scale regeneration schemes referred to in paragraph 10a. we would expect the bulk of expenditure to take place over 5 years. For other schemes referred to in paragraphs 10b and 11 funding will be available for 1 -7 years, if resources permit.

5.     Partnerships must consider carefully whether bidding for Challenge Funding is the most appropriate way to secure additional funding for their regeneration strategy. Preparing proposals which have some likelihood of success takes a great deal of time and effort, with no certainty of an award.

6.   The South East has a competitive economy in UK terms, supplying just over 15% of the UK's GDP. However prosperity is not evenly spread. The 1998 Index of Local Deprivation (ILD) highlights this. There are pockets of social exclusion and deprivation across the Region. 

7.   In order to maintain and improve competitiveness the region must address constraints on its capacity to accommodate economic growth. This involves ensuring that individuals and communities across the whole of the South East can benefit from and contribute to economic success; and ensuring that the quality of the environment is maintained and enhanced. The Challenge Fund provides support to locally driven regeneration initiatives and funding will be targeted to areas of greatest need.

8.    The priorities set out below give a clear indication of how SEEDA intends to target resources to areas of greatest need. This will help partnerships decide whether or not to put forward proposals in Round 5.

9.     Partnerships wanting to submit proposals for Round 5 must meet the geographic and partnership priorities set out below, in addition to the requirements of the Bidding Guidance. Moreover, partnerships with funding from previous SRBCF rounds must demonstrate a good track record on delivery of schemes and community involvement.

10.    Geographic Priorities - To target Challenge Fund resources to areas of greatest need:

Priority will be given to proposals from partnerships primarily addressing needs in the following geographical locations:-

a) those local authority districts that have been targeted by DETR Ministers as within the top tranche of most deprived local authority districts as determined by the 1998 Index of Local Deprivation (ILD). These areas are designated by the highest levels of deprivation at district, ward or enumeration district level, on any of the 4 ILD measures.  Partnership Priorities 
12.     Bids must come from partnerships of appropriate public, private, community and voluntary sector organisations, with sufficient capability to meet the requirements set out in the Guidance Notes and to deliver their proposed scheme. This includes new partnerships bidding for the first time.

13.   Partnerships must show clear linkages with local area based initiatives and public programmes as appropriate.

14.   Experience shows the more innovative schemes have a clear geographical focus, are based on thorough research and active involvement with residents on the needs of an area and submitted by a broad based partnership. Many of the best schemes deliver a broad range of outputs designed to address the needs of an area as a whole. Single purpose bids may be supported provided they are set in the context of a regeneration strategy for the area. The effective commitment of partnerships to community capacity building will be a criterion of support. Where bids include physical development, especially of derelict land, bidders should consult English Partnerships.

15.   The Region expects an allocation of up to £120,000 to support innovative community enterprise and investment schemes. This funding will be available on a matched funding basis to a limit of £50,000 per scheme. Partnerships considering such proposals should contact GOSE as soon as possible.

16.   Existing partnerships will be aware of the possibilities for European funding available in their areas and its use to improve value for money in regeneration schemes. New partnerships who wish to know more about European funding should contact John Pinnell at GOSE; telephone 01483 882541. 

Bidding Arrangements
17.     Partnerships MUST contact GOSE to discuss their proposals as soon as possible. Proposals received at the 'expression of interest' (outline bid) deadline without any previous contact with GOSE will NOT be supported. Bids from Rural Development Areas must also contact the Rural Development Commission.

18.     You will note from the bidding guidance that submission of final bids should be made to the SEEDA, rather than GOSE, and it is SEEDA who will be making recommendations to Ministers on winners. SEEDA will become operational on 1 April 1999. Allan Willett is the Chairman designate and has been consulted in drawing up this guidance. More detailed information on location, contacts and hand-over arrangements will be given to appropriate bidders before the final bidding stage.

 Resources
1.   We expect to have in the range of £6m-£8m available for new schemes in 1999/2000 and about £16m-£18m in 2000/01 and 2001/02.

2.   It will be helpful if bidders discuss proposed spending profiles with GO-WM before submitting a final bid and that they think carefully about building flexibility into their profiles.

Need
3.   The approach adopted in the Round 4 West Midlands Framework was close to the pattern of priorities emerging from the Regeneration Comprehensive Spending Review. There is therefore no need for a major restatement of the framework in the light of Round 5.

4.   The West Midlands has two authorities - Birmingham and Sandwell - which feature in the top ten most deprived Districts in the Index of Deprivation. The scale and intensity of deprivation in Birmingham and Sandwell is of special concern and bids which concentrate effort and resources to achieve a lasting impact in these most deprived areas of the region will be actively encouraged.

5.   A number of other West Midlands Districts exhibit deprivation well above the national average according to the Index of Deprivation. Bids specifically targeted on meeting needs in Wolverhampton, Walsall, Coventry and Stoke-on-Trent will be welcomed.

6.   It is expected that schemes in the above six areas will account for eighty per cent of resources available for new projects in the West Midlands.

7.   The remaining twenty per cent of resources are available to meet pockets of need which may be identified more widely across the region. Bids targeted on the needs of small areas, including rural and ex-coalfields communities, and supported by detailed deprivation and other relevant data applicable to the area will be considered for funding from the twenty per cent.

West Midlands Priority Themes
8.   First, the region is home to a significant population from black and minority ethnic communities. The age structure of these communities tends to be younger than the regional average. They suffer disproportionately from long term, especially male long term, unemployment. English remains the second language within some communities presenting particular challenges in the education system and the workplace. Regrettably racial discrimination is still perceived to be an obstacle to success for many of these communities. It is important that the SRB backs schemes which will help these groups to share better in the prosperity of the region. Bids which directly involve ethnic minority communities as partners in the planning and delivery of initiatives will be particularly welcomed.

9.   Secondly, the workforce of the West Midlands has historically been less qualified than the British workforce as a whole and West Midlands school leavers are less well qualified than the national average. People are the key to the region's international competitiveness. Competitive advantage is dependent on the skills, inventiveness and entrepreneurial ability of the people of the West Midlands. Priorities for the region are therefore to enable young people to achieve the highest possible levels of educational attainment, to raise the skills levels of the workforce and match these to the needs of West Midlands employers, and to improve the quality and quantity of school/business contacts. There is serious concern in the region about the attitudes in society, schools, homes towards manufacturing industry which is still a highly significant employer in the region. Changes in the culture this represents are desirable and any SRB project supporting such changes will be looked on with some favour.

10.   There is evidence in some parts of the West Midlands of families who have not known the experience of working through two or more generations. In these families there is no expectation about learning or work and no sense that a route out of poverty can be found or would succeed. Action targeting this deep rooted and difficult to change aspect of economic and social dependency is also a priority for the region, as are projects which reinforce the New Deal programme, in encouraging youngsters and older people into the workplace.

11.   Some of the worst concentrations of multiple deprivation occur in areas of poor housing. SRB has the potential to link improvements of the housing stock with training, education and employment opportunities for local people. Residents surveys undertaken by many local authorities show that crime and fear of crime feature high on the list of community concerns. There is scope to use the SRB to develop Community Safety initiatives linked to the partnership led Crime and Disorder strategies in the Region.

12.   Proposals for improving the health of those who are the worst off and the most vulnerable in the region are a priority. Parts of the West Midlands score high against a number of indicators for poor health and are amongst the worst in the country. The health inequalities are very marked and closely linked to levels of deprivation. Major determinants of poor health in addition to those above are the environment, poor access to services (not just health services) and type of lifestyle. There are also known to be serious concerns about drugs use in both rural and urban parts of the West Midlands. SRB can be used to support efforts to develop effective responses to substance misuse which build on the work of Drugs Action Team partnerships within the region.

13.   Annex E of the bidding guidance refers to innovative community enterprise schemes. Resources are included within paragraph 1 above for match funding for such schemes and it is anticipated that a small number of such schemes might be supported.

14.   Priority areas of need in rural areas have already been identified by Rural Development Areas. Bids are invited that tackle relevant rural issues such as low wages, SME competitiveness, diversification of the local economy, access to services and facilities and the need for balanced communities meeting the need of young and old.

 Synergy
15.   Through City Pride in Birmingham and the recently announced LGA New Commitment Pathfinders, more emphasis is now being placed on the development of broad district-wide area regeneration strategies. Where such strategic regeneration partnerships exist, SRB bids should have been discussed with the Partnership and support its strategy. Bids should also take account of English Partnership's West Midlands Regional Strategy due to be issued in September.

16.   Bidders will also wish to be aware of the impact of any targeted area initiative such as, for example, Health Action Zones, Education Action Zones, which may offer scope for SRB proposals to support innovative or cross-authority approaches in local areas.

17.   Bids may reinforce economic regeneration activity being undertaken through the European Structural Funds. Although the 1998 bidding round has been completed, there will be a bidding opportunity in Spring 1999. Guidance on the post-1999 European Structural Funds for the region is being negotiated.

Process
18.   This Round of SRB is being launched in a transitional year, alongside the establishment of the Regional Development Agency. Alex Stephenson, the Chairman designate of the West Midlands RDA, has been consulted on the regional framework and it is intended that the RDA Board, when appointed, will take a view on the bids coming forward at outline stage. It will, however, be necessary for GO-WM to handle the process on behalf of the incoming RDA prior to 1 April 1999.
