 Introduction
1.   This document supplements the Single Regeneration Budget Round 5 Bidding Guidance which was launched on 8 September 1998. It aims to guide potential bidders on the needs and priorities within Yorkshire & the Humber and to indicate the scale of resources likely to be available to support these. It is intended to help structure and direct discussions between Government Office for Yorkshire & the Humber (GOYH) and those preparing Round 5 proposals.

2.   The Yorkshire & the Humber Regional Development Agency Chairman-designate (Graham Hall) has been consulted during the preparation of this document and has given his support. He has indicated that he regards this bidding round as a transitional year, and it is likely that future rounds will have a sharper focus in tune with RDA priorities. Relevant regional publications are listed at Annex 1 and any Round 5 proposals will be expected to demonstrate clear linkages with the key messages they contain.

Regional Context
3.   The 1998 Index of Local Deprivation shows that many of the region's local authorities are among the worst 100 nationally. Eight local authorities, covering the whole of South Yorkshire and much of West Yorkshire, fall within the worst 50 nationally on one or more measures. There are other pockets of severe poverty and deprivation in rural areas, particularly the remote upland areas, and in those parts of the region most affected by the consequences of declining employment in traditional industries such as coal mining, textiles, metal manufacture and fishing.

4.   Unemployment in the region has been falling steadily over the last three years but has remained consistently above national rates. There are wide variations in unemployment rates with pockets of very high unemployment in parts of the region and amongst particular groups, for example, ethnic minority communities. Hidden unemployment in rural areas with their greater access and delivery costs is also an issue. The proportion of people who are long term unemployed has also fallen but remains significant.

5.   Gross Domestic Product has grown steadily in line with national trends. However, GDP per head was only 91.2% of the UK average in 1995, although growth in GDP per head was above the UK average. There are wide variations in GDP at sub-regional level where, for example, in South Yorkshire GDP was only 75.6% of the UK average. Although North Yorkshire displays above average levels of GDP per head, the region includes five Rural Development Areas, designated due to high concentrations of economic and social need.

6.   Despite steady improvements in educational achievement and skill levels, the region lags behind a number of other regions. Improvements in GCSE performance in 1997 were above the English average and participation in education beyond 16 continues to grow. Performance across the region varies significantly and research has indicated a strong correlation between poor educational performance and social deprivation. Skills levels are improving although they remain below the national average and the present targets will be difficult to achieve. Many employers are committed to training but there remains a significant minority who need to be convinced of the benefits.

7.   The region has some of the worst local authority housing stock, the physical condition of which has declined relative to other sectors, and which continues to take on an increasingly welfare role. However, concentrations of deprivation are also associated with high levels of disrepair, unfitness and low energy efficiency in private sector housing. Statistics disguise considerable differences within the region although communities living in poor housing areas are also the most likely to suffer multiple deprivation through social and economic exclusion, rising crime and poor health.

8.   The next few years will see significant shifts in the resources available to support regeneration activities in different parts of the region. In particular, the targeting of European Commission programmes is currently under negotiation.

 Resources and Targeting
9.   All existing commitments to SRB Rounds 1 - 4 will continue to be honoured, subject to continuing performance in line with delivery plans. New resources available to support SRB Round 5 activities within Yorkshire & the Humber will be in the order of £9-11m in 1999/2000 and £20-24m in each of the two subsequent years. The total value for Yorkshire & the Humber Round 5 funding will be in the order of £90-100m over the next five years.

10.   Around 80% of the resources available over the next three years will be targeted on areas of extensive and multiple deprivation. These are defined as the areas which feature in the top 50 on one or more measures in the 1998 Index of Local Deprivation. The resulting priority areas within Yorkshire & the Humber are listed at Annex 2, and these include many of the communities which have suffered the worst effects of coal closures. Where a local authority area is included due to its position on a particular enumeration district or ward level indicator, any proposals will be expected to include measures which specifically address the needs of that locality.

11.   As indicated in the Round 5 national Bidding Guidance, schemes funded from the 80% will involve large scale, comprehensive approaches to addressing regeneration needs. An average scheme value of £20-25m in SRB funding over 5 years is likely, but schemes of both higher and lower values will be supported. The resources available will not be sufficient to support such schemes in all the priority areas under Round 5, and there will continue to be competition for the available funds. Round 5 funding will provide support for 2-3 comprehensive schemes, but future spending plans allow for further large schemes in other areas to be considered in subsequent years. Round 5 resources will also allow support for some small scale activity, such as capacity building or linking of existing schemes, in priority areas which do not obtain more comprehensive support. Partnerships in priority areas may wish to consider the merits of submitting a small scale proposal alongside a more comprehensive bid, or identifying specific elements of their proposals which might be considered for individual support. Some partnerships may wish to consider submitting only a small scale bid for Round 5 support to allow for initiatives which prepare the ground for a more comprehensive proposal in a future round.

12.   The remaining 20% of Round 5 resources will be used to support projects which tackle identified pockets of deprivation elsewhere. Particular priority will be given to rural areas and former coalfield areas which fall outside those local authorities listed in Annex 2. These local schemes are likely to be specifically targeted, realistic in scale, and will need to be supported by clearly evidenced indicators of need.

13.   The national Bidding Guidance refers to innovative community enterprise and investment schemes. The resources indicated in paragraph 9 above include funds for schemes such as credit unions, development trusts and Local Exchange and Trading Systems and it is anticipated that a small number of such schemes might be supported. However, total regional funding for these is unlikley to exceed £300,000.

14.   Support for thematic, rather than area-based, bids will also be considered where a clear case can be made for an initiative which covers a sub-region or the whole region.

15.   Support will only be considered for good quality proposals which clearly demonstrate that they :

reflect local circumstances;

will lead to significant impact;

have measurable outcomes which contribute to Government targets;

will provide value for money; and

can provide assurance of sound financial and operational management and monitoring arrangements.

Accountable Bodies will be expected to demonstrate that they take a clear lead in ensuring the delivery, performance, quality and evaluation of successful schemes.

 Regional Priorities
16.   Partnerships should adopt a strategic approach to regeneration which ensures that proposals complement and build on existing activities. Bids may build on current SRB funded schemes, and where appropriate they may pull together or extend existing SRB initiatives to ensure maximum impact and sustainability. 

17.   Proposals should specify how they will add value to mainstream public sector programmes and services, especially those delivered by local authorities and Training & Enterprise Councils. Linkages with other policies, area-based initiatives and strategies will need to be explicit (e.g. New Deal for Communities; Welfare to Work; Health/Education Action Zones; Crime and Disorder measures; strategies of agencies such as English Partnerships and Rural Development Commission, etc.) and proposals will need to demonstrate how local strategies complement wider sub-regional and regional strategies. In particular, they will need to show how they link with European funded activities and area-based action plans.

18.   Partnerships will need to demonstrate that local communities have been fully consulted, and they are directly involved in, and supportive of, proposed schemes. Partnerships themselves will be expected to be inclusive and to take active steps to promote local participation. Proposals should address the issue of partnership capacity building and show how the local community will be engaged and equipped to participate meaningfully in the regeneration of its area. Voluntary and community sector capacity building should be linked to a properly constructed community development plan.

19.   Proposals will be expected to maximise available resources through private sector leverage and other partnership contributions. Realistic assessments should be supported by clear justification, and will need to take into account the potential impact of any changes in availability of European or other funds.

20.   All proposals should address social exclusion and enhance opportunities for those at a disadvantage in the areas of greatest need. Bids will need to reflect the findings of the Government's Social Exclusion Unit. In particular, the interests and needs of those from ethnic minority communities should be addressed specifically and adequately, and appropriate ethnic minority representation in partnerships will be essential. Proposals should also make clear how they will address the often inter-related issues which can place young people at a social disadvantage.

21.   Priority will be given to proposals in respect of former coalfield areas. These will need to take account of the multiple deprivation identified in these areas and must clearly address the issues raised in the recent Coalfield Task Force report. Partnerships may wish to consider the possible merits of a collaborative approach to regeneration and joint proposals for addressing the needs of the region's coalfields which maximise available resources.

22.   Sustainable development requires both a healthy rural environment and a healthy rural economy that respects and sustains the environment. A healthy rural economy is important for many reasons, including economic growth, conservation and combating social exclusion and poverty. Problems exist in terms of the scattered nature of local communities, the narrow economic base in many areas and the shortage of employment and training opportunities. The region needs to tackle these issues in order to create the conditions necessary to allow rural enterprise to flourish and to ensure a diverse and vibrant rural economy. Rural proposals will be expected to focus on needs and priorities in those areas designated as Rural Development Areas (see Annex 3) and that have been identified in the Rural Development Programme and other relevant local strategies. Where appropriate bids will need to show how they build on activities supported under the Rural Challenge Fund.

23.   Education and skills development remains of key importance for the region. Short term priorities include: raising attainment at secondary school level; raising the skill levels of those in employment; development of key skills; and development of Information Technology skills. Ensuring that those leaving education are fully equipped with the skills and attitudes required by employers will be of key importance.These issues might be addressed through initiatives such as intensive work experience programmes and through further development of linkages between employers and education and training providers. Proposals will need to make clear how they meet the identified education and training needs of their particular locality, including any specific emerging skill shortages. Important areas for longer term investment include: pre-school and primary school developments; continuing development of basic skills and IT skills ; and the opening up of access facilities outside school hours, including summer school developments.

24.   Bids will be expected to include measures to address crime reduction and demonstrate how they will link to local crime reduction and community safety strategies published by the statutory partnerships established under the Crime & Disorder Act. Elements which have often been overlooked in earlier rounds are victim support, preventing repeat victimisation and managing offenders/ex-offenders in the community. Bids should also consider how they will link with Youth Offending Teams which are to be established by local authorities under the Crime & Disorder Act.

25.   The worst ward areas featuring in the Index of Local Deprivation are associated with poor housing conditions which are unlikely to be addressed by Housing Investment Programme and Capital Receipts Initiative resources alone. SRB strategies aimed at addressing multiple deprivation should not ignore the housing element and such bids should show how housing issues feed into the proposed plans for regeneration. Where appropriate , they should also take into account Government resources being made available through the New Deal for Communities.

26.   The Regional Housing Framework for Yorkshire & the Humber identified eight key themes:

joint working arrangements;

housing market analysis;

housing quality;

unpopular housing

planning for growth;

supported housing;

rural and remote housing; and

special needs housing, including black and ethnic minorities.

Most of these are inextricably linked to economic and social regeneration, and can only be addressed by local housing authorities working in partnership with mainstream service providers and regeneration agencies. It is increasingly accepted that there are some structural mismatches between supply and demand for some housing types and locations. Regeneration through demolition and (partial) replacement may be the most satisfactory option here, following rigorous option appraisal. The issue of homelessness will also need to be specifically addressed where appropriate.

27.   Bidders will need to consider the impact of their proposals on the environment. In particular, the following issues should be taken into account:

dealing with the legacy of derelict and contaminated land, particularly in former coalfield areas, and the need to avoid use of greenfield sites;

encouraging greater use of walking, cycling and public transport and minimising the travel impacts of development, building on integrated transport strategies and land use planning;

encouraging community involvement in the management of their local environment through the LA21 process;

looking at ways to manage waste better, through minimisation, recycling and utilisation schemes;

sustaining and enhancing the character of local environments, whether built or natural.

28.   Other issues which proposals should take into account include:

The contribution which sporting and cultural interests can make to regeneration strategies - particularly linked to quality of life objectives, to personal and community capacity building, and to improving educational achievements;

Links to the work of local Drug Action Teams and the implementation of the Government's 10 year strategy for tackling drug abuse ("Tackling Drugs to Build a Safer Britain", published April 1998);

Measures which support and strengthen families. Key themes include: support for parenting, support for families and children at risk, promoting volunteering, tackling social exclusion;

Attention to good design - particularly "Secure by Design", a standard which is recognised and promoted by all four police forces in the region - and how good design can contribute to fire safety and prevention.

 Timetable and Decision Process
29.   The full bidding timetable is set out in the SRB Round 5 Bidding Guidance. Key deadlines are:

27 November 1998  - submission of expressions of interest to GOYH;

30 April 1999           - submission of final bids to the RDA;

June 1999                 - bidders informed of decisions.

30.   Expressions of interest should be submitted using the proforma as set out in the national Bidding Guidance. Those partnerships bidding for large scale funding for comprehensive schemes will be expected to supplement this with a "first draft" of the final bid to facilitate meaningful assessment and constructive dialogue. It is anticipated that the emerging RDA Shadow Board will be consulted on the merits of proposals at expressions of interest stage. This will take place mid-December 1998, with responses to partnerships and feedback meetings in January 1999. When formally established, the RDA Board will assess final bids and make recommendations to Ministers. (Further details of the RDA's address, SRB contact name, etc. will be provided before the final bidding stage.)

31.   In order to limit the time and resources spent working up proposals with little prospect of financial support, those considering submissions must examine them critically to ensure they fully meet the requirements of the national Bidding Guidance and this Regional Framework. It will also be important for potential bidders to begin an early dialogue with GOYH and to work closely with the GO in the preparation of their bids. Any partnerships considering submitting a proposal who have not yet made contact with the Government Office should do so before 30 September 1998.

Contacts
